Speaker: NA
Text: Tuesday, 22 April 1980

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden)

Speaker: NA
Text: took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Clerk-Petition s have been lodged for

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation as follows and copies will be re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to the appropriate Ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members ofthe House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That there is an urgent need to ensure that the living stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dard of pensioners will not decline, as indeed the present

Speaker: NA
Text: level or cash benefits in real

Speaker: NA
Text: ment beyond indexation related to the movement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Consumer Price Index. By this and other means your pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: itioners urge that action to be taken to:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Adjust all pensions and benefits quarterly to the Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer Price Index, including the " fixed " 70's rate.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Raise all pensions and benefits to at least 30 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Average Weekly Earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Taxation relief for pensioners and others on low in-

Speaker: NA
Text: comes by:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) The present static threshold of $75 per week for

Speaker: NA
Text: taxation purposes be increased to $ 100 per week.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) A substantial reduction in indirect taxation on

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer goods.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Dobie, Mr Fisher, Mr Charles Jones,

Speaker: NA
Text: MACKenzie, Mr Leo MCLeay, Mr Morris and

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Street.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Land Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whereas before Europeans settled in Australia the Abor-

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal peoples of Australia had lived on their traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: lands from time immemorial and had in Aboriginal law and

Speaker: NA
Text: customs a clear title to those lands; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas Europeans and other non-Aboriginal people

Speaker: NA
Text: have occupied and used most of the traditional lands of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal peoples against their will and without nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiation, compensation or treaty; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas it has been the practice of nations established in

Speaker: NA
Text: territories previously occupied by indigenous inhabitants to

Speaker: NA
Text: reach a negotiated settlement with those inhabitants; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas that occupation has seriously damaged the tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional way oflife of Aboriginal Australians and has caused

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty and hardship to be the fate of the great majority of

Speaker: NA
Text: their surviving descendants; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the surviving descendants of the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: peoples have expressed a wish to have their rights to land

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged, to preserve their link with their Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: ancestors and to maintain their distinctive identity with its

Speaker: NA
Text: own cultural heritage; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the people of Australia in 1967 voted overwhelm-

Speaker: NA
Text: ingly that the Commonwealth Parliament should have re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility for laws relating to Aboriginal Australians; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas it is accepted internationally by the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations organisation that each country should work to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish the rights of indigenous peoples to self-

Speaker: NA
Text: determination, non-discrimination and the enjoyment of

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS their own culture; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the Woodward Commission in 1974 established

Speaker: NA
Text: principles by which Aboriginal rights to land should be

Speaker: NA
Text: acknowledged and realised; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament in

Speaker: NA
Text: Pensions February 1975resolvedthat Aboriginal Australians should

Speaker: NA
Text: be compensated for the loss of their traditional lands and for

Speaker: NA
Text: the damage to their way oflife; and

Speaker: NA
Text: whereas the Nauonal Aboriginal Conference unani-

Speaker: NA
Text: mously resolved in April 1979 in Canberra to ask the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth to negotiate a Treaty with Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians.

Speaker: NA
Text: terms requires upward adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government should invite the Aboriginal people of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia to negotiate a Treaty with the Commonwealth of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, and any Treaty should contain provisions relating

Speaker: NA
Text: to the following matters: (i) The protection of Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: identity, languages, law and culture, (ii) The recognition and

Speaker: NA
Text: restoration of rights to land by applying, throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, the recommendations of the Woodward Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission, (iii) The condiuons governing mining and exploi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation of other natural resources on Aboriginal land, (iv)

Speaker: NA
Text: Compensation to Aboriginal Australians for the loss of tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional lands and for damage to those lands and to their tradi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tional way of life, (v) The right of Aboriginal Australians to

Speaker: NA
Text: control their own affairs and to establish their own associ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations for this purpose.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petiuoners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr by Mr Holding, Mr James and Mr Kerin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Unemployment: Social Security Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That as it is clear that unemployment is a long term prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem in Australia, the Government should extend to the un-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed the same assistance as is given to any other disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantaged member of the community. There is an urgent

Speaker: NA
Text: need to alleviate the financial hardship and emotional stress

Speaker: NA
Text: that the unemployed are suffering.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) That the Government adopt positive policies to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce unemployment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) That the basic Unemployment Benefit be raised to at

Speaker: NA
Text: least the level of the poverty line as calculated by Pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fessor Henderson.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) In line with other Social Service additional income

Speaker: NA
Text: awards, and in order to encourage work creation

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes and the fostering of initiative and self re-

Speaker: NA
Text: spect, that the $6.00 per week additional income limit

Speaker: NA
Text: be raised to at least $20.00 per week.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) That the financial penalties above the earning of

Speaker: NA
Text: $20.00 per week, assessed on a monthly basis, be cal-

Speaker: NA
Text: culated at the same rate as other Social Security

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) That the Commonwealth grant subsidies to state

Speaker: NA
Text: governments so that the unemployed can be granted

Speaker: NA
Text: transport concessions in order that they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: penalised in job seeking.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) That pharmaceutical and medical concessions be

Speaker: NA
Text: granted to the unemployed equivalent to those

Speaker: NA
Text: received by other Social Service beneficiaries.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr James and Mr Kerin.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition ofthe undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in the electorate of Richmond respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we the undersigned wish to protest against the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: 2,4-D and 2,4,5-T as herbicides and ask the Council of Lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: more to ban their use until the Australian Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: leases its findings from its inquiry into these herbicides.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Anthony.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: petiuon of the undersigned citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth that many Australians are concerned with the inad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equacy of Overseas Aid, both Government and Private as

Speaker: NA
Text: well as with support for local charities. Such Aid is saving

Speaker: NA
Text: precious lives, giving undernourished and homeless people

Speaker: NA
Text: encouragement and help, bringing malnourished children to

Speaker: NA
Text: health, education and a better life, giving people friendship

Speaker: NA
Text: and a new hope.

Speaker: NA
Text: We therefore respectfully request that the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government provide some incentive to encourage such Aid

Speaker: NA
Text: by making the same tax concessions to approved voluntary

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas aid organizations, as are already provided for chari-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties working within Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Lionel Bowen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Peution received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Use of Live Animals in Scientific Research

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representadves in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition ofthe undersigned Citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth that the practice ofexperimenting upon

Speaker: NA
Text: living animals in the supposed interests of Mankind involves

Speaker: NA
Text: the infliction of much pain and distress upon defenceless

Speaker: NA
Text: creatures that it is no longer generally held that such inhu-

Speaker: NA
Text: mane experiments are an essential part of medical and other

Speaker: NA
Text: scientific research and that much progress has been made in

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of alternative methods which are generally cheaper

Speaker: NA
Text: and more accurate, safer and more reliable.

Speaker: NA
Text: Wherefore your petitioners pray that your Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: House will take all such measures as may be necessary to

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the estabUshment of research

Speaker: NA
Text: tutes to explore techniques which replace the use of living

Speaker: NA
Text: animals, to extend their adoption

Speaker: NA
Text: opment of other humane avenues of scientific investigation.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your pedtioners, as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr John Brown.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: National Women's Advisory Council

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members ofthe House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition ofthe undersigned citizens of Australia respect-

Speaker: NA
Text: fully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been democratically elected by the women of Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: Use of Herbicides That the National Women's Advisory Council is not

Speaker: NA
Text: representative ofthe women of Australia;

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council is a dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: criminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: Council imposed on them.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore pray:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the National Women's Advisory Council be

Speaker: NA
Text: abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity with Australian men of having issues of concern

Speaker: NA
Text: to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parlia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary representative without intervention and inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ference by an unrepresentative 'Advisory Council'.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petiuoners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Burns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Rum: Excise Duty

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the retail price of Australian rum is too high and

Speaker: NA
Text: should be reduced to enable the average Australian to buy

Speaker: NA
Text: it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that steps be taken

Speaker: NA
Text: to reduce the excise duty on Australian rum.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Donald Cameron.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Service Pensions

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: petition ofthe undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whereas the Government has recently extended the eligi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility for Service Pensions to include members of Allied

Speaker: NA
Text: forces, eligibility for merchant seamen remains excessively

Speaker: NA
Text: restrictive.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment extend eligibility for Service Pensions to all merchant

Speaker: NA
Text: seamen whose service took them into a theatre of war and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the practice of relying exclusively on forms T124X and

Speaker: NA
Text: TI24T to establish eligibility be abandoned.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Dawkins.

Speaker: NA
Text: within all existing Insti-

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: and to continue the devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: North Queensland Air Services

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. That Ansett Airlines of Australia have proposed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth Government that it be permitted to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate an airline service between Townsville and

Speaker: NA
Text: Singapore via Darwin.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. That the North Queensland Airports Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Council has brought down a report in favour of the

Speaker: NA
Text: designation of a North Queensland airport as an inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national airport.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. The Government approve of the Ansett proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: operate a service between Townsville and Singapore

Speaker: NA
Text: via Darwin.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. The Government approve any other reasonable appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for the use of a North Queensland airport for

Speaker: NA
Text: charter and regional

Speaker: NA
Text: destinations.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. The Government proceed with the designation of a

Speaker: NA
Text: North Queensland airport as an international airport

Speaker: NA
Text: without unreasonable delay.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Dean.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction of Cycle Path in the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives assembled. The petition of the under-

Speaker: NA
Text: signed citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That for reasons of commuter safety and to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: recreational use of Canberra's bushland areas a cycle path

Speaker: NA
Text: be immediately constructed by the National Capital Devel-

Speaker: NA
Text: opment Commission from Alexander Street, Red Hill, to

Speaker: NA
Text: Deakin.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Haslem.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Honourable Members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the undersigned concerned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and members of the human family respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: lays before your consciences and your regard for the honour

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia and its present and future well-being, the fol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowing considerations:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. That grave and callous infringements of the basic

Speaker: NA
Text: human rights to life and liberty have forced multitudes

Speaker: NA
Text: of our fellow human beings to leave the countries of

Speaker: NA
Text: their birth, the Indo-China States;

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. That in consequence of the brutal policies of the

Speaker: NA
Text: annical Totalitarian Government of Vietnam several

Speaker: NA
Text: hundred thousand refugee men, women and children

Speaker: NA
Text: have been victims through drowning

Speaker: NA
Text: ethnic and religious hatreds of their oppressors; -

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. That because of the failure of opulent nations to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide more than face-saving, token assistance, the

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of Hong Kong, Malaysia, Thailand and

Speaker: NA
Text: gapore have been strained beyond limit:

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. That Australia, a wealthy nation with vast areas like

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ord River region and vast undeveloped resources

Speaker: NA
Text: ideally suited for resettlement and development could:

Speaker: NA
Text: set up camps of lirst refuge for the processing and

Speaker: NA
Text: temporary settling ol" 250.000 refugees annually

Speaker: NA
Text: liluTihv alsu giving useful employment to suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: pivsenii) imeiiiploji'd Auslialiam as niralois and

Speaker: NA
Text: 'in.li'ciui. )-

Speaker: NA
Text: Recruit volunteers or use part of the armed ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices to seek out, rescue and convey to mainland

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia such refugees as have managed to leave

Speaker: NA
Text: the countries of Indo-China;

Speaker: NA
Text: Accept the reiterated offer of some Church organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: isations to resettle thousands of such refugees.

Speaker: NA
Text: 5. That the policy we advocate will not only rebound to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's honour, but will stimulate the economy by

Speaker: NA
Text: stepping up demand in housing, clothing, agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: accessories and so on.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Barry Jones.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: services to and from international

Speaker: NA
Text: Merchant Seaman: Repatriation Benefits

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members ofthe House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The peution of

Speaker: NA
Text: the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth

Speaker: NA
Text: that:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. Merchant seaman who were captured and held as pris-

Speaker: NA
Text: oners of war during World War II are not treated us

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Members of the Forces' (veterans) for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: entitlements to Repatriation benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. 'Member of the Forces' is defined by Part III, Section

Speaker: NA
Text: Capital Territory 23 (c) of the Repatriation Act 1920-70 as 'enlisted or

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed for service in connexion with naval or mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: tary preparations or operations'. 'Served in a theatre of

Speaker: NA
Text: war' means served at sea . . . at a time when

Speaker: NA
Text: danger from hostile forces of the enemy was incurred

Speaker: NA
Text: in that area . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. 114 Australian merchant seamen were repatriated

Speaker: NA
Text: after the war and it is estimated that only about 60 of

Speaker: NA
Text: these men survive today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Repatriation Acts Amendment Bill of 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: made available free medical and hospital treatment to

Speaker: NA
Text: all veterans who were prisoners of war. The reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: stated by the Minister, was that abnormal hardships

Speaker: NA
Text: and privations, suffered by these veterans, could affect

Speaker: NA
Text: their general health and well-being as they get on in

Speaker: NA
Text: years, and are deserving of special consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Refugees Your petitioners therefore pray that:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government should amend the appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate legislation so that merchant seamen prisoners-of-war are

Speaker: NA
Text: defined as'Members of the Forces'(or veterans) so that they

Speaker: NA
Text: are entitled to the appropriate Repatriation benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Barry Jones.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government honours its responsibilities to Aborigi-

Text: nal people according io ihe spirit of ihe 19ft 7 Referendum

Text: votegixing the Coinmoinvcalili Go\einmciii power io inicr

Speaker: NA
Text: that it takes action to ensure that the Noonkanbah com-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Health Care

Speaker: NA
Text: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: peution of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: that there are Australian Aboriginal children living

Speaker: NA
Text: under conditions of inadequate nutrition in the back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground of poor housing, hygiene, and overcrowding that

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts to 'a Third World enclave in the midst of

Speaker: NA
Text: affluence' (see also the Report from the House of Rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Aboriginal Health' 1979);

Speaker: NA
Text: that such a state of affairs is intolerable in our

Speaker: NA
Text: that only an effort on an unprecedented scale could cre-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate conditions that would give these children the rights set

Speaker: NA
Text: out in the United Nations

Speaker: NA
Text: Child.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your pedtioners therefore humbly pray that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will make generous funding available for the specific

Speaker: NA
Text: purposes of:

Speaker: NA
Text: making a real improvement in the health, housing, edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation, employment and welfare of the Aboriginal people,

Speaker: NA
Text: doing so with due regard for the needs, hopes and aspir-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations ofthe Aboriginal people themselves;

Speaker: NA
Text: providing increased help, encouragement and oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: tunity for Aboriginal people to train as nursing aides and

Speaker: NA
Text: in other paramedical roles, and as fully qualified nurses,

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors and social workers;

Speaker: NA
Text: providing increased health education for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people in ways that are acceptable to them.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Les MCMahon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble

Speaker: NA
Text: petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully

Speaker: NA
Text: showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1. We call upon the Commonwealth and State Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to select a site

Speaker: NA
Text: and to protect it by immediate development.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. We do not agree to the expansion of Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

Text: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTE

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Text: Is the Minister for Industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: Relations aware of an industrial dispute at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Omega navigation aid site in Victoria? Is it a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: marcation dispute, that is, a fight between two or

Speaker: NA
Text: more unions? What action is the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: taking to help resolve this matter?

Speaker: Mr STREET
Text: I am aware of a dispute which

Speaker: NA
Text: has arisen at the Omega site. The cause of the

Speaker: NA
Text: dispute is demands by the Australian Building

Speaker: NA
Text: Construction Employees and Builders Labourers

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation that its members do the work in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in erecting the transmission mast at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Omega station. This work is currently being done

Speaker: NA
Text: by members of the Federated Ironworkers As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sociation of AustraUa, and the BLF is now using

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial action to press its demands. As the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member has said, the dispute is a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: marcation one involving who does the work on

Speaker: NA
Text: the mast and, as in all demarcation disputes, the

Speaker: NA
Text: trade union movement has an obligation to see

Speaker: NA
Text: that work on the site continues pending resol-

Speaker: NA
Text: ution of the dispute.

Speaker: NA
Text: I point out that in 1977 this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: passed legislation strengthening the powers of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with disputes of this kind. These processes

Speaker: NA
Text: have not yet been exhausted. The Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: trying to ensure that the legislation which was

Speaker: NA
Text: passed then is used in the way in which it was

Speaker: NA
Text: intended to be used. We condemn the attempts

Speaker: NA
Text: by the BLF to win coverage through industrial

Speaker: NA
Text: action on this site, and we are keeping the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition under review.

Text: of people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr THOMSONI t must be used and, at the

Text: same time, protected. I invite the honourable

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: must be done in a sensible, rational and practical

Speaker: NA
Text: lationships between Australia and the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity. In the course of the multilateral trade

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiations we made some progress in getting

Speaker: NA
Text: some access to European countries for agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural commodities. We see that as a bridgehead

Speaker: NA
Text: for making further progress. The progress we

Speaker: NA
Text: have made in that regard should not be accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: as the end of the road. We will keep pushing to

Speaker: NA
Text: try to get greater access into the European mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: ket because we believe that ultimately the sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ventionist and subsidy policies of the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity will defeat themselves under their own

Speaker: NA
Text: weight. We believe that it is completely wrong to

Speaker: NA
Text: place an embargo on trade in foodstuffs when we

Speaker: NA
Text: in turn have placed no embargo on the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity's exports to Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: ETHANOL PRODUCTION

Speaker: Mr COTTER
Text: Is the Minister for Business

Speaker: NA
Text: and Consumer Affairs aware of the enormous

Speaker: NA
Text: interest in the Federal Government's decision to

Speaker: NA
Text: allow farmers to produce ethanol for fuel? When

Speaker: NA
Text: will the Government be issuing experimenter li-

Speaker: NA
Text: cences for the production of ethanol? Can the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister assure the House that farmers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kalgoorlie electorate will be amongst the first to

Speaker: NA
Text: receive licences?

Speaker: Mr GARLAND
Text: The position is that legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to provide experimenter licences is at

Speaker: NA
Text: present before the Senate. It provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: issue of some 50 licences. Applications for

Speaker: NA
Text: cences were invited some time ago by circular

Speaker: NA
Text: and Press release. I have had two inquiries from

Speaker: NA
Text: applicants from the Kalgoorlie electorate; but

Speaker: NA
Text: overall only some 26 formal applications have

Speaker: NA
Text: been received at present, although there has

Speaker: NA
Text: been a great deal of interest. These are being

Speaker: NA
Text: progressively examined and assessed by my

Speaker: NA
Text: Department and by that of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: National Development and Energy in antici-

Speaker: NA
Text: pation of the legislation. Most of them appear to

Speaker: NA
Text: be based on genuine research projects and, as

Speaker: NA
Text: such, I would expect them to be approved. Cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly advice will be sent to all applicants very

Speaker: NA
Text: soon and I expect that all legislative

Speaker: NA
Text: requirements-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MCLean-When ?

Speaker: Mr GARLAND
Text: A s the assessment is

Speaker: NA
Text: completed, but the legislation is not yet in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: Then there will be a necessity for gazettal of

Speaker: NA
Text: regulations. I expect that all that process will be

Speaker: NA
Text: finished during the next month.

Speaker: NA
Text: CHIEF JUSTICE OF AUSTRALIA

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Text: I direct my question to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Acting Attorney-General. Has the Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: reattention been drawn to an article in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Daily Telegraph of today's date which indicates

Speaker: NA
Text: that the New South Wales Corporate Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission is moving to have a company struck

Speaker: NA
Text: from the register for failing to provide annual re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turns since 1973? Is he aware that this company

Speaker: NA
Text: owns the home of the Chief Justice of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: in George Street, Careel Bay? Will the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: indicate whether the Government may recon-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider its decision not to provide the Chief Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: with palatial accommodation in Canberra if the

Speaker: NA
Text: home is sold up for the payment of fines?

Speaker: Mr ELLICOTT
Text: Th e question is simply

Speaker: NA
Text: answered by saying that there is no proposal to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide the Chief Justice with accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: by way of a home in the Australian Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: SOVIET INVASION OF AFGHANISTAN

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Text: I ask the Prime Minister:

Speaker: NA
Text: Has there been an almost universal condem-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, a

Speaker: NA
Text: condemnation expressed by the United Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Islamic Conference, including even the

Speaker: NA
Text: Palestine Liberation Organisation, all members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Association of South East Asian Nations,

Speaker: NA
Text: most Asian and western European countries and

Speaker: NA
Text: even some European communist parties?

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Probabl y even Indonesia.

Speaker: Mr NA BROWN
Text: We will see where the

Speaker: NA
Text: liLabor Party stands. In that case can the Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister say whether there has been any ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pression of pleasure at the Soviet invasion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghanistan or any expression of the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: one should rejoice at that invasion? If so, from

Speaker: NA
Text: what quarters has that expression of opinion

Speaker: NA
Text: come and what would be the implications for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's national security if onegave support

Speaker: NA
Text: within Australia to the expression of that view?

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Text: I take a point of order. Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, this is not under the direction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister or any other Minister. An

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member cannot ask whether there

Speaker: NA
Text: has been any expression of opinion anywhere on

Speaker: NA
Text: this issue. What is the proposition?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The question is seeking infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation from the head of the Government ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth, I take it, in order that the infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation can be taken into account by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member in forming his views about a matter

Speaker: NA
Text: of international importance.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: I take a point of order. I find

Speaker: NA
Text: your ruling fascinating, Mr Speaker. I would re-

Speaker: NA
Text: mind you that you ruled that the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: was not responsible for the behaviour ofhis Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: isters when a series of questions were raised

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to the business interests and conduct of the

Speaker: NA
Text: former Minister for Primary Industry. I merely

Speaker: NA
Text: raise this matter if you are determined to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister to go ahead and answer this

Speaker: NA
Text: question. Incidentally, we repudiate the view

Speaker: NA
Text: which was expressed in the paper-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman will make his point of order.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Mr Speaker, I think in all the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances you ought to allow me to finish be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause our assessment of the impartiality or other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise with which you administer the affairs of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament will very much be weighed in the bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance according to how you determine this mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter. I remind you, Mr Speaker, of your very tough

Speaker: NA
Text: rulings in relation to a series of questions to

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers-on e series, of course, specifically re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lated to the former Minister for Primary

Speaker: NA
Text: Industry-a s to the probity of their conduct as

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers and sometimes in relation to both the

Speaker: NA
Text: discharge of their duty as public office holders

Speaker: NA
Text: and conflict of interest arising from the probity

Speaker: NA
Text: their behaviour in, for instance, personal busi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness matters. I remind you that your initial ruling

Speaker: NA
Text: was to allow those questions but later you made

Speaker: NA
Text: a most restrictive ruling on these matters. If you

Speaker: NA
Text: are to rule today that, suddenly, because it

Speaker: NA
Text: appears that the circumstances have been

Speaker: NA
Text: directed towards this side of the House it is ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceptable, well, of course, you are the Speaker

Speaker: NA
Text: and your ruling I suppose will prevail; but it will

Speaker: NA
Text: have devastating consequences on the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidence, if not the respect, that you expect to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain from this side of the House, because ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: inconsistency.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I ruled on that question. I

Speaker: NA
Text: gave my reasons. The Leader of the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: then put to me an earlier ruling I gave. My recol-

Speaker: NA
Text: lection of my earlier ruling is that I did permit

Speaker: NA
Text: questions of the Prime Minister concerning every

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, but I did not permit questions of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in relation to Ministers on mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters for which the Ministers were not answerable

Speaker: NA
Text: to this House. I did permit questions to be asked

Speaker: NA
Text: of the right honourable gentleman as to his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: fidence in Ministers. I see no relationship whatso-

Speaker: NA
Text: ever between this question and the other series of

Speaker: NA
Text: questions. It is unfortunate that the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition should put his argument in a form

Speaker: NA
Text: that suggests that if I do not agree with him he

Speaker: NA
Text: will regard me as lacking impartiality. What

Speaker: NA
Text: must be borne in mind by every member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House is that my impartiality will not be judged

Speaker: NA
Text: on whether I please a member, any number of

Speaker: NA
Text: members or any party. I will make my judgments

Speaker: NA
Text: as I feel to be proper and announce them. If the

Speaker: NA
Text: in rehonourable gentleman disagrees with them he

Speaker: NA
Text: may challenge them within the forms of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: Al l members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House will be aware of the widespread con-

Speaker: NA
Text: demnation ofthe invasion of Afghanistan. There

Speaker: NA
Text: has been condemnation by 104 members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations. There has been a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: condemnation from the Islamic Conference.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many other countries around the world individu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ally have demonstrated their abhorrence by the

Speaker: NA
Text: actions that they have taken. This has now been

Speaker: NA
Text: underlined by the unfolding of an effective boy-

Speaker: NA
Text: cott of the Olympic Games. I think that Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians would be concerned to find that the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: cipal Press officer of Mr Wilkes, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party in Victoria, has written in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Star that one should rejoice that for once

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviets are not acting in an objectively

Speaker: NA
Text: counter-revolutionary role as the Chinese seem

Speaker: NA
Text: always to act in these days. He pointed out that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party should be supporting both the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Afghan Government and the Soviet assistance to

Speaker: NA
Text: that Government.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: Well , we are not.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: I am just saying

Speaker: NA
Text: what Mr Wilkes's principal Press officer is

Speaker: NA
Text: saying.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Text: H e is an idiot.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: I am glad of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman's confirmation that Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Wilkes is employing an idiot. The letter goes on

Speaker: NA
Text: to indicate the great reforms that have been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted in Afghanistan since 1978, obviously ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: plauds the invasion and indicates that we should

Speaker: NA
Text: all be rejoicing in relation to it. That is a quite

Speaker: NA
Text: extraordinary document in the Labor Star, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is not out of line with what Senator Georges said

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Senate on 6 March this year. He stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: With all its limitations, there is more dignity and

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Soviet Union than there is in our own society-

Speaker: NA
Text: On 8 March 1979 the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunter said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I do not apprehend any fear for Australia should

Speaker: NA
Text: Indonesia come under the influence of the Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is plainly a view within elements of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Labor Party and particularly in the

Speaker: NA
Text: notorious socialist Left in Victoria-

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: I t is worth noting

Speaker: NA
Text: that Mr Hartley and the socialist Left in particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar have supported the Leader ofthe Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: since the Leader of the Opposition repudiated

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hawke over economic and wages policies at

Speaker: NA
Text: the Adelaide conference last year. Mr Hawke

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that it was a gutless sell-out to the Left.

Speaker: NA
Text: Since then there have been moves that will result

Speaker: NA
Text: in the socialist Left gaining greater influence in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Party in Queensland where there are

Speaker: NA
Text: now, in effect, two branches of the Labor Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: With the lurch to the left, the willing captive of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Left-

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: The Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: might think that this is a matter of humour. It

Speaker: NA
Text: may be a matter of humour to it, but it is also a

Speaker: NA
Text: matter of very deep concern to the wider Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian community. The fact that these matters

Speaker: NA
Text: are so evident within the Labor Party quite obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously explains the antics of the Leader of the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position in recent days.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLIC E

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Text: M y question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Administrative Services. In view

Speaker: NA
Text: of the debate to be held later today on the Auswhere

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1980, I

Speaker: NA
Text: ask: How many officers carrying out law enforcethat

Speaker: NA
Text: ment functions were there in

Speaker: NA
Text: cotics Bureau before its dissolution because of

Speaker: NA
Text: criticism by the royal commissioner into drugs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Justice Williams? How many of these officers

Speaker: NA
Text: have applied to transfer to the Australian Fedrate

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Police? How many have been accepted by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commissioner for the Australian Federal currently

Speaker: NA
Text: Police? How many have been rejected because of

Speaker: NA
Text: alleged corruption, inefficiency and/or ance

Speaker: NA
Text: incompetence?

Speaker: Mr JOHN MCLEAY
Text: I thank the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: gentleman for the question and I welcome him to

Speaker: NA
Text: the new front bench position to which he has

Speaker: NA
Text: been promoted. Two or three weeks ago I

Speaker: NA
Text: answered a similar question put to me by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Leader of the Opposition. I forget the exact

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, but I think the number of special con-

Speaker: NA
Text: morality stables who transferred from the Narcotics Bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: reau is 84 and I think the other figure that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member is seeking is 20 or 30

Speaker: NA
Text: officers. I will research the matter and supply the

Speaker: NA
Text: facts to him later today during the debate on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: DEFENCE RESERVE PERSONNEL:

Speaker: NA
Text: COMPENSATION

Speaker: Mr SHORT
Text: I s the Minister representing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Social Security aware of the wide-

Speaker: NA
Text: spread public welcome to the Government's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent decision to increase the size of the Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: Force reserves from 22,000 to 30,000? Is it a fact

Speaker: NA
Text: that under existing legislation Federal Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment compensation to persons injured while

Speaker: NA
Text: serving in the reserves is limited to six months? Is

Speaker: NA
Text: it a fact that if a reservist wishes to be covered for

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation purposes beyond that period he is

Speaker: NA
Text: required to take out private insurance at his own

Speaker: NA
Text: cost? Does the Minister regard this situation as

Speaker: NA
Text: one discouraging young Australians from joining

Speaker: NA
Text: the reserves? If so, will he take urgent action to

Speaker: NA
Text: have this situation examined with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: extending the period for which compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: will be paid?

Speaker: Mr HUNT
Text: I am aware of the expansion of

Speaker: NA
Text: the reserve forces, but I am not aware of the cir-

Speaker: NA
Text: cumstances to which the honourable gentleman

Speaker: NA
Text: has referred. The position, as I know it, is that

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Defence Force Reserve have a

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation facility under the Compensation

Speaker: NA
Text: (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act

Speaker: NA
Text: while participating in Defence Force Reserve

Speaker: NA
Text: activities. As I understand it, if a member suffers

Speaker: NA
Text: an injury in the course of any military service,

Speaker: NA
Text: compensation is payable for an unlimited period

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of incapacity for civil employment,

Speaker: NA
Text: such incapacity is supported by appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate medical certificates. I am quite certain that

Speaker: NA
Text: is how the provisions of the Act apply to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal NarReserve servicemen.

Speaker: NA
Text: For the first 26 weeks of incapacity, compen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sation is payable at the reservist's normal civilian

Speaker: NA
Text: of pay. If a reservist is incapacitated beyond

Speaker: NA
Text: that period, weekly incapacity benefits are paid

Speaker: NA
Text: at $90 a week. He is also eligible for a

Speaker: NA
Text: spouse allowance of $23.60 a week and an allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: of $11.25 a week for each dependent child.

Speaker: NA
Text: Those rates of compensation are the same as are

Speaker: NA
Text: payable for all Commonwealth employees, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding regular members of the Defence Force

Speaker: NA
Text: who sustain a work-connected injury. However, I

Speaker: NA
Text: will convey the honourable member's concern to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister and I have no doubt that she will

Speaker: NA
Text: in touch with him direct about the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: COUNTRY TELEPHONE EXCHANGES

Speaker: Mr FITZPATRICK
Text: Is the Minister for Post

Speaker: NA
Text: and Telecommunications aware that many

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas still have very poor telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: vices due to obsolete equipment in telephone

Speaker: NA
Text: exchanges? Can the Minister give a guarantee

Speaker: NA
Text: that there will be no slowing down of the

Speaker: NA
Text: program of replacement of this obsolete equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment while waiting for a connection to be made

Speaker: NA
Text: to the so-called national satellite communication

Speaker: NA
Text: system?

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Without any doubt I can give

Speaker: NA
Text: such a guarantee. Some little while ago the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government agreed to Telecom Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: spending an extra $30m in the current year on

Speaker: NA
Text: the conversion to automatic operation of those

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of telephones to which the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member is referring. This accelerated program of counter-productive

Speaker: NA
Text: conversion to automatic of old manual teleadvantage

Speaker: NA
Text: phones will mean that by the

Speaker: NA
Text: nearly all Australians will have access

Speaker: NA
Text: ern, automatic telephone service. It is far from

Speaker: NA
Text: the case that satellite developments are holding

Speaker: NA
Text: up those moves. The Government is accelerating would

Speaker: NA
Text: them at the same time.

Speaker: NA
Text: WOOL SALES TO THE SOVIET UNION

Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Text: Is the Minister for Trade and

Speaker: NA
Text: Resources aware of an allegation that he recently

Speaker: NA
Text: sought from the Soviet Union guarantees or as-

Speaker: NA
Text: surances that that country would continue to buy

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian wool? Is this allegation correct?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: Ther e have been some alle-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations to this effect. In fact the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corio made a number of statements

Speaker: NA
Text: in the House last night and on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Broadcasting Commission radio program AM

Speaker: NA
Text: this morning which are factually incorrect.

Speaker: NA
Text: ject those statements completely, both in sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stance and in the spirit of the Government's pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy towards the Soviet Union. Firstly, the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member suggested that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: trade officials were called in by the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and informed that wool sales would

Speaker: NA
Text: be boycotted. As far as I am aware, Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: trade officials in Moscow have had discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Soviet trade ministry officials on only

Speaker: NA
Text: one occasion since the Soviet invasion of

Speaker: NA
Text: Afghanistan. It was an informal meeting. The re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port of that meeting indicates that no threat, or

Speaker: NA
Text: indeed suggestion, was made that Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: wool sales would be boycotted. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corio suggested also that I had

Speaker: NA
Text: called in for discussions Soviet trade officials in

Speaker: NA
Text: get Australia. Let me make it very clear that since

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: called in any Soviet trade officials. In fact, I have

Speaker: NA
Text: had no contact with any member of the Soviet

Speaker: NA
Text: Embassy.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member stated also that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: ser- fairly certain that the Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: sought undertakings or at least information from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Soviet Union as to its intention in relation to

Speaker: NA
Text: wool sales. On no occasion have I sought either

Speaker: NA
Text: undertakings or information regarding the

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Union's position on the purchase of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian wool. These allegations are totally un-

Speaker: NA
Text: founded and I reject them without qualification.

Speaker: NA
Text: On the basis of these incorrect assertions the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member accused me of hypocrisy. I

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to that accusation simply by quoting two

Speaker: NA
Text: very short comments made by the Leader ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition. On 19 February he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is absolutely no point in empty gestures, or in

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that damage Australia, or dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: our national interest, more than they do the

Speaker: NA
Text: middle of the 1980s Soviet Union.

Speaker: NA
Text: to a modOn the same date he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: I have said from the beginning that an effective boycott, or

Speaker: NA
Text: the transfer of the Olympic Games away from Moscow,

Speaker: NA
Text: have embarrassed the Soviet Union deeply, and could

Speaker: NA
Text: have been expected to drive home to many of her own

Speaker: NA
Text: people the point that the invasion of Afghanistan was re-

Speaker: NA
Text: pugnant to and rejected by most countries of the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: If there is any hypocrisy, I invite the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: made a judgment as to where that hypocrisy lies.

Speaker: NA
Text: ETHNIC PRESS

Speaker: Dr CASS
Text: Ha s the attention of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn

Speaker: NA
Text: to a question directed to his predecessor on 2

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1978, in reply to which the previous Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter promised to give consideration to the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: clusion of Opposition news releases in the pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lication For the Ethnic Media which is produced

Speaker: NA
Text: I re- by the Minister's Department? As no further

Speaker: NA
Text: word has been heard from the previous Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: does this mean that after 18 months' consider-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation he was unable to make a decision? Was a

Speaker: NA
Text: decision made to ignore the question and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's promise, or is the matter still under

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration? Why has departmental editorial

Speaker: NA
Text: comment appeared in the 8 April issue of From

Speaker: NA
Text: the Ethnic Press, a publication issued by the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment which purports to be a weekly selection

Speaker: NA
Text: of news and editorial opinion from Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign language Press? Does it mean that both

Speaker: NA
Text: publications, posing as a service to the ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: communities, have now degenerated into ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles for departmental propaganda?

Speaker: Mr MACPHEE
Text: In respect of the first part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's question, my attention

Speaker: NA
Text: has not previously been drawn to that matter. I

Speaker: NA
Text: will investigate it forthwith and speak to him

Speaker: NA
Text: later this afternoon. In respect ofthe second mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter, my attention has been drawn to the editorial

Speaker: NA
Text: note. I believe that the action ofthe Deputy Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: retary of the Department on this occasion was

Speaker: NA
Text: perfectly justified. I shall explain to the House

Speaker: NA
Text: the reasons for it. In fact, the journal From the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ethnic Press is not an avenue of propaganda in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the Department. It is a service. It pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vides summaries of what is published in all eth-

Speaker: NA
Text: nic Press. It is taken as being an accurate sum-

Speaker: NA
Text: mary. Sometimes the articles as summarised are

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves taken as being true and are therefore

Speaker: NA
Text: not questioned. On this occasion there was a ref-

Speaker: NA
Text: erence in La Fiamma which was in error in sev-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral respects. It happened that the same edition

Speaker: NA
Text: quoted the honourable member for Maribyr-

Speaker: NA
Text: nong. The decision facing the editor of From the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ethnic Press was: Should he omit the reference

Speaker: NA
Text: because it was in error and would be reproduced

Speaker: NA
Text: in other journals without question, or should he

Speaker: NA
Text: include it and quote the honourable member's

Speaker: NA
Text: contribution but include an editorial note mak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing it clear that the report was in error in

Speaker: NA
Text: spects? He chose to do the latter. It did not affect

Speaker: NA
Text: the contribution ofthe honourable member. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that the editorial note was

Speaker: NA
Text: accuracy and was therefore in every way

Speaker: NA
Text: justified.

Text: TASMANIAN INDUSTRIES

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I call the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Franklin.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: Thank you, Mr Speaker. ing

Speaker: NA
Text: Sorry, fellows. I direct a question to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. It concerns all Tasmanians.

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition members interjecting-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable Tasmanians

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Franklin will resume his seat. I indithis

Speaker: NA
Text: cate to the honourable gentleman that if he percruing

Speaker: NA
Text: sists in making comments as a preface to his

Speaker: NA
Text: question I will rule him out of order.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: Thank you, Mr Speaker. people

Speaker: NA
Text: What Government initiated the

Speaker: NA
Text: CaUaghan inquiry into industries in Tasmania?

Speaker: NA
Text: What benefits are nowflowingto Tasmania as a

Speaker: NA
Text: result of the report of that inquiry? Have the

Speaker: NA
Text: claims of the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Lowe,

Speaker: NA
Text: during the previous State election now been

Speaker: NA
Text: proved to be completely without foundation? In

Speaker: NA
Text: fact, were they a con on the Tasmanian people?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: The answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the last part of the honourable gentleman's ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion is a plain and short yes. I think all honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able gentlemen will know that the initiatives of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government, as a result of the CaUaghan re-

Speaker: NA
Text: port and as a result of other measures, have very

Speaker: NA
Text: materially assisted Tasmania and industries in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania. As further evidence of this assistance,

Speaker: NA
Text: on 15 April of this year I announced the decision

Speaker: NA
Text: to establish a national marine science centre in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tasmania, costing about $25m over a period, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cluding $9m for a research vessel.

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Di d that come out of the

Speaker: NA
Text: CaUaghan report?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: Yes, it is very

Speaker: NA
Text: much as a result of matters that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has pursued following the CaUaghan report

Speaker: NA
Text: which, of course, this Government initiated. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will mean the moving of the relevant division of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: search Organisation from Cronulla in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales to Tasmania. It will lead to an enhanced

Speaker: NA
Text: national effort and very greatly assist in the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plementation of the Government's broad poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cies in relation to Tasmania. It needs to be noted

Speaker: NA
Text: that it follows the movement of the Antarctic

Speaker: NA
Text: Division of the Department of Science and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment and also the establishment of the

Speaker: NA
Text: some reAustralian Maritime College at Launceston.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are but some of the initiatives that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has pursued in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: in the interests of CaUaghan report.

Speaker: NA
Text: I understand that Mr Lowe, speaking a short

Speaker: NA
Text: while ago on television in Tasmania, tried to take

Speaker: NA
Text: all of the credit for these particular matters him-

Speaker: NA
Text: self, ignoring completely the efforts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable gentleman who asked this question,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Franklin, and ignor-

Speaker: NA
Text: in particular the efforts of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime member for Denison who has worked long and

Speaker: NA
Text: assiduously not only in relation to the Antarctic

Speaker: NA
Text: centre but also in relation to the movement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: division of the CSIRO. I am quite certain that all

Speaker: NA
Text: recognise the effect ofthe policies of

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the advantages that are ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: to all of the people of Tasmania as a result

Speaker: NA
Text: of the policies of this Government. Mr Lowe

Speaker: NA
Text: would have to be much better than he is to make

Speaker: NA
Text: believe that he is responsible for these

Speaker: NA
Text: now famous particular matters.

Speaker: NA
Text: INVESTMENT ALLOWANCE

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: I refer the Acting Treasurer to

Speaker: NA
Text: a statement that was made by the Minister for In-

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry and Commerce when he was Treasurer, in

Speaker: NA
Text: January 1976, announcing details of the invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment allowance, in which it was claimed that the

Speaker: NA
Text: allowance would be a strong encouragement for

Speaker: NA
Text: business to expand so as to become more efficient

Speaker: NA
Text: and more productive. Is it a fact that more than

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 1,100m of tax revenue has been forgone

Speaker: NA
Text: through the operation of the investment allow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance in the last four years? Did the annual rate of

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity increase in the economy from 1976

Speaker: NA
Text: to 1979 average only 1.7 per cent, half the aver-

Speaker: NA
Text: age achieved during the Labor period of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment? Why has the investment allowance failed

Speaker: NA
Text: so dismally to stimulate productivity?

Speaker: Mr ERIC ROBINSON
Text: I do recall a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment made by the Minister for Industry and

Speaker: NA
Text: Commerce when he was Treasurer regarding the

Speaker: NA
Text: investment allowance. The view that he ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pressed, that the investment allowance made a

Speaker: NA
Text: very valuable contribution to Australia, is one

Speaker: NA
Text: that is shared by all members of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Indeed, it was a decision made in order

Speaker: NA
Text: that we could get some development and growth

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the industrial section of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian community. Considerable benefits have

Speaker: NA
Text: flowed from it in terms of reducing costs, increas-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing exports and increasing our capacity to com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pete. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that,

Speaker: NA
Text: when this Government was returned to office, the

Speaker: NA
Text: nation's ability to compete had been vastly

Speaker: NA
Text: eroded due to the fiscal policies which the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious Administration had pursued.

Speaker: NA
Text: On return, this Government took steps in a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of ways-reducin g Government expen-

Speaker: NA
Text: diture, controlling the money supply and

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing the investment allowance-t o get

Speaker: NA
Text: this nation competitive again. That, of course, is

Speaker: NA
Text: what has occurred. There have been some

Speaker: NA
Text: tremendous benefits. Had there been greater re-

Speaker: NA
Text: straint in a number of other areas, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: the wages area, and a greater degree of responsi-

Speaker: NA
Text: bility from the Labor Opposition with regard to

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial relations and had the Labor Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition discharged a national responsibility in

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the members of its trade unions to act more in

Speaker: NA
Text: the national interest, we would have had greater

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity in this country. The investment al-

Speaker: NA
Text: lowance has played a very valuable role in

Speaker: NA
Text: increasing productivity and great credit is upon

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government for its implementation.
