Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATION

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: Shortland )- Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: claim to have been misrepresented.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable gentle-

Speaker: NA
Text: man wish to make a personal explanation?

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: Yes .

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: He may proceed.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: In the Australian of 18 April

Speaker: NA
Text: 1980 under the byline of Gary O'Neill a state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment appears referring to a speech which I made

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) last Thursday.

Speaker: NA
Text: It reads:

Speaker: NA
Text: He-

Speaker: NA
Text: Meaning myself-

Speaker: NA
Text: said last year the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Liberal council meeting in Perth the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: sidering selling TAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report goes on:

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Robinson later denied having made the statement.

Speaker: NA
Text: The report is completely untrue. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: Finance ( Mr Eric Robinson) has refused to move

Speaker: NA
Text: away from his statement that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: considering the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines.

Speaker: NA
Text: The article inaccurately reports what I said,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is shown on page 1918 of Hansard. I said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister then told the Federal Liberal Party Council

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting in Perth that the Government was considering the

Speaker: NA
Text: sale of TAA.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Treasurer ( Mr Howard) when challenged at the time

Speaker: NA
Text: in Newcastle to refute what the Minister for Finance had

Speaker: NA
Text: said, refused to answer. He still stands in that position.

Speaker: NA
Text: have the two senior finance Ministers of the Government re-

Speaker: NA
Text: fusing to deny that the sale of TAA is being considered.

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA'S RELATIONS WITH IRAN

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Affairs)-b y leave-M y colleague

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Trade and Resources ( Mr Anthony)

Speaker: NA
Text: and I are jointly responsible for giving effect

Speaker: NA
Text: the decisions that I am about to announce relatwill

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to the detention of the American hostages in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tehran and the decisions we have taken on

Speaker: NA
Text: lations with Iran. The Government has made a

Speaker: NA
Text: further review of trade in non-food items with

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran and has considered a range of options open

Speaker: NA
Text: to it. It has been decided to prohibit further

Speaker: NA
Text: exports of Disappearing Automatic Retaliatory

Speaker: NA
Text: Target-DART-equipmen t to Iran until the taining

Speaker: NA
Text: hostages are released. The DART equipment is

Speaker: NA
Text: the only item of military or quasi-military equipportance,

Speaker: NA
Text: ment now being exported to Iran from Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have also decided to cease remaining

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance to trade in non-food items with Iran.

Speaker: NA
Text: The assistance which is now to cease will include

Speaker: NA
Text: export insurance cover on new business and

Speaker: NA
Text: export incentive arrangements in respect of non-

Speaker: NA
Text: food trade with Iran.

Speaker: NA
Text: I take this opportunity to draw the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian exporters to the increasingly un-

Speaker: NA
Text: favourable climate for trade with Iran. Our judg-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is that the climate will continue to deterio-

Speaker: NA
Text: rate unless and until the hostages are released.

Speaker: NA
Text: Their continued detention is not only an affront

Speaker: NA
Text: to a fundamental principle of relations between

Speaker: NA
Text: states, it is also a cruel and increasingly danger-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous affront to the American people in human

Speaker: NA
Text: terms.

Speaker: NA
Text: Innocent American citizens have been

Speaker: NA
Text: detained for nearly half a year. Whatever their

Speaker: NA
Text: physical condition, there can be no doubt regard-

Speaker: NA
Text: Tor Finance, Mr Robinson, told a

Speaker: NA
Text: was coning the mental strains and anguish they are

Speaker: NA
Text: suffering. Neither can there be any doubt about

Speaker: NA
Text: the strength of feeling among their fellow coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: trymen concerning their condition and safety. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the circumstances the United States has shown

Speaker: NA
Text: for remarkable forebearance. It has walked the path

Speaker: NA
Text: of negotiation with patience, in the face of

Speaker: NA
Text: is considerable provocation and repeated dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: appointment. To assume that its forebearance is

Speaker: NA
Text: unlimited or to equate it with indifferent or weak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ness would be a grave mistake. A great democ-

Speaker: NA
Text: racy cannot be expected to wait indefinitely

Speaker: NA
Text: while revolutionary factions resolve their

Speaker: NA
Text: differences-wit h the lives of its citizens being

Speaker: NA
Text: used as pawns.

Speaker: NA
Text: In taking these further decisions that I have

Speaker: NA
Text: So we announced, the Government's objective is to

Speaker: NA
Text: register with the Iranian authorities, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: clearest possible terms, its repugnance at Iran's

Speaker: NA
Text: behaviour in using hostages as a political device

Speaker: NA
Text: and its concern about the danger to peace which

Speaker: NA
Text: flows from that behaviour. Attempting to humili-

Speaker: NA
Text: test the limits of the patience of a great

Speaker: NA
Text: the power is an extremely dangerous game. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's firm view is that only concerted

Speaker: NA
Text: to action by the United States' friends and allies

Speaker: NA
Text: bring home to the Iranian authorities that

Speaker: NA
Text: their handling of the hostages issue is totally un-

Speaker: NA
Text: reacceptable to the international community.

Speaker: NA
Text: The United States is moving in a deliberate

Speaker: NA
Text: and considered way to make clear to Iran the

Speaker: NA
Text: costs of persisting in detaining the hostages. The

Speaker: NA
Text: justice of its case; the common interest in main-

Speaker: NA
Text: the principle of diplomatic immunity; the

Speaker: NA
Text: responsibility of alliance; and, of overriding im-

Speaker: NA
Text: the need to remove a danger to world

Speaker: NA
Text: peace-al l these considerations justify firm sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: official port from America's allies.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government's concern has been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: inforced by the consultations last week of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) with

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth and other leaders in Salisbury

Speaker: NA
Text: during the Zimbabwe independence cel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ebrations. So long as there is no movement in the

Speaker: NA
Text: situation, other measures open to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will be kept under close and constant re-

Speaker: NA
Text: view. But the hope of the Government is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there will be movement, and that this irrational

Speaker: NA
Text: and callous behaviour will cease forthwith.

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Text: Oxley-Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition)-b y leave-Th e statement of the

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: described as a low level response to an extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: difficult and potentially extremely dangerous

Speaker: NA
Text: situation-on e that could imply great difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: for the rest of the world. In fact, I think that one

Speaker: NA
Text: could fairly go beyond stating that it was a low

Speaker: NA
Text: level response and say that it was a rather limp

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction from a government that displayed so

Speaker: NA
Text: much fury so recently on another international

Speaker: NA
Text: situation not far removed geographically from

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran. What it boils down to is a fairly clear dem-

Speaker: NA
Text: onstration that once again, when it comes to

Speaker: NA
Text: competitive interests, on the one hand, on the

Speaker: NA
Text: part of farm exports and, on the other hand, in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational relations, the Nauonal Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: wins hands down in every such situation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us look at the potential that Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: to apply influence on Iran. Australia has develsee

Speaker: NA
Text: oped a substantial trade with Iran, and a trade

Speaker: NA
Text: with a considerable growth rate. Our exports for

Speaker: NA
Text: the first six months of the currentfinancialyear

Speaker: NA
Text: amounted to $120m compared with $116m for bassy

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of 1978-79. So the rate of growth

Speaker: NA
Text: exports this year is twice that which applied

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978-79. More significantly, of that total amount

Speaker: NA
Text: of exports-tha t is, of the $ 120m-onl y about

Speaker: NA
Text: $9m was not accounted for by farm products.

Speaker: NA
Text: Meat and live sheep accounted for $50m and

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat for $44m. They were the dominant items.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is significant because the inspired leaks

Speaker: NA
Text: from unidentified but official sources which contributes

Speaker: NA
Text: appeared prominently in the newspapers this

Speaker: NA
Text: morning left the community with the impression

Speaker: NA
Text: that this was a massive retribution by Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: against Iran in support of our

Speaker: NA
Text: the sort. More than that, once again, the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Country Party has extracted as the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of its partnership in the coalition complete

Speaker: NA
Text: immunity for the products in which their conunease

Speaker: NA
Text: stituency is directly involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: But let me go on. I want to make it clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: we sympathise with the United States and its

Speaker: NA
Text: leaders in this dilemma. For six months, 50 cititrated.

Speaker: NA
Text: zens of the United States who are entitled to

Speaker: NA
Text: full protection of international law and practice

Speaker: NA
Text: covering diplomatic representation have been tary

Speaker: NA
Text: prisoners. For six months, the immunity of the

Speaker: NA
Text: official United States Embassy and its contents

Speaker: NA
Text: has been persistently and scornfully breached.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most shameful feature of the situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tehran is the studied refusal of any recognised

Speaker: NA
Text: authority to take responsibility for what has been

Speaker: NA
Text: going on. That is what President Carter is seek-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing to do now-t o create a situation whereby re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility has to be shouldered at official level

Speaker: NA
Text: so that at least there is a defined party for

Speaker: NA
Text: negotiation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The great fear must be that there is no level of

Speaker: NA
Text: authority both willing and able to accept the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibility. There is strong ground now for the

Speaker: NA
Text: belief that nobody in Iran is able to exercise

Speaker: NA
Text: effective control. We see in that country a presi-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent elected by an impressive majority with the

Speaker: NA
Text: support of the religious parties, taking moderate

Speaker: NA
Text: positions and saying the right sorts of things-

Speaker: NA
Text: indisputably an intelligent and able man, but un-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to take effective action. We see as the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ligious head of state a tired and sick old man

Speaker: NA
Text: whose grasp of the day-to-day realities of inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national developments appears suspect and who

Speaker: NA
Text: is more inclined to react than to lead. We see a

Speaker: NA
Text: revolutionary council of a dozen or so other

Speaker: NA
Text: figures, mostly little known and understood less,

Speaker: NA
Text: who are given to making ringing declarations

Speaker: NA
Text: has from a basis of dubious authority. Soon we will

Speaker: NA
Text: an elected parliament whose outlook and real -

Speaker: NA
Text: authority are problematical at this stage.

Speaker: NA
Text: The students occupying the American Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: and holding the hostages see themselves as

Speaker: NA
Text: in both a political and a religious force. We now

Speaker: NA
Text: in have contending student groups rampaging

Speaker: NA
Text: through the universities-on e faction at least be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieving it does so with the blessing, or at the be-

Speaker: NA
Text: hest, of its religious leaders. A huge refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: problem continues to grow on the border with

Speaker: NA
Text: Iraq where military exchanges of varying sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance have also been taking place. All of this

Speaker: NA
Text: to a picture of instability and ineffec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive control and leadership on a frightening

Speaker: NA
Text: scale. Forces are at work which could rip Iran

Speaker: NA
Text: apart with a level of bloodshed we hesitate to

Speaker: NA
Text: ally. It is nothing of contemplate.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the same time, our sympathy for the

Speaker: NA
Text: American position is tinged with considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: on several scores. The overriding one

Speaker: NA
Text: arises from the feeling that the situation has de-

Speaker: NA
Text: veloped an inexorable momentum of its own and

Speaker: NA
Text: that the direction is towards a form of military

Speaker: NA
Text: action. The American people are angry and frus-

Speaker: NA
Text: They are demanding action. According to

Speaker: NA
Text: the a Washington Post poll published yesterday as

Speaker: NA
Text: many as two-thirds of Americans support a mili-

Speaker: NA
Text: course of action-unspecifie d though it is. In

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States at present the most sensitive

Speaker: NA
Text: decision-making with the most profound impli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations for the whole world is proceeding in the

Speaker: NA
Text: worst possible environment. The process is

Speaker: NA
Text: taking place in the full heat of the primary polls

Speaker: NA
Text: leading up to the American presidential election

Speaker: NA
Text: at the end of this year. The one certainty in

Speaker: NA
Text: daunting in the extreme. It is that no President of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States can seek re-election in just a

Speaker: NA
Text: few months time while 50 American diplomatic

Speaker: NA
Text: personnel remain hostage in Tehran. But the

Speaker: NA
Text: time fuse is even shorter than that. No American

Speaker: NA
Text: President can continue through the shoals and

Speaker: NA
Text: shallows of the primaries campaign for much

Speaker: NA
Text: longer without taking some decisive action in this

Speaker: NA
Text: situation. The dilemma is that the diplomatic in-

Speaker: NA
Text: itiatives are virtually exhausted already and that

Speaker: NA
Text: we are very close to the point where only military

Speaker: NA
Text: options are left.

Speaker: NA
Text: The potential consequences of military action

Speaker: NA
Text: are such that I believe we should avoid public

Speaker: NA
Text: speculation upon them at this stage. However,

Speaker: NA
Text: we cannot overlook the fact that the Soviet lations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Union shares an uneasy border with Iran and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintains significant military forces in the area.

Speaker: NA
Text: In my assessment, Iran's oil does not even enter

Speaker: NA
Text: the immediate calculation of possible Russian

Speaker: NA
Text: action. But border instability, with its effect

Speaker: NA
Text: Soviet Muslims in the region, could do so. Iran

Speaker: NA
Text: poised to become aflashpointcomparable with

Speaker: NA
Text: that provided by the Balkans in earlier times.

Speaker: NA
Text: Iran the spheres of interest of the two super-

Speaker: NA
Text: powers are dangerously close to overlapping.

Speaker: NA
Text: Almost 30 years ago a major misjudgment by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Central Intelligence Agency led to the

Speaker: NA
Text: throw of the elected Mossadegh government in

Speaker: NA
Text: Tehran and the installation of the Shah, with

Text: tarianism that are now so well documented. That

Speaker: NA
Text: United States in that country today. We cannot

Text: regime brought a significant measure of econstrate

Speaker: NA
Text: omic development to Iran. Of that there is no

Text: doubt, but it did so with vast inequities between

Text: the people, with the unconscionable use of torbound

Speaker: NA
Text: ture and uncontrolled secret police activities,

Text: through Savak, against a background of corruplesson

Text: tion, coercion and gross violation of human

Speaker: NA
Text: rights.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is difficult to call that sort of development

Speaker: NA
Text: progress. It should emphasise to us at once and

Speaker: NA
Text: do so once again the need to look at the world

Speaker: NA
Text: alistically and to defend basic principles Union

Speaker: NA
Text: consistently-tw o measures that we have been

Text: Timor. We should recognise that one of the legit-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: on circumstances in which a series of events could

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: gerate Soviet successes. The Russians do not

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: they do. In recent years they have been thrown

Speaker: NA
Text: out of countries such as Egypt and Somalia. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have not maintained their influence in places

Text: such as Angola. The communist monolith, com-

Speaker: NA
Text: prising Russia and China, crumbled while Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: tern observers were still forecasting its dire

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences.

Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATION

Text: Corio)- Mr Speaker,

Speaker: NA
Text: your indulgence to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Mr SCHOLES
Text: Mr Speaker, in answer to a

Speaker: NA
Text: question during Question Time the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Trade and Resources ( Mr Anthony) said, among

Speaker: NA
Text: other things, that 1 had used inaccurate infor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mation when I indicated that a threat had been

Speaker: NA
Text: made or was reported to the Government some

Speaker: NA
Text: time ago on a possible Russian boycott of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Financial Review of 5 February

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: that has been proposed.

Text: made. His statement was quite incorrect, as were

Speaker: NA
Text: WORKS

Speaker: NA
Text: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I have received letters from

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable members for Cunningham ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: West), Diamond Valley ( Mr N. A. Brown) and

Speaker: NA
Text: Denison ( Mr Hodgman) proposing that definite

Speaker: NA
Text: Cox Peninmatters of public importance be submitted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: House for discussion today. As required by

Speaker: NA
Text: Standing Order 107, I have selected the matter

Speaker: NA
Text: which in my opinion is the most urgent and im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant, that is that proposed by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: I seek member for Cunningham, namely:

Speaker: NA
Text: The urgent need for the use of Commonwealth powers to

Speaker: NA
Text: deteriorating relations between the Kimberley

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines and mining companies and the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: I call upon those members who approve of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed discussion to rise in their places.

Speaker: NA
Text: More than the number of members required by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: Cunningham) (3.50)-In Western

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUa over the last few months there has been

Speaker: NA
Text: a deterioration in relations between the 8,000

Speaker: NA
Text: AusKimberley Aborigines, the Western AustraUan

Speaker: NA
Text: in State Government, Amax Petroleum Co. and

Speaker: NA
Text: other mining companies. There is a fundamental

Speaker: NA
Text: conflict between a 30,000-year old culture-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: culture of Aborigines-an d those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: and interested in seeing the progress of the second

Speaker: NA
Text: measures great post-war mining development that is oc-

Speaker: NA
Text: curring in Western Australia. Similar develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will possibly occur in the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory and Queensland in coal projects, aluminium

Speaker: NA
Text: Moscow projects and so on. There are those in conserva-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive State governments, mining companies, the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Government and certainly the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of National Development and Energy who

Speaker: NA
Text: determined to call a halt to the gains made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia's original inhabitants, the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines, in the area of land rights and to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: verse the gains that have been made by these

Speaker: NA
Text: people in the last few years. Perhaps the prime

Speaker: NA
Text: example of this is at a far away pastoral lease in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western AustraUa called Noonkanbah. This

Speaker: NA
Text: station covers 4,700 square kilometres and was

Speaker: NA
Text: by the Aboriginal Land Fund Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: for the traditional local Aborigines in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975. It is now home to 200 or 300 Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people who recently were fringe dwellers in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fitzroy Crossing area.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Fremantle ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Dawkins) and I have twice visited this area in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last three weeks -on 2 April and 19 April. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: the House to note that despite the intransigence

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Court Government in Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: and the professed interest of the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Chaney) in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate, neither of those people have visited the

Speaker: NA
Text: area even once during this time of confrontation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Noonkanbah includes a large area of Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: sacred sites within a wide radius of the Pea Hill

Speaker: NA
Text: area. Sacred sites in Western Australia are sup-

Speaker: NA
Text: posed to be protected under the Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act which was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced by a State Labor government in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1972. Under the provisions of the Act the

Speaker: NA
Text: trustees of the Western Australian Museum have

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to investigate and declare Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: sacred sites. The Minister for Cultural Affairs has

Speaker: NA
Text: the power to override the Museum definitions.

Speaker: NA
Text: In June 1979, after an extensive survey, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Museum compiled a report

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Pea Hill sacred site leases which favoured

Speaker: NA
Text: the Aborigines. Amax Petroleum holds explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration leases over much of the Pea Hill area. In

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1978 the approximate location for a

Speaker: NA
Text: drilling site was shown to the Museum by Amax

Speaker: NA
Text: Petroleum. Subsequently the Museum's defini-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the sacred sites was rejected by the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Cultural Affairs, who gave no reason

Speaker: NA
Text: whatsoever. The Minister accepted that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: time that Amax Petroleum drilled in that area.

Speaker: NA
Text: This decision was in accord with the decisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian Government not to grant

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral leases at all to Aborigines. Indeed none

Speaker: NA
Text: have been transferred since 1977. Attempts by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Land Fund Commission to acquire further

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral leases in Western Australia have met

Speaker: NA
Text: with a negative response from the Court

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Gordon Downs station was

Speaker: NA
Text: applied for. This station, which is in the east

Speaker: NA
Text: Kimberleys, is presently owned by Vesteys. The

Speaker: NA
Text: decision to transfer this lease was opposed by Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Wordsworth, the Western Australian Lands

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister. He gave no reason except that he

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to try to incorporate vacant Crown land

Speaker: NA
Text: in the area into a viable station. The real reason,

Speaker: NA
Text: of course, was simply that he did not want to see

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines acquire any further pastoral leases.

Speaker: NA
Text: The same situation arose when the Land Fund

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission attempted to acquire Laurel Downs

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral lease for Aboriginal use. The Comwere

Speaker: NA
Text: mission tendered $5,000 more than any other sites.

Speaker: NA
Text: tenderer but it was knocked back and the State

Speaker: NA
Text: pastoral lease eventually went to United States

Speaker: NA
Text: interests. The Chairman of the Kimberley Lands

Speaker: NA
Text: Council, Mr Jimmy Bieundurry had this to say

Speaker: NA
Text: about no transfers of pastoral leases to Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nes being allowed by the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Court Government since 1977:

Speaker: NA
Text: It seems grossly inequitable that this small area of'Free'

Speaker: NA
Text: land should be denied to a group in excess of 100 people

Speaker: NA
Text: with a traditional association and a recognised land need, in

Speaker: NA
Text: favour of the marginal economic benefits it may have to a

Speaker: NA
Text: foreign company with millions of acres in WA and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: I return to Noonkanbah. Prior to the Amax drill-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings the Western Australian Government

Speaker: NA
Text: received pleas from numerous sources, including

Speaker: NA
Text: the Western Australian Museum and the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Aboriginal Council, not to allow drill-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing on sacred sights at Noonkanbah. This was

Speaker: NA
Text: the way the report of the Aboriginal Sites De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment of the Western Australian Museum put

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter:

Speaker: NA
Text: Above all else a man . . . and his children were be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieved to have actually originated from the area of the local

Speaker: NA
Text: descent group. That is to say their spirit emanated from a

Speaker: NA
Text: particular site within the countiy and returned there after

Speaker: NA
Text: death. A man or woman is therefore believed to be a living

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the country, and to share a common spirituality with

Speaker: NA
Text: the land. If the land is damaged or in any way broken up

Speaker: NA
Text: then the spiritual component of a living person is also

Speaker: NA
Text: deemed to be at risk. Additionally the land is full of spiritual

Speaker: NA
Text: essence-

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Aboriginal Council passed these

Speaker: NA
Text: resolutions:

Speaker: NA
Text: That this full National Conference of the NAC urgently

Speaker: NA
Text: request the Minister's immediate intervention to halt pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceedings taken by West Australian State Government in

Speaker: NA
Text: allowing Amax Mining Company to conduct exploration on

Speaker: NA
Text: Noonkanbah.

Speaker: NA
Text: The National Aboriginal Conference request the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: to urge the Federal Government to use the powers vested in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in the 1967 Referendum, draw up legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation and in doing so:

Speaker: NA
Text: Guarantee full protection of Aboriginal sacred sites and

Speaker: NA
Text: insuring that NO exploration or mining take place within

Speaker: NA
Text: an area recognised as such.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Professor of Anthropology at the University

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western Australia had this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: It would be a tragedy if unresolved, clumsily handled

Speaker: NA
Text: issues of this sort were to leave an indelible mark on the

Speaker: NA
Text: reputation and development of this State.

Speaker: NA
Text: That approach can lead only to further dissatisfaction and

Speaker: NA
Text: disilusionment, and to contempt and dismay on the part of

Speaker: NA
Text: all of us who are concerned with human welfare and justice.

Speaker: NA
Text: Instead of taking heed of those calls, what did we

Speaker: NA
Text: see the Court Government do? On 18 March

Speaker: NA
Text: under the umbrella of 35 police Amax moved in

Speaker: NA
Text: to drill, accompanied by officials of the West

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Mines Department. The Aborigines

Speaker: NA
Text: given five minutes to decide on one of two

Speaker: NA
Text: An injunction was granted to prevent drill-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing for one week but water drilling subsequently

Speaker: NA
Text: commenced on the weekend of 28 and 29 March.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have here the words of the West Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: which appeared in the West Australian. He was

Speaker: NA
Text: present on that occasion. I ask the House to think

Speaker: NA
Text: about these words as they are very well put. The

Speaker: NA
Text: article states:

Speaker: NA
Text: As the drills dug into the ground which the Noonkanbah

Speaker: NA
Text: people hold as sacred, I felt

Speaker: NA
Text: of these people left the degradation of alcohol excesses

Speaker: NA
Text: social upheaval to return to the land at Noonkanbah.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Saturday-

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the Court Government-

Speaker: NA
Text: they lost a little bit more of themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was there with the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Fremantle ( Mr Dawkins) on April 2, which was

Speaker: NA
Text: a watershed day in Aboriginal land rights histhe

Speaker: NA
Text: tory. Passive confrontation was successful when

Speaker: NA
Text: 130 Aborigines, in the presence of eight or nine

Speaker: NA
Text: police officers, requested Amax to leave without

Speaker: NA
Text: any violence. To everyone's great surprise Amax

Speaker: NA
Text: left. Why? I say to the House that it was simply

Speaker: NA
Text: because Amax realised that the alternative was

Speaker: NA
Text: to hold a police presence there for the whole duron

Speaker: NA
Text: ation of the drilling and that that was not possfor

Speaker: NA
Text: ible. It was a moral victory for the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people on that day which posed a huge dilemma

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Court Government in Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me trace some of the Premier's

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to this withdrawal by Amax was one of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plete fury. The next day in all of the media we

Speaker: NA
Text: were informed that Court said-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cotter- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. I ask that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: withdraw the reference to the Premier of Wesglad

Speaker: NA
Text: tern Australia as having told lies.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr Millar)- Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst the honourable member's remark was Minister's

Speaker: NA
Text: not directed to any member of this House, it

Speaker: NA
Text: constitute unparliamentary language. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr WEST
Text: I n deference to you, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, I will withdraw. The Western Austern

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Premier offered misrepresentations to

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. He said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: agreed to drilling. That was incorrect. He said

Speaker: NA
Text: they had threatened violence to Amax personnel.

Speaker: NA
Text: Police who were present would deny that. He

Speaker: NA
Text: says that the whole situation is due to white stirwilling

Speaker: NA
Text: rers. In fact, it is the tribal elders, many of

Speaker: NA
Text: lived through horrors such as the Forrest River

Speaker: NA
Text: massacre in 1926, who are leading the Aborigiassert

Speaker: NA
Text: nal movement at Noonkanbah. In case the forces

Speaker: NA
Text: House doubts what I am saying, let me trace

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the recent utterances of this bellicose,

Speaker: NA
Text: belligerent, intransigent, insensitive and inept

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Premier on this issue. Before

Speaker: NA
Text: an article the drilling he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: We believe that enough time has been spent on the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has been the subject of discussion for a long time.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the withdrawal he went on to say that drill-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing would proceed-whethe r by Amax or some-

Speaker: NA
Text: one else. Later on the following weekend Sir

Speaker: NA
Text: ashamed of my white skin. Many

Speaker: NA
Text: and Charles Court said that in preparation for the

Speaker: NA
Text: company's return to the site the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: would co-operate in organising logistical and

Speaker: NA
Text: other support. What does he mean by 'logistical

Speaker: NA
Text: support?' He obviously means one thing- a

Speaker: NA
Text: massive police presence to protect the Amax

Speaker: NA
Text: drilling operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: All this has simply resulted in the hardening of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal position to meet an intransigent

Speaker: NA
Text: State Government position. I was there again last

Speaker: NA
Text: Saturday at a bush meeting on the banks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Fitzroy River where Aboriginal law men had

Speaker: NA
Text: gathered from 30 Kimberley communities. They

Speaker: NA
Text: carried resolutions calling for no mining on

Speaker: NA
Text: sacred sites and no mining at all on Noonkanbah

Speaker: NA
Text: the complete lease for three years. They called

Speaker: NA
Text: the Federal Minister's intervening, using his

Speaker: NA
Text: powers under section 51 of the Constitution, and

Speaker: NA
Text: they resolved that all communities in the Kim-

Speaker: NA
Text: berleys would support the Noonkanbah

Speaker: NA
Text: lies. His reacAborigines.

Speaker: NA
Text: What has the Federal Minister been doing

Speaker: NA
Text: while all this has been going on? That is the $64

Speaker: NA
Text: question that I ask this House. I refer to a Press

Speaker: NA
Text: statement which states that before the confron-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation on 2 April the Minister said that he was

Speaker: NA
Text: to see the rumour that the company would

Speaker: NA
Text: enter the property without notice and with police

Speaker: NA
Text: protection had been laid to rest by the Premier of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. How naive can one get? The

Speaker: NA
Text: prime action afterwards was to write a

Speaker: NA
Text: does long letter to the West Australian which he

Speaker: NA
Text: him ended by virtually begging for an absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: confrontation. The tragedy of this Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: handling of Aboriginal affairs is simply that its

Speaker: NA
Text: two Ministers responsible have come from Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and they appear unable to handle

Speaker: NA
Text: the the reactionary Court Government and the Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines tern Australian Liberal Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Chaney has been seen in Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as a weak, ineffectual Minister not

Speaker: NA
Text: to confront the Liberals in his home State.

Speaker: NA
Text: whom He was very lucky to receive a reprieve on 2

Speaker: NA
Text: April, but he is now frittering away the chance to

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal power. Will he delay until Court

Speaker: NA
Text: Amax back in to a further confrontation

Speaker: NA
Text: with Aborigines at Noonkanbah? If he waits

Speaker: NA
Text: until Premier Court achieves that, it is virtually

Speaker: NA
Text: certain that a large police presence will be

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary, and then he will be forced to use Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral powers eventually whether he likes it or not.

Speaker: NA
Text: On Friday, 4 April, I talked personally with

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Chaney in Western Australia. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Fremantle and I

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed: Firstly, that a new investigation and

Speaker: NA
Text: mapping of sacred sites be undertaken on the

Speaker: NA
Text: leases; secondly, that Amax suspend its oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ations while this takes place; thirdly, that the

Speaker: NA
Text: original community be asked to nominate a rep-

Speaker: NA
Text: resentative to the mapping team; fourthly, that a

Speaker: NA
Text: new mapping team be led by an independent

Speaker: NA
Text: authority such as Professor Rowley or perhaps, if

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptable to him, by Dr H. Coombs and; fifthly,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government and Amax commit them-

Speaker: NA
Text: selves to accepting thefindingsof the study and

Speaker: NA
Text: avoiding drilling and other mining activities in

Speaker: NA
Text: the areas so designated. What has happened?

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Minister has not acted! On the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trary, the latest attitude of the Court Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is epitomised in a statement made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Western Australian Minister for Cultural Affairs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill Grayden, who has responsibility fpr Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal affairs. All he has done is to accuse the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal and union groups of using

Speaker: NA
Text: confrontation-style tactics to assert territorial

Speaker: NA
Text: claims. He told the Western Australian Cabinet

Speaker: NA
Text: that Noonkanbah had been chosen as a focal

Speaker: NA
Text: point for these claims and had become one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: spearheads of Aboriginal territory advancement.

Speaker: NA
Text: What nonsense! Noonkanbah obviously is a dry

Speaker: NA
Text: run for diamond mining in the north east Kim-

Speaker: NA
Text: berleys where the Ashton joint venture is 57 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent owned by Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a gearing up to put into effect a massive dia-

Speaker: NA
Text: mond mining operation near Kununurra. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition is saying that the time has come for

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal intervention in an examination of the

Speaker: NA
Text: whole land rights question, to present model

Speaker: NA
Text: land rights legislation to the States, to allow

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines to run their own land developments

Text: commission and to effect Federal and State

Speaker: NA
Text: agreements to define sacred sites wherever they

Speaker: NA
Text: may be!

Speaker: NA
Text: any way lacks interest in Aboriginal people

Speaker: NA
Text: simply because he failed to make two visits, as

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member opposite suggest, in the

Speaker: NA
Text: last couple of weeks.

Speaker: NA
Text: If one were to look at the performance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member of Cunningham in relation

Speaker: NA
Text: to Aboriginal affairs during thetimehe has been

Speaker: NA
Text: in the Parliament one could be forgiven for ask-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing whether he knew whether Aboriginals

Speaker: NA
Text: existed before he was appointed Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: spokesman on Aboriginal anairs. I searched the

Speaker: NA
Text: Hansard record to find out the extent of his con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributions to matters relating to Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: affairs. I found that he had asked one question

Speaker: NA
Text: which was part of a run of questions on a particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lar issue. Obviously those questions were handed

Speaker: NA
Text: out to members of the Opposition. In a speech on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Human Rights Commission Bill he made a

Speaker: NA
Text: passing reference to Aboriginals in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: the racial discrimination legislation. He seeks to

Speaker: NA
Text: compare his performance with the considerable

Speaker: NA
Text: interest of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: which has been well known for many years.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is well

Speaker: NA
Text: known for his involvement in the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: legal rights movement in Western Australia and

Speaker: NA
Text: for his willingness to work for Aboriginal people.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is well known in this Parliament for his in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volvement in the Aboriginal affairs committees

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Government. He is well known for his dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinguished service on the Joint Committee on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory)

Speaker: NA
Text: Act and for the very distinguished contribution

Speaker: NA
Text: he made to that legislation. I do not think it is fair

Speaker: NA
Text: proper for the honourable member for Cun-

Speaker: NA
Text: to make snide references to the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter for Aboriginal Affairs who has performed so

Speaker: NA
Text: well in this area both before he was appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: and as Minister. The mere fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cunningham made two

Speaker: NA
Text: to a certain location after being appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: he Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal affairs

Speaker: NA
Text: does not make him an expert. I think that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: no more carefully documented than by reading

Speaker: NA
Text: the speech made by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: in Cunningham today. Although it was laced with

Speaker: NA
Text: quotes it showed that he still does not understand

Speaker: NA
Text: the issue which is involved. The matter of public

Speaker: NA
Text: importance is in these terms:

Speaker: NA
Text: The urgent need for the use of Commonwealth powers

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent deteriorating relations between the Kimberley

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines and mining companies and the Western Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: What is he asking for? He is asking for 'the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth powers'. Did his address take

Speaker: NA
Text: up the matter of those powers? The only occasion

Speaker: NA
Text: on which he referred to Commonwealth powers

Speaker: NA
Text: was when he referred to a meeting of legal

Speaker: NA
Text: officers which had considered this question. He

Speaker: NA
Text: referred obliquely to section 51 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution. I ask the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham whether he knows what section 51

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Constitution is about. It is a section of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Constitution which has many parts to it. It would

Speaker: NA
Text: be helpful to know what parts he was referring

Speaker: NA
Text: to. Was he endeavouring to suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth should exercise its power in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation to restrictions on the export of minerals? Is

Speaker: NA
Text: that what he was trying to do? Was he trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: suggest that the Commonwealth ought to use its

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to make laws for people of a specific

Speaker: NA
Text: race-tha t might include Aboriginals-a s a basis

Speaker: NA
Text: for legislating in this area? Was he suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Commonwealth Government should use

Speaker: NA
Text: its power to acquire land for purposes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth?

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West-Now , you've got it.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: If that is the basis of his ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gument it is rather fascinating because never be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore have I heard honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: try to look at this question objectively. The

Speaker: NA
Text: power to acquire land is the power to do so on

Speaker: NA
Text: just terms. What does that mean? The power to

Speaker: NA
Text: acquire land on just terms means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth, when approaching a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: State to acquire land, has to pay for that land not

Speaker: NA
Text: the value which is determined by the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment but the value which is evaluated indepen-

Speaker: NA
Text: dently. That matter ultimately can be disputed in

Speaker: NA
Text: the courts. The fact of the matter is that we can-

Speaker: NA
Text: vassed this question in some detail when we

Speaker: NA
Text: looked at the most complex situation in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland.

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members ought to understand

Speaker: NA
Text: what the passage down that road means to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth. They ought to realise the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation consequences it would have for the people

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia. Mark my words: If the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government buys land for the Aborigines

Speaker: NA
Text: in Western Australia, Queensland or any other

Speaker: NA
Text: State in order to protect the interests of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines, it has to buy the mineral rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: that land. If there happens to be extensive aggre-

Speaker: NA
Text: gations of minerals in a particular area the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: monwealth Government in effect would have to

Speaker: NA
Text: to buy those minerals from the State, if the State

Speaker: NA
Text: owned the land. I do not have the figures at my

Speaker: NA
Text: fingertips but if that is the path the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: wishes to tread the Commonwealth Government

Speaker: NA
Text: would need to expend hundreds, i f not thou-

Speaker: NA
Text: sands, of millions of dollars. What would that do

Speaker: NA
Text: to Aboriginal programs throughout Australia?

Speaker: NA
Text: We know how much money is available in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget for programs for Aboriginal people. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would be lucky to buy minimal areas of land for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines with money allocated in the Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: We would have to forgo housing programs,

Speaker: NA
Text: health programs, education programs and Abor-

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal legal aid services. Are honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite suggesting that this is the path

Speaker: NA
Text: we should follow? I do not believe it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let us examine the record of honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members opposite when they were in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. When dealing with legislation in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: and when dealing with the report of Mr Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: Woodward in 1975, the Labor Government did

Speaker: NA
Text: not seek to extend the operation of that legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation beyond the Northern Territory. That

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be made known. In 1975 the then Min-

Speaker: NA
Text: ister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hughes ( Mr Les Johnson),

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced a Bill in relation to Aboriginal land

Speaker: NA
Text: rights. Ultimately that legislation was completed

Speaker: NA
Text: by this Government. In his second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech the then Minister stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . that the Australian Parliament may only legislate in

Speaker: NA
Text: this direction in the Northern Territory is a matter of regret,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we have made it clear to the various State Governments

Speaker: NA
Text: that we support similar recognition of Aboriginal land title in

Speaker: NA
Text: the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is the position I have adopted in this House.

Speaker: NA
Text: I regard the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory) Act as a model. I believe it is appropri-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate that the States should implement similar

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation in relation to Aboriginal land. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve that if such legislation had been enacted in

Speaker: NA
Text: the States we would be in a far better position in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to Western Australia than we are at the

Speaker: NA
Text: moment. There is no doubt about that. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: also that the comment is pertinent to New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales-the State from which I come and from

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honourable member for Cunningham

Speaker: NA
Text: comes. It will be interesting to see the results

Speaker: NA
Text: which emerge from the committee of inquiry in

Speaker: NA
Text: New South Wales because we have seen no great

Speaker: NA
Text: enthusiasm to take up the Woodward committee

Speaker: NA
Text: report and to implement its terms holus-bolus;

Speaker: NA
Text: nor have we seen any great enthusiasm for the

Speaker: NA
Text: provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights

Speaker: NA
Text: (Northern Territory) Act to be introduced holusrecognised

Speaker: NA
Text: bolus in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West-The y are slightly more enthusiastic

Speaker: NA
Text: than Court.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Are they slightly more

Speaker: NA
Text: enthusiastic? I would like to see action rather

Speaker: NA
Text: than words. Let us wait and see. The path is a

Speaker: NA
Text: tortuous one. If we examine the steps taken

Speaker: NA
Text: various State governments of various political

Speaker: NA
Text: persuasions- I am referring to Labor and nonfor

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor State governments-w e will find that to

Speaker: NA
Text: date they have been unwilling, although they

Speaker: NA
Text: have the powers to do so, to adopt legislation

Speaker: NA
Text: which enables these matters to be resolved

Speaker: NA
Text: framework in which legitimate Aboriginal nal people.

Speaker: NA
Text: interests and the interests of the community gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: erally are taken into account. That is what is per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitted by the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory) Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: It has to be understood that in this area

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal land rights and mining developments

Speaker: NA
Text: not mutually exclusive. I was fascinated by the

Speaker: NA
Text: opening remarks of the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Cunningham. He appeared to suggest that in

Speaker: NA
Text: some way they were incompatible. Recently, I

Speaker: NA
Text: was at a land rights forum in New South Wales.

Speaker: NA
Text: We all know that honourable members opposite

Speaker: NA
Text: take an interest in uranium development. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have a somewhat adverse view to such developreasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. At that meeting I heard an Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: speaking after a rather rabid anti-uranium

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker. I am not suggesting that he was a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Labor Party. The Aboriginal from

Speaker: NA
Text: stood up and said: 'What are you on about,

Speaker: NA
Text: mate? Are you here about uranium or Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: land rights?' He was not interested in whether he

Speaker: NA
Text: was making an anti-uranium speech. All he priate

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to know was that Aboriginal land rights pass

Speaker: NA
Text: would be protected. That was his real concern some

Speaker: NA
Text: and his real interest. By the very nature of his indrawn.

Speaker: NA
Text: terjection, I think he recognised that mining

Speaker: NA
Text: velopment and land rights are not incompatible.

Speaker: NA
Text: They can be the subject of negotiation between

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable men who have an intention of overresolve

Speaker: NA
Text: coming what difficulties may arise between

Speaker: NA
Text: and are prepared to take into account each

Speaker: NA
Text: other's interests.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Cunningham

Speaker: NA
Text: made some mention of an article written by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for the West Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian. Clearly, the Minister and members on

Speaker: NA
Text: this side of the House are very much aware of the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of the Aboriginal people in their land

Speaker: NA
Text: and traditional sites. In that article the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: spelt out in some detail the spiritual significance

Speaker: NA
Text: of land to Aboriginals. Of course, it has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is not significant to the same

Speaker: NA
Text: degree in relation to every location or to every

Speaker: NA
Text: site. Aboriginal interest does not follow the

Speaker: NA
Text: boundaries of a pastoral lease. Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: interest is in very particular and precise locations.

Speaker: NA
Text: I was interested in the comments by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Cunningham suggesting

Speaker: NA
Text: that his own approach to the Minister was to seek

Speaker: NA
Text: by a new investigation and mapping of Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: sites and the suspension of the Amax operations

Speaker: NA
Text: the time being in an endeavour to settle upon

Speaker: NA
Text: new personalities that might be involved in such

Speaker: NA
Text: a mapping task, presumably after discussions

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Western Australian Government, the

Speaker: NA
Text: in a Commonwealth Government and the Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr West-Wha t do you suggest?'

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Text: Quite frankly, I thought that

Speaker: NA
Text: that was a positive suggestion. It was not the sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborgestion that the honourable member for Cun-

Speaker: NA
Text: are ningham made today. He said that the Common-

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth ought to use some imaginary powers that

Speaker: NA
Text: it has to enable it to march into the States

Speaker: NA
Text: tomorrow and to grant Aboriginal land rights on

Speaker: NA
Text: some other basis. The fact ofthe matter is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there can be no such approach. The Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs, in all his statements on this

Speaker: NA
Text: topic, has said that there is an opportunity for

Speaker: NA
Text: men to sit down together and to work

Speaker: NA
Text: out an appropriate response; and he was pursu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing these matters with the Western Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. It might be helpful for me to quote

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the speeches of the Minister in the

Speaker: NA
Text: other place. I quote from a speech made on this

Speaker: NA
Text: topic in the Senate chamber on 1 April. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: In all those circumstances, I do not believe it is an appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: case where the Commonwealth ought to step in and

Speaker: NA
Text: its own legislation which in turn would have to make in

Speaker: NA
Text: way the same distinctions as are now trying to be

Speaker: NA
Text: deHe was speaking about the difficulties experi-

Speaker: NA
Text: enced when discussions take place between Ab-

Speaker: NA
Text: originals, government and mining companies to

Speaker: NA
Text: questions as to where mining might and

Speaker: NA
Text: them might not be appropriate. He went on:

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a situation in Western Australia' at the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: which is not totally satisfactory because of lack of clarity. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am pursuing with the Western Australian Government some

Speaker: NA
Text: better set of rules which could be more easily understood by

Speaker: NA
Text: all concerned.

Speaker: NA
Text: If honourable members look at the speech that

Speaker: NA
Text: he made on that same day and on the same topic

Speaker: NA
Text: they will see that he had this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is the consistent cry of the Opposition that we should use

Speaker: NA
Text: the powers given in the 1976 referendum to override the

Speaker: NA
Text: States and thereby advance Aboriginal welfare. I would see

Speaker: NA
Text: that as a last resort, bearing in mind that in so many key

Speaker: NA
Text: fields it is the States that deliver the services that

Speaker: NA
Text: tial to Aborigines, be they education, health, welfare, hous-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing, police or the court system.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals can be plucked out of Australia's general politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal and administrative system and made sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: ject . . . to some system of Commonwealth law is, in

Speaker: NA
Text: my view, to fly in the face of reality, a reality which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party when in government had to face and which tem-

Speaker: NA
Text: pered its rhetoric.

Speaker: NA
Text: These are important questions. There is scope

Speaker: NA
Text: further negotiations and discussions. In my view,

Speaker: NA
Text: not even the Labor Party realistically in the

Speaker: NA
Text: or even now puts forward the proposition that

Speaker: NA
Text: there ought to be intervention by the that

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Mr MILLAR - long

Speaker: NA
Text: Order! The honourable member's time has of

Speaker: NA
Text: expired.

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: Fremantle) (4.20)-The

Speaker: NA
Text: speech by the honourable member for Dundas

Speaker: NA
Text: ( Mr Ruddock) was an appropriate speech. At

Speaker: NA
Text: least it was consistent with everything this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been saying in the field of

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal Affairs since it came into office

Speaker: NA
Text: 1975. The speech was full of lots

Speaker: NA
Text: tions but nothing more. He quoted some earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: instances where the good intentions of Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment had led to an allegedly appropriate result.

Speaker: NA
Text: He instanced the Aurukun and Mornington Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Island situation. I say to the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dundas: If he thinks the solution at Aurukun

Speaker: NA
Text: and Mornington Island is an appropriate solin

Speaker: NA
Text: ution for the situaton in the Kimberleys, he will

Speaker: NA
Text: find that he is on a complete collision course

Speaker: NA
Text: the Aboriginal people of the Kimberleys. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Aurukun and Mornington Island solution was a

Speaker: NA
Text: disaster. As a result of that the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal Affairs at that time, Mr Viner, was forced

Speaker: NA
Text: out of his portfolio. The Aurukun and MorningHe

Speaker: NA
Text: ton Island dispute destroyed him. Just as surely

Speaker: NA
Text: as that happened, this dispute in the Kimberleys

Speaker: NA
Text: will destroy the current Minister for Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs (Senator Chaney) unless he takes

Speaker: NA
Text: positive action and talks about more than just

Speaker: NA
Text: good intentions.

Speaker: NA
Text: These good intentions have come from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) down. Perthat

Speaker: NA
Text: haps I can just quote from a speech made by

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister in 1978 when he was opening the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Aboriginal Conference: He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It was never good enough for politicians or bureaucrats

Speaker: NA
Text: whether at the State or Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: iginal people their conception of what was good

Speaker: NA
Text: original people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Yet that is exactly what has been happening

Speaker: NA
Text: and again. Vain and egotistical State Premiers

Speaker: NA
Text: have been trying to force their wishes on the

Speaker: NA
Text: original people of this country. It istimethat this

Speaker: NA
Text: are so essensort of self-righteousness on the part of this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government gave way to a little positive action.

Speaker: NA
Text: To suggest that in some way

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me instance another example. In 1978 the

Speaker: NA
Text: then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner,

Speaker: NA
Text: was at Docker River. I was present at that site

Speaker: NA
Text: where the title deeds to the Petermann Ranges

Speaker: NA
Text: were handed over to the people of that region in

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Northern Territory. The ceremony took place

Speaker: NA
Text: in Western Australia, for the very good reason

Speaker: NA
Text: past that Western Australian Aborigines had no land

Speaker: NA
Text: rights nor the prospect of any. The Minister took

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity to express his support for the

Speaker: NA
Text: land claims of the people of Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: He indicated his hope that it would not be too

Speaker: NA
Text: before they too had the same sort of tenure

Speaker: NA
Text: land as that held by the people in the North-

Speaker: NA
Text: ern Territory. Later he expressed the view that

Speaker: NA
Text: there ought to be a common approach to land

Speaker: NA
Text: rights in relation to that central area, parts of

Speaker: NA
Text: which are in South Australia, the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory and Western Australia. Nothing happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as the Aboriginal people of that area were

Speaker: NA
Text: in concerned it was just more good intentions and

Speaker: NA
Text: of good intenmore disappointment.

Speaker: NA
Text: I come now to the current Minister. A refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: ence has been made to his article in the West

Speaker: NA
Text: of 11 April. I find very little in that

Speaker: NA
Text: article with which I can disagree. There are a

Speaker: NA
Text: couple of very substantive matters on which I am

Speaker: NA
Text: severe disagreement with the Minister, but in

Speaker: NA
Text: terms of it being a fairly vacuous statement ofhis

Speaker: NA
Text: with good intentions I cannot really disagree. What

Speaker: NA
Text: we need is something more than self-righteous,

Speaker: NA
Text: vacuous good intentions on the part of Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborin this Government. The Minister said that he

Speaker: NA
Text: was in favour of the preservation of scared sites.

Speaker: NA
Text: supports the idea that Aboriginals need to

Speaker: NA
Text: have land and access to more land. But all he is

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared to do is say that he will try to talk

Speaker: NA
Text: around to his point of view the Premier of Wes-

Speaker: NA
Text: some tern Australia. The honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: his Dundas said that the Minister believes that these

Speaker: NA
Text: are questions which can be sorted out by reason-

Speaker: NA
Text: able men. I ask: Is the Premier of Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia a reasonable man? Even if we concede

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Chaney is a reasonable man, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: the Premier of Western Australia a reasonable man?

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly, he is not. In my view, and as the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Cunningham ( Mr West) has

Speaker: NA
Text: already outlined, the Premier and his Ministers

Speaker: NA
Text: are temperamentally unsuited to deal with this

Speaker: NA
Text: level to impose on the Abor-

Speaker: NA
Text: for the Abissue. All they have been prepared to do is

Speaker: NA
Text: score political points at the expense of the

Speaker: NA
Text: besieged people of Noonkanbah. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: time misrepresented and distorted those people's

Speaker: NA
Text: views and actions on numerous occasions. As a

Speaker: NA
Text: Abconsequence, they have totally lost any chance

Speaker: NA
Text: that they ever had of trying to solve this dispute.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have demonstrated that they are not leave to do so.

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable men, nor are they interested in solv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the underlying problems at Noonkanbah.

Speaker: NA
Text: They do not seem to understand the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: people with whom they are dealing.

Speaker: NA
Text: seem to understand the sorts of lives that most of 2d Session

Speaker: NA
Text: these old men at Noonkanbah have lived. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have lived through massacre; they have lived in

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances of gross discrimination. If they

Speaker: NA
Text: had raised their heads in support of their claims a

Speaker: NA
Text: few years ago, they would have been brutally

Speaker: NA
Text: repressed, as the honourable member for Dun-

Speaker: NA
Text: das knows. The Minister makes another point.

Speaker: NA
Text: He says that we must not threaten the good re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations between black and white in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, one has to agree with that point, but

Speaker: NA
Text: for how much longer will it be the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have to bear the burden of good re-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations between black and white in this country?

Speaker: NA
Text: For how much longer will Aboriginals have to be

Speaker: NA
Text: the ones on whom the responsibility falls? Do

Speaker: NA
Text: they have to sit by and take what is meted out to

Speaker: NA
Text: them by an aggressive white community, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in the Kimberleys? What has the Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter had to say about Mr Widdell, who tried to

Speaker: NA
Text: intoxicate members of the Turkey Creek com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity so that they could not take part in the

Speaker: NA
Text: State election? What has the Minister had to say

Speaker: NA
Text: about the Police Commissioner who has rounded

Speaker: NA
Text: up Aborigines, put them in paddy wagons and

Speaker: NA
Text: then cross-examined them about their voting justice

Speaker: NA
Text: procedures or about the way in which they voted tralian

Speaker: NA
Text: at the last State election?

Speaker: NA
Text: For how much longer will Aboriginal people

Speaker: NA
Text: have to put up with this sort of treatment in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of good relations between black and

Speaker: NA
Text: white? It seems to me that it is high time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Aborigines were given a fair go. They have

Speaker: NA
Text: begun now-belatedl y but with a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: passion-t o stand up for their rights, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: their land rights, and for their beliefs. It is time notwithstanding,

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Minister stopped hiding behind the ideal

Speaker: NA
Text: of good relations between black and white

Speaker: NA
Text: simply to see the Aboriginals of this country

Speaker: NA
Text: trodden under foot by the State Government yet

Speaker: NA
Text: again.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish briefly to refer to another matter which

Speaker: NA
Text: involves this situation very much. In February

Speaker: NA
Text: this year, just a couple of months ago, we saw a

Speaker: NA
Text: report prepared by the State Department of the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States of America for a committee of the

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Representatives and a committee of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate in that country. It is entitled: 'Country Re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports on Human Rights Practices for 1979'. I

Speaker: NA
Text: have spoken to the Minister who was at the table

Speaker: NA
Text: earlier and he gave me permission to have this

Speaker: NA
Text: document incorporated in Hansard. I now seek

Speaker: NA
Text: Leave granted.

Text: The document read asfollows-
