Text: COUNTRY REPORTS ON HUMAN RIGHTS

Speaker: NA
Text: PRACTICES FOR 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: REPORT

Speaker: NA
Text: submitted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS US HOUSE

Speaker: NA
Text: OF REPRESENTATIVES

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS US

Speaker: NA
Text: SENATE

Speaker: NA
Text: by the

Speaker: NA
Text: DEPARTMENT OF STATE

Speaker: NA
Text: In accordance with Sections 116 (d)and 502B (b) ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, as amended

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 FEBRUARY 1980

Speaker: NA
Text: Printed for the use of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and

Speaker: NA
Text: Foreign Relations of the House of Representatives and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate respectively

Speaker: NA
Text: EAST ASIA AND THE PACIFIC

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is committed to the principles of freedom and

Speaker: NA
Text: and full personal rights assured for all citizens. Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: society adheres firmly to the democratic traditions

Speaker: NA
Text: inherited from Great Britain. Political, economic and social

Speaker: NA
Text: rights are guaranteed under the Australian constitution,

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation and common law.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Federal Racial Discrimination Act of 1975 prohibits all

Speaker: NA
Text: forms of racial discrimination based on color, race, ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: background or place of birth. Concurrently with the passage

Speaker: NA
Text: of this Act, Australia ratified the International Convention

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination,

Speaker: NA
Text: thereby undertaking a commitment to combat racism both at

Speaker: NA
Text: home and abroad. The Racial Discrimination Act of 1975

Speaker: NA
Text: which overrides any existing laws that may

Speaker: NA
Text: operate with a discriminatory effect, the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been accused of administering certain laws

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in a way

Speaker: NA
Text: that has the effect of discriminating between the rights of

Speaker: NA
Text: white and black Australians. This fact is recognized by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government of Australia which, through the Office of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissioner for Community Relations, is seeking to end

Speaker: NA
Text: such vestiges of discrimination.

Speaker: NA
Text: Respect for the Integrity of the Person, Including Freedom

Speaker: NA
Text: from:

Speaker: NA
Text: a. Torture

Speaker: NA
Text: Torture is neither condoned nor practiced in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: b. Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or

Speaker: NA
Text: Punishment

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian law prohibits such punishment and is respected in

Speaker: NA
Text: practice. Writs of habeas corpus are available. Preventive

Speaker: NA
Text: detention is not practiced.

Speaker: NA
Text: c. Arbitrary Arrest or Imprisonment

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian law prohibits such action and is respected in

Speaker: NA
Text: practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: d. Denial of Fair Public Trial

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian law guarantees the right to a fair hearing, the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to a fair public trial and the unimpeded right of coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: sel; these guarantees are respected in practice. Defendants

Speaker: NA
Text: are informed in advance of charges and have pre-trial access

Speaker: NA
Text: to evidence against them.

Speaker: NA
Text: e. Invasion of the Home

Speaker: NA
Text: Effective legal safeguards exist to prevent arbitrary invasion

Speaker: NA
Text: of the home in Australia. No search may be conducted with-

Speaker: NA
Text: out a judicially issued warrant.

Speaker: NA
Text: 2. Governmental Policies Relating to the Fulfillment of

Speaker: NA
Text: Such Vital Needs as Food, Shelter, Health Care and

Speaker: NA
Text: Education:

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has one of the most comprehensive social welfare

Speaker: NA
Text: systems among the Western democratic nations. Basic food,

Speaker: NA
Text: shelter, health care and social security benefits are guaran-

Speaker: NA
Text: teed for the entire population, including recent immigrants.

Speaker: NA
Text: Social security and welfare accounts for the largest single

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the Australian Government's budget expenditures,

Speaker: NA
Text: amounting to some 28 per cent in the fiscal year ending 10

Speaker: NA
Text: June 1979. Public education is universal and free and in-

Speaker: NA
Text: cludes special facilities for the handicapped. There is a gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral right of ownership of private property which is protected

Speaker: NA
Text: by law.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginal rights and development are of constant and

Speaker: NA
Text: active concern in Australia. Because of deep cultural

Speaker: NA
Text: differences between the Aboriginal and European popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lations, the Commonwealth Government experienced great

Speaker: NA
Text: difficulty in pursuing its former policy of assimilation

Speaker: NA
Text: through promoting social change among the Aboriginals so

Speaker: NA
Text: that they would become indistinguishable from other Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians in standards of living,

Speaker: NA
Text: in community affairs. By late 197S, government policy had

Speaker: NA
Text: changed to one of commitment to the principle that Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nals should be as free as other Australians to determine their

Speaker: NA
Text: own varied futures. The policy of the Queensland Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, however, continues to promote the concept of full inte-

Speaker: NA
Text: gration of all indigenous people.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government acknowledges that in general the Aborigi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nal population is disadvantaged

Speaker: NA
Text: housing, health and employment. Through the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: of Aboriginal Affairs and other federal and state agencies,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has sought to secure for Aboriginals access

Speaker: NA
Text: to government service equal to that accorded other Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian citizens together with

Speaker: NA
Text: to their disadvantaged state. Special programs have been

Speaker: NA
Text: undertaken to assist Aboriginals in becoming self-sufficient.

Speaker: NA
Text: These include encouragement of land ownership, expansion

Speaker: NA
Text: of employment opportunities, training programs, support for

Speaker: NA
Text: small business acquisition, home ownership and involve-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in other development projects. These policies are

Speaker: NA
Text: directed toward helping the Aboriginals to become economi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cally self-sufficient while preserving their distinctive

Speaker: NA
Text: 3. Respect for Civil and Political Liberties, Including:

Speaker: NA
Text: a. Freedom of Speech, Press, Religion and Assembly

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian law guarantees all

Speaker: NA
Text: are respected in practice. There is no government-owned

Speaker: NA
Text: Press and no Press censorship. Members of all religious sects

Speaker: NA
Text: are free to observe their practices without interference from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: In West Australia, 1976 amendments to the Police Act re-

Speaker: NA
Text: strict a person from organizing or conducting a procession,

Speaker: NA
Text: meeting, or assembly in a public place without the per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission of the Commissioner of Police. The Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: may not, however, withhold such permission unless he has

Speaker: NA
Text: reason to believe there will be a disturbance. A few trade

Speaker: NA
Text: unionists in West Australia have been arrested and fined for

Speaker: NA
Text: violations of this law. In Queensland, laws governing street

Speaker: NA
Text: marches have led to confrontation between the police and

Speaker: NA
Text: civil rights activists.

Speaker: NA
Text: b. Freedom of Movement Within the Country, Foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: Travel and Emigration

Speaker: NA
Text: There are no restrictions on movement within or outside

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, including the right of emigration. Race is barred

Speaker: NA
Text: as a criterion for approval or rejection of an application to

Speaker: NA
Text: immigrate to Australia and, on a per capita basis, Australia's

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptance of Indochinese refugees is the highest of any

Speaker: NA
Text: country in the world. Since 1975 some 25,000 refugees from

Speaker: NA
Text: Indochina have been admitted for permanent residence in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: c. Freedom to Participate in the Political Process

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth law guarantees this freedom, which is

Speaker: NA
Text: respected in practice. Complaints have been made that cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain amendments to the electoral laws of West Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: have the effect of restricting the right of Aboriginals to vote.

Speaker: NA
Text: These provisions relate to enrollment and voting procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: and could be applied in a manner to discourage voting by

Speaker: NA
Text: Aboriginals and others notfluentin English. In at least one

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, illiterates were prevented from using' how to vote'

Speaker: NA
Text: cards and the outcome ofthe elections was overturned by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian courts. Women have enjoyed full political and

Speaker: NA
Text: civil rights in Australia since the turn of the century. In prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice, however, they do not participate in the political and

Speaker: NA
Text: economic life of the country to the same extent as men. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are six women members of the Federal Senate, but no

Speaker: NA
Text: woman serves currently in the House of Representatives.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian trade union is strong, well-organized and

Speaker: NA
Text: active both in politics and in industrial relations. The rights

Speaker: NA
Text: to organize, strike, bargain collectively and lobby are

Speaker: NA
Text: guaranteed in law and exercised in practice.

Speaker: NA
Text: occupation, and participation

Speaker: NA
Text: 4. Government Attitude and Record Regarding Inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national and Non-governmental Investigation of Alleged

Speaker: NA
Text: Violations of Human Rights:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Department of State has no knowledge of any requests

Speaker: NA
Text: to investigate alleged violations of humanrightsin Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: by international or non-governmental organizations.

Speaker: Mr DAWKINS
Text: I thank the House. The im-

Speaker: NA
Text: in such areas as education,

Speaker: NA
Text: portant thing about this report is that it is an

Speaker: NA
Text: examination of human rights around the world.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a section on Australia. Whilst in many

Speaker: NA
Text: respects Australia fares well, there are a number

Speaker: NA
Text: additional services appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: of areas in which this report levels some criticism.

Speaker: NA
Text: For instance, it criticises the Queensland

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in relation to its treatment of Abor-

Speaker: NA
Text: igines. It also criticises the Queensland Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in relation to its laws of assembly. It is criti-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: culture. relation to those parts of that State's electoral

Speaker: NA
Text: laws which discriminate against Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people. It also criticises the Western Australian

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: of these basic rights and they

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Government has become a member of

Speaker: NA
Text: the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: no other reason-i f it is not interested in protect-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the rights of the Aboriginal people in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is a separate international question also.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is that at Noonkanbah it is an American

Speaker: NA
Text: company which has been pushed by the State

Speaker: NA
Text: Government into desecrating sacred sites. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: Amax (Exploration) Australia Inc. is probably

Speaker: NA
Text: an unwilling partner in this exercise. I would not

Speaker: NA
Text: be at all surprised if Amax did not go back to

Speaker: NA
Text: that site at Pea Hill. It is an American company

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being pushed into this situation. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: something which would never happen in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United States. This is an international matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government can ignore that fact no longer.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Dundas seems to

Speaker: NA
Text: balk at the prospect of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Government taking any effective action on this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. I would have thought-an d I am sure that

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: have thought-tha t the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Dundas would have read the Senate committee

Speaker: NA
Text: report of 1978, which lucidly enunciates the ways

Speaker: NA
Text: in which the Commonwealth can intervene in

Speaker: NA
Text: this area. It can acquire land and such acquisition

Speaker: NA
Text: does not necessarily need to have the horrendous

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences to which the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Dundas was alluding.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable discussions on these question

Speaker: NA
Text: mining on Aboriginal land or on sacred sites

Speaker: NA
Text: less we improve the tenure of the Aboriginal

Speaker: NA
Text: people over their land. There is no point in proon

Speaker: NA
Text: posing palsy-walsy discussions with the Aborigithe

Speaker: NA
Text: nes if they have no rights to the land in question.

Speaker: NA
Text: They have no rights at all at the moment.

Speaker: NA
Text: tenure of the land has to be improved so that years.

Speaker: NA
Text: they can participate meaningfully in any

Speaker: NA
Text: tiations which take place. We are not saying

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: nes, as a result of their prior ownership of this

Speaker: NA
Text: country, have a right to be reasonably consulted

Speaker: NA
Text: about the natureof the resource development

Speaker: NA
Text: and where it will take place. That is all that

Speaker: NA
Text: are asking for.

Speaker: NA

Text: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1980

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill presented by Mr Macphee, and read a

Speaker: NA
Text: first time.

Speaker: NA
Text: sitting Thursday to which

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr MACPHEE
Text: Balaclava-Minister for Im-

Speaker: NA
Text: migration and Ethnic Affairs) (4.51)- I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: The purpose of the Bill is to provide for two

Speaker: NA
Text: minor machinery amendments to the Migration

Speaker: NA
Text: Act 1958. The first is contained in clause 3 and

Speaker: NA
Text: amends the definitions of 'proclaimed airport'

Speaker: NA
Text: and 'proclaimed port' in sub-section 5 (1) of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Migration Act. The amendment is necessary as a

Speaker: NA
Text: consequence of the provisions of clause 4 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Customs Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1980 which

Speaker: NA
Text: replaces the concept of establishing ports and ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pointing airports by proclamation with a system

Speaker: NA
Text: of appointments by the Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, clause 4 of the Bill narrows one of

Speaker: NA
Text: the defences to an offence under sub-section

Speaker: NA
Text: 11C(1) of the Migration Act committed by a

Speaker: NA
Text: carrier which brings persons to Australia without

Speaker: NA
Text: visas or return endorsements. Under the Act as

Speaker: NA
Text: presently drafted a carrier has a defence if he can

Speaker: NA
Text: establish that he had reasonable grounds for be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieving that a person was not exempted from the

Speaker: NA
Text: need to obtain a visa or return endorsement. The

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment will limit the defence to establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: that he had reasonable grounds for believing

Speaker: NA
Text: that the person was exempt from the need to

Speaker: NA
Text: obtain a visa or return endorsement. I commend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Hurford)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Text: Blaxland) (4.53)-This is a

Speaker: NA
Text: cognate debate covering two Bills. The purpose

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Excise TariffAmendment Bill (No. 3) is to

Speaker: NA
Text: increase the price of oil and the purpose of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill is to de-

Text: crease the price of liquefied petroleum gas. It is a

Text: curious combination of legislation aimed at

Speaker: NA
Text: putting the price of one fuel up and the price of

Text: another fuel down. It shows the disarray of the

Text: Government's energy policies and the complete

Text: lack of co-ordination and direction with which

Text: Government energy policy is now being directed.

Text: I think it is fair to say that the Government's en-

Text: ergy policy is completely in tatters and in a state

Text: ment's energy policy has essentially been higher

Text: have higher petrol prices but we are now to have

Speaker: NA
Text: lower prices for liquefied petroleum gas, not just

Speaker: NA
Text: for household users-th e Opposition supports

Speaker: NA
Text: having lower prices for them-bu t for industry in

Speaker: NA
Text: general. The Government has said that liquefied

Speaker: NA
Text: petroleum gas is so valuable that it has to be

Speaker: NA
Text: rationed by price, but it is going to ration it

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing the price. The price will be reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: $50 to $ 100 a tonne less than it is at the moment.

Text: Quite obviously the whole rationale of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's pricing policy has disappeared.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has been stumping the country

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that Australia must have an opportunity

Speaker: NA
Text: cost energy pricing policy- a policy that must

Speaker: NA
Text: reflect the replacement cost of energy and the

Text: true world value of it. That is why we have a high

Text: oil price and that is why motorists have to pay

Speaker: NA

Text: Government says that its policy has been

Text: ment immediately panics, drops its bundle and

Speaker: NA
Text: runs in with a subsidy to try to maintain its politi-

Text: from $18.66 a barrel to $24.77-a n increase of

Speaker: NA
Text: When we talk of liquefied petroleum gas we are

Speaker: NA
Text: talking essentially about butane and propane.

Speaker: NA
Text: These two products are produced at refineries in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia and are also naturally occurring prod-

Speaker: NA
Text: ucts in the Bass Strait oil producing areas. We

Speaker: NA
Text: produce roughly two million tonnes of LPG a

Speaker: NA
Text: year and we consume about 400,000 tonnes. The

Speaker: NA
Text: rest is exported to Japan. The Government, in

Speaker: NA
Text: the last 12 months, has dramatically increased

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of liquefied petroleum gas. About a

Speaker: NA
Text: year ago the price of liquefied petroleum gas was

Speaker: NA
Text: about $88 a tonne. It has now gone up to $252 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne. One may ask how this has happened.

Speaker: NA
Text: Essentially it has happened in this way: After the

Speaker: NA
Text: Iranian revolution there was a cutback in Iranian

Speaker: NA
Text: oil production and the glut of oil which had been

Speaker: NA
Text: evident in the world for a couple of years before

Speaker: NA
Text: that time disappeared. A premium was being

Speaker: NA
Text: paid in the spot market for oil and other pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: roleum products. The Organisation of Petroleum

Speaker: NA

Text: give liquefied petroleum gas the status of a full

Speaker: NA
Text: commodity and to price it appropriately on its

Speaker: NA
Text: British thermal unit heat equivalent, or its energy

Speaker: NA
Text: component. A result was that the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas has increased dramati-

Text: cally in the last 15 to 18 months. The Fraser

Speaker: NA
Text: Government decided to price liquefied pet-

Text: Esso-BHP was selling into the world market by

Speaker: NA
Text: selling to Japan, the price it was receiving started

Speaker: NA
Text: to rise as the world market price rose. The result

Speaker: NA
Text: was that our domestic price rose with those

Speaker: NA
Text: increases.

Text: Mr Jacobi-Nothin g to do with production at

Speaker: NA
Text: all.

Speaker: NA
Text: time has expired.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: Franklin) (5.24)-The two

Speaker: NA
Text: Bills before the House are of major significance

Speaker: NA
Text: and importance to this nation. The first is

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: second is the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No.

Speaker: NA
Text: 3). The Minister for Business and Consumer

Speaker: NA
Text: Affairs ( Mr Garland) indicated in his second

Speaker: NA
Text: reading speech that liquefied petroleum gas will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a viable alternative to petrol. I intend

Speaker: NA
Text: afternoon to confine most of my remarks to LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: and to how people can be encouraged to use

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG as an alternative fuel. I hope to explain

Speaker: NA
Text: many concerned people in Australia how it can

Speaker: NA
Text: be used and how its use can be encouraged. The

Speaker: NA
Text: world is facing an energy crisis and, unless

Speaker: NA
Text: tive action is taken by the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: courage the rational use of our natural energy

Speaker: NA
Text: sources, Australia may experience shortages and

Speaker: NA
Text: hardships similar to those now being expericase.

Speaker: NA
Text: enced by other countries. For this reason the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has formulated a policy of encourthe

Speaker: NA
Text: aging the use of LPG as u means ol'reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: dependence on imported oil, particularly in areas

Speaker: NA
Text: where LPG has premium value such as in

Speaker: NA
Text: automotive use.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe LPG can be a successful alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: to petrol power driven motor vehicles. There will

Speaker: NA
Text: be a reduction in the price of propane and

Speaker: NA
Text: butane to a common maximum price of $205 per

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne other than for petrochemical and non-

Speaker: NA
Text: traditional industrial uses. This means that the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of propane will be reduced by about 20 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent and the price of butane will be reduced by

Speaker: NA
Text: about 30 per cent. The new price will provide ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proximately a 50 per cent price differential be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor tween LPG and motor spirit in the Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: reference market and will provide a major incen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive towards the use of LPG in motor vehicles,

Speaker: NA
Text: especially in the case of fleet owners. I remind

Speaker: NA
Text: before the House that many taxi firms throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: subAustralia have heeded the warning and have

Speaker: NA
Text: already successfully converted most of their ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangement the hicles to LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: Conversion to LPG is not something new.

Speaker: NA
Text: or Many European countries have had LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: equipped vehicles for about 25 years. For

Speaker: NA
Text: example, Holland has on its roads 250,000 ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles converted to run on LPG. Because of a de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendence on imported crude products many of

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan's taxis and private vehicles are fitted for

Speaker: NA
Text: use. Japan, incidentally, imports most of its

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG from Australia. This country has proven

Speaker: NA
Text: that LPG fuelled cars can be reliable, safe and

Speaker: NA
Text: successful.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government must do several things to

Speaker: NA
Text: entice and encourage people in Australia to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: vert to LPG. First of all I believe we must direct a

Speaker: NA
Text: campaign not only atfleetowners but also at the

Speaker: NA
Text: ordinary car users of Australia telling them pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: the cisely the advantages and the disadvantages of

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG. Many people have an inherent fear of the

Speaker: NA
Text: use of LPG. This, of course, can be refuted by the

Speaker: NA
Text: success of its use in Japan and European coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries. Of course, when a dog bites a man very few

Speaker: NA
Text: people take notice. But when a man bites a dog

Speaker: NA
Text: this everybody sits up and takes notice. For that

Speaker: NA
Text: reason I believe we need to conduct a campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: to tell the people of Australia that LPG can be a

Speaker: NA
Text: to successful, safe and very viable alternative.

Speaker: NA
Text: To me there seems to be a pessimistic attitude

Speaker: NA
Text: posito LPG. We have read of an accident in New

Speaker: NA
Text: enSouth Wales in which a car using LPG was in-

Speaker: NA
Text: revolved in an explosion. We feel sorry for the

Speaker: NA
Text: people who were injured. But this is an isolated

Speaker: NA
Text: People should be informed of the success of

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG in other countries. I believe for that reason

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been very remiss. We

Speaker: NA
Text: our indicated that wc hoped many people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia would convert to LPG. But I am afraid

Speaker: NA
Text: we did not come up with a successful campaign

Speaker: NA
Text: to be directed at the car owners of Australia, the

Speaker: NA
Text: car users of Australia, to use LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: It takes about nine hours to convert a normal

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicle to LPG. Most modern motor ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles can be converted. Installers, of course, are

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming very efficient. The legitimate ones are

Speaker: NA
Text: now licensed. I believe that all installers in every

Speaker: NA
Text: State will have to be licensed in the near future.

Speaker: NA
Text: Of course, if we are to ask people to convert we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to make absolutely certain that they will be

Speaker: NA
Text: protected. Installers use mainly four basic com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponents to set up their new system- a steel fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: tank made to specification and generally located

Speaker: NA
Text: in the boot, a fuel lock filter, a converter and a

Speaker: NA
Text: gas carburettor. It is a simple process and, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, with experience and know-how it is being

Speaker: NA
Text: improved every day. Of course, many legitimate

Speaker: NA
Text: dealers are starting up all over Australia. I be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieve the thrust of the Government should be

Speaker: NA
Text: directed at encouraging and enticing people to

Speaker: NA
Text: convert their motor vehicles to LPG use.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are advantages and there are disadvant-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages in the use of LPG. I would like to outline

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the advantages and disadvantages. One

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage is that there are no lead, carbon or

Speaker: NA
Text: sludge formations on the valves or on any com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bustion chamber. There is no oil dilution. The

Speaker: NA
Text: engine runs up to three times longer without re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiring an overhaul. There is no oil contami-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation, no cylinder wash down and no crank case

Speaker: NA
Text: oil dilution. Oil stays clean and maintains its

Speaker: NA
Text: lubricating properties five or six times longer.

Speaker: NA
Text: Consequently there is a reduction in the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil changes and, as a result, there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: duction in the amount of oil used throughout

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, a fuel pump is not needed because

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG generates its own pressure. Consequently

Speaker: NA
Text: there is a reduction in the amount of work

Speaker: NA
Text: required to be carried out, such as in the

Speaker: NA
Text: overhauling of fuel pumps and so on. Spark

Speaker: NA
Text: plugs last four or five times longer and perform

Speaker: NA
Text: at peak efficiency most of the time because with

Speaker: NA
Text: clean-burning LPG there are no deposits. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are savings also in relation to replacement of

Speaker: NA
Text: parts, maintenance and labour. Of course, carbu-

Speaker: NA
Text: rettors do not get gummed up and for that reason

Speaker: NA
Text: the periodic replacement of parts is eliminated. If

Speaker: NA
Text: a car converted to LPG is tuned and adjusted

Speaker: NA
Text: correctly the engine will run quietly, smoothly

Speaker: NA
Text: and efficiently. The performance of the car is, of

Speaker: NA
Text: course, completely dependent on the person who

Speaker: NA
Text: carries out the conversion. If the work is done by

Speaker: NA
Text: a skilled person to specification the owner can

Speaker: NA
Text: rest assured there will be no problems.

Speaker: NA
Text: I shall now deal with some of the disadvant-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages of LPG use. A lot is said today about LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many people who condemn its use do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: very much about it.

Speaker: Mr SHIPTON
Text: Yo u can do mine.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: If I could do the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's conversion, I would. The disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantages can be confined to three or four in

Speaker: NA
Text: number. First, there is a reduction in power, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in top gear and, of course, this happens

Speaker: NA
Text: mostly out on the open road. The loss of power is

Speaker: NA
Text: predicted at around 10 per cent to 15 per cent.

Speaker: NA
Text: Secondly, there are problems with the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: filling stations and, of course, there are problems

Speaker: NA
Text: with filling the tank with LPG. However, I am

Speaker: NA
Text: hopeful that as LPG becomes a more accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative more filling stations will supply this

Speaker: NA
Text: product and consequently filling a car with LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: will be easier and a far more efficient operation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Thirdly, there have been certain problems with

Speaker: NA
Text: valve seating, but I believe that is only the result

Speaker: NA
Text: of incomplete and incompetent adjustment when

Speaker: NA
Text: the original equipment is fitted. Of course, the

Speaker: NA
Text: fitting of the tank sometimes creates a few prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems in terms of boot size but I believe that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: long term with the help of car manufacturers

Speaker: NA
Text: they also can be overcome.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe that with a more vigorous marketing

Speaker: NA
Text: approach more cars could be converted to LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: I believe the process can be simplified and the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of conversion can be reduced. As a conse-

Speaker: NA
Text: quence I believe more people may be

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged to convert to LPG. To me conversion

Speaker: NA
Text: to LPG is a sensible alternative. It could be very

Speaker: NA
Text: attractive because if there were a shortage of pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rerol one could switch to the use of LPG. I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: with a far greater and more vigorous approach

Speaker: NA
Text: we could increase the demand for LPG and en-

Speaker: NA
Text: courage the building of a greater number of

Speaker: NA
Text: outlets.

Speaker: NA
Text: We could encourage people to convert to the

Speaker: NA
Text: dual system, meaning that they could with the

Speaker: NA
Text: flick of a lever run their cars on either petrol or

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG. Surely this is something that we should be

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging car manufacturers to do. If they can

Speaker: NA
Text: offer options on gear boxes, differentials, uphol-

Speaker: NA
Text: stery, seating and so on we should be asking

Speaker: NA
Text: them to manufacture motor vehicles that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: converted quite easily to LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Jacobi-O r to petrochemicals.

Speaker: Mr GOODLUCK
Text: Certainly. I have been a

Speaker: NA
Text: strong advocate of the proposition that car

Speaker: NA
Text: manufacturers should be able to manufacture a

Speaker: NA
Text: motor either to be driven by petrol or to be pow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ered by LPG. I believe that they should offer this

Speaker: NA
Text: as an alternative. They should offer an LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: powered motor vehicle as an option. They can

Speaker: NA
Text: offer options on differentials, gear boxes and so

Speaker: NA
Text: on, so why should they not be able to produce a

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicle that can be run on either petrol or

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG? Government incentives should be offered

Speaker: NA
Text: to manufacturers to experiment on these very im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant alternatives. If that were done I believe

Speaker: NA
Text: in the near future the number of motor vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: predicted to convert to LPG use-i t is about 12

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent or 14 per cent-woul d increase greatly.

Speaker: NA
Text: This would mean that the amount of petrol being

Speaker: NA
Text: burned in some of the larger and more inefficient

Speaker: NA
Text: motor vehicles in Australia today would be

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some problems exist. I earnestly ask the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to look at them very seriously.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sometimes, because of change, it is very easy to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that we will do this or we will do that, but we

Speaker: NA
Text: need stricter regulations on conversion tech-

Speaker: NA
Text: niques. At the moment there is a lack of unifor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mity among the States regarding registration and

Speaker: NA
Text: licensing of premises and operators. There is a

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of availability of tanks, conversion kits and

Speaker: NA
Text: ancillary fittings and a lack of Australian gearing

Speaker: NA
Text: or know-how to produce kits and associated

Speaker: NA
Text: fittings. Why should we import most of our kits?

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely companies such as Repco- I believe it is

Speaker: NA
Text: already interested-ca n produce those kits and

Speaker: NA
Text: subsequently reduce the cost to the normal

Speaker: NA
Text: motorist of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: At one stage in Victoria there was

Speaker: NA
Text: of some 26,000 for conversion. I believe the cata-

Speaker: NA
Text: lyst for the conversions in Australia was the Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: and Fuel Corporation of Victoria. I believe it has

Speaker: NA
Text: done an excellent job in encouraging people in

Speaker: NA
Text: Victoria to convert to LPG use. Sometimes there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a shortage of inner tanks and V8 conversion

Speaker: NA
Text: kits. If we ask people to convert, we must make

Speaker: NA
Text: absolutely certain that the people who do the job

Speaker: NA
Text: have every encouragement and have every op-

Speaker: NA
Text: portunity to do it. I realise that there is a great

Speaker: NA
Text: concern to have licensing and inspection ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: rangements. Some States have just started to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: troduce stringent legislation, which we need.

Speaker: NA
Text: People at this moment are frightened because of

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the things that are being circulated

Speaker: NA
Text: within the community, to the extent that they will

Speaker: NA
Text: not convert. Safety is a prerequisite and we must

Speaker: NA
Text: make absolutely certain that the people who will

Speaker: NA
Text: do the conversions know how to do them and

Speaker: NA
Text: will do them according to the regulations.

Speaker: NA
Text: All conversion kits are presently imported. I

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned that we need to encourage the manu-

Speaker: NA
Text: facture of those kits in Australia. Why should we

Speaker: NA
Text: be dependent on other countries producing those

Speaker: NA
Text: kits? The firms involved make their normal

Speaker: NA
Text: profit. We should be producing those kits in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. I believe we could offer an alternative

Speaker: NA
Text: far cheaper than that being offered by some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the dealers throughout Australia today. Conver-

Speaker: NA
Text: sion cost has increased from $300 to $400, from

Speaker: NA
Text: $400 to $500 and I believe that it is now some-

Speaker: NA
Text: times as much as $900 a car. If we ask people to

Speaker: NA
Text: convert we must make absolutely certain they get

Speaker: NA
Text: the best possible price-no t necessarily the

Speaker: NA
Text: cheapest-an d that they get a safe, reliable job.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government should aim for that. It is also an

Speaker: NA
Text: objective of my Government to convert 14 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of all motor vehicles to LPG use. Assistance

Speaker: NA
Text: must be given to all people if they are to convert

Speaker: NA
Text: at our request. If we ask people to convert we

Speaker: NA
Text: need to make certain that they get every assist-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance. I hope that all members ofthe House will

Speaker: NA
Text: work toward that one achievement. If we ask

Speaker: NA
Text: that people accept our pricing policies we need to

Speaker: NA
Text: make certain that they get the best possible deal.

Speaker: NA
Text: I firmly believe that liquefied petroleum gas

Speaker: NA
Text: use is here to stay. I hope that most members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this House would support a high-powered cam-

Speaker: NA
Text: paign asking people to convert to LPG. This

Speaker: NA
Text: would not involve just issuing a Press statement

Speaker: NA
Text: saying that we hope that they will do this and we

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that they will do that. We need to tell the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia the benefits and the disad-

Speaker: NA
Text: vantages. I hope that with such encouragement

Speaker: NA
Text: we will be able to save our precious oil. Such a

Speaker: NA
Text: thrust would be of great advantage to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: a waiting list tralian motoring public.

Speaker: Mr JACOBI
Text: Hawker) (5.39)-On the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 3) we have a

Speaker: NA
Text: wide-ranging debate. The heart of the issue is the

Speaker: NA
Text: energy policies of this Government. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not have an energy policy; it is a mish-

Speaker: NA
Text: mash. Its import parity pricing policy on both oil

Speaker: NA
Text: and gas is nothing more than a policy structured

Speaker: NA
Text: to satisfy the Treasury and to provide its revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: input. The Government will receive $3.5 billion

Speaker: NA
Text: because of its pricing policy. If this policy is at all

Speaker: NA
Text: constructive, why is it that this Government can

Speaker: NA
Text: allocate only $9.1m of that $3.5 billion for en-

Speaker: NA
Text: ergy research? It is a shambles, hypocrisy and a

Speaker: NA
Text: disgrace. The Federal Treasury, in a recent sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to the Senate Standing Committee on

Speaker: NA
Text: National Resources, stated:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . for the sources of energy which are traded

Speaker: NA
Text: internationally-e.g . oil, natural gas, and coal-anothe r con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition is that the price be equivalent to world parity level. An

Speaker: NA
Text: import parity price consisting of the world price plus

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and other associated costs should be charged when

Speaker: NA
Text: some of Australian requirements are imported, and an

Speaker: NA
Text: export parity price less these costs when fuel is exported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied petroleum gas has recently been priced

Speaker: NA
Text: on this basis with the endorsement of the Prices

Speaker: NA
Text: Justification Tribunal, presumably on accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of the posted price for LPG at the Persian

Speaker: NA
Text: Gulf plus freight and ancillary charges to Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian ports. Is there any reason why refineries

Speaker: NA
Text: should get $252 a tonne when a cost-related

Speaker: NA
Text: price would be of the order of $100 a tonne? The

Speaker: NA
Text: PJT no longer has jurisdiction in pricing LPG on

Speaker: NA
Text: a cost-related basis. The price of LPG has been

Speaker: NA
Text: lowered by $47 a tonne, as a result of the recent

Speaker: NA
Text: decision of this Government, to be available for

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and domestic use at half the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: gasolene. This reduces the export price for Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian consumers from $252 a tonne to $205 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oil refineries produce about 350,000 tonnes

Speaker: NA
Text: per annum, of the total Australian consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: of 450,000 tonnes. The remaining 100,000 breath

Speaker: NA
Text: tonnes comes from Esso-BHP in Bass Strait. The

Speaker: NA
Text: 350,000 tonnes per annum from refineries acts

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts to only about 2 per cent of total refinery

Speaker: NA
Text: products. This sector of refinery

Speaker: NA
Text: priced at $88 a tonne in January 1979 and later

Speaker: NA
Text: at $147 a tonne. In January this year it was

Speaker: NA
Text: priced at $252 a tonne to correspond with an

Speaker: NA
Text: f.o.b. price or a c.i.f. price in Japan of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: naturally occurring LPG less freight and export

Speaker: NA
Text: charges. In other words it was priced at world

Speaker: NA
Text: export parity The arbitrary reduction of $47

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne has resulted in the gasolene price from

Speaker: NA
Text: refineries being increased by 18c a litre by the

Speaker: NA
Text: PJT. The price of LPG from refineries follows

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government directives; it is not the price

Speaker: NA
Text: termined by the PJT, although the latter

Speaker: NA
Text: been obliged to approve the increases in crude.

Speaker: NA
Text: gasolene prices as a result of the directives to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the price by $47 a tonne. For many years oil

Speaker: NA
Text: refineries supplied fuel oil to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: dustry at only a fraction of the price of imported

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel oil, such reductions being made at the

Speaker: NA
Text: pense of higher prices for gasolene, turbine fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: and other products of the refineries. Fuel oil from

Speaker: NA
Text: refineries is no longer sold at lower prices than

Speaker: NA
Text: imports.

Speaker: NA
Text: Surely today there is scope for the price

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG from refineries to be also a fraction of the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of imported LPG or its equivalent posted

Speaker: NA
Text: export price. It is important to have a fuel of

Speaker: NA
Text: importance available cheaply. As LPG constilevels

Speaker: NA
Text: tutes only 2 per cent of refinery products, the

Speaker: NA
Text: prices of all refinery products could absorb withmade

Speaker: NA
Text: out substantial increases a conceded price of,

Speaker: NA
Text: $100 a tonne for LPG, against $252 a tonne for

Speaker: NA
Text: export-a s fuel oil was sold at $20 a tonne

Speaker: NA
Text: against imported oil or parity fuel which was

Speaker: NA
Text: then $70 a tonne. The oil refineries are the

Speaker: NA
Text: to make this adjustment, not necessarily the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers of naturally occurring LPG whose receiv-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing of export parity price gives the incentives for

Speaker: NA
Text: greater oil search and, we hope, greater oil pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction from Australian crudes. The Treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: submission abounds in statements such as:

Speaker: NA
Text: The supply of energy is influenced by the rewards avail-

Speaker: NA
Text: able to energy producers and the demand for energy is

Speaker: NA
Text: affected by its price.

Speaker: NA
Text: No commendation is to be given to this Treasury

Speaker: NA
Text: attitude which preaches perfect competition

Speaker: NA
Text: amidst ideal conditions. Energy pricing is too im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant to allow theoretical economic principles

Speaker: NA
Text: to be followed in certain sections of our com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity in isolation. This is clearly the situation

Speaker: NA
Text: that has applied in Western Australia in the

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing of North West Shelf gas. In the same

Speaker: NA
Text: the Treasury also states that the receipt by

Speaker: NA
Text: natural gas producers of'artificially low prices

Speaker: NA
Text: to discourage the optimum level of recovery

Speaker: NA
Text: from existing sources and exploration for new

Speaker: NA
Text: production was sources of gas'.

Speaker: NA
Text: I suggest that this statement is incorrect. The

Speaker: NA
Text: so-called low prices were fixed on a commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: basis and explorers know very well that higher

Speaker: NA
Text: prices will be paid for any newfinds.Revenues

Speaker: NA
Text: from existing wells will be spent where the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest rate of return is attainable, including ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: a ploration spending. The present pricing of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas to Australian consumers

Speaker: NA
Text: needs a full inquiry based on the scheduling of

Speaker: NA
Text: actual and long term costs of producing LPG gas

Speaker: NA
Text: defrom Australian sources and from refineries pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: has ducing LPG from imported and indigenous

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to direct a series of questions to

Speaker: NA
Text: inthe Minister and to the Depanment. Does the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government regularly monitor the production of

Speaker: NA
Text: exoil in the Middle East? Does the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain any check on oil product cargoes from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East to ensure that cargoes initially

Speaker: NA
Text: destined for this country are not diverted to other

Speaker: NA
Text: destinations in the event of a sudden shortage

Speaker: NA
Text: developing? Does the Government monitor the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual sale price of crude oil and LPG in the

Speaker: NA
Text: of Middle East? Is the Government satisfied that

Speaker: NA
Text: the oil companies are acquiring oil at the most

Speaker: NA
Text: favourable price for Australian use? Has the

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government made any estimates of the likely

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil production by Middle East producers

Speaker: NA
Text: in the nextfiveto 10 years? Has the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: any estimates of likely future oil prices?

Speaker: NA
Text: say, What efforts has the Government made to re-

Speaker: NA
Text: duce the risk of supply interruptions by diversify-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sources of supply of crude oil for Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: use? What are the prospects of successfully diver-

Speaker: NA
Text: ones sifying sources of supply such as Venezuela,

Speaker: NA
Text: China and Nigeria? What options are being can-

Speaker: NA
Text: vassed? What is the level of oil trade on a

Speaker: NA
Text: government-to-government basis both generally

Speaker: NA
Text: and for the major exporters? Which of the major

Speaker: NA
Text: exporters are now engaged on this sort of trade?

Speaker: NA
Text: Do countries importing oil on this basis normally

Speaker: NA
Text: receive favourable treatment-fo r example, first

Speaker: NA
Text: priority in the event of supply interruptions, or

Speaker: NA
Text: better prices? What efforts has the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: made or is it making towards establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: government-to-government oil imports for

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia? What progress has been made?

Speaker: NA
Text: For the last three years this Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: maintained a stoney silence on what is becoming

Speaker: NA
Text: a very critical issue. What is the likelihood of

Speaker: NA
Text: Middle East oil producers wanting to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: the level of refined products exported at the ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: pense of crude oil? What effect would this have

Speaker: NA
Text: on the AustraUan oil refining industry and on the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of oil products in Australia? Is the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment taking any action to offset any disadvant-

Speaker: NA
Text: ages that this change may bring? I should like to

Speaker: NA
Text: make a few observations. At the moment

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia relies on its importation of crude oil,

Speaker: NA
Text: basically from the Middle East. AustraUa im-

Speaker: NA
Text: ports crude oU, from, in this order, Saudi Arabia,

Speaker: NA
Text: Kuwait, Indonesia, Iraq, the United Arab

Speaker: NA
Text: Emirates, Singapore and Bahrain. The Iranian

Speaker: NA
Text: revolution had such a dramatic impact on the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: business not only because it reduced the flow of

Speaker: NA
Text: crude oil to world markets but also because it

Speaker: NA
Text: disrupted traditional marketing patterns. Crude

Speaker: NA
Text: od supplies were gradually being shifted from in-

Speaker: NA
Text: ternational oil companies to governments of

Speaker: NA
Text: exporting countries. This will have long term im-

Speaker: NA
Text: plications for this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: In 1978 an advisory body to Japan's Ministry

Speaker: NA
Text: of International Trade and Industry-MITI -

Speaker: NA
Text: published a far-reaching report on the future di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rection of that country's oil policy. It made cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain recommendations and I think we ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: note them. They were:

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) to diversify the sources of crude imports away

Speaker: NA
Text: the Middle East towards the Pacific region;

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) increase the proportion of imports contracted

Speaker: NA
Text: through deals with

Speaker: NA
Text: governments;

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) double the share of imports developed by Japanese

Speaker: NA
Text: companies and expand exploration in Japan and

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas;

Speaker: NA
Text: (iv) broaden financial and technical co-operation with

Speaker: NA
Text: oil-exporting states;

Speaker: NA
Text: (v) enlarge the scope of the Japanese National Oil Cor-

Speaker: NA
Text: poration (JNOC);

Speaker: NA
Text: (vi) .increase oil stockpiles;

Speaker: NA
Text: (vii) consolidate the local industry; and

Speaker: NA
Text: (viii) step up usage of natural gas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fortunately for the Japanese, in the context of

Speaker: NA
Text: the critical situation in the Middle East, it had

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficient forethought at least to tackle these con-

Speaker: NA
Text: tingencies. We as a nation and the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to examine the critical and radical situ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation which is developing in the Middle East.

Speaker: NA
Text: Amongst producers, Iraq has been the chief pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of government-to-government deals for a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of years. In addition, sources within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Department of Foreign Affairs indicate clearly

Speaker: NA
Text: that Saudi Arabia, Iran, the United Arab

Speaker: NA
Text: Emirates and Kuwait are now all keen to enter

Speaker: NA
Text: government-to-government contracts. These are

Speaker: NA
Text: countries on which we rely for oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasury sources further suggest that all 13

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Organisation of Petroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: Exporting Countries now have national oil

Speaker: NA
Text: companies. All the consuming countries now

Speaker: NA
Text: have national oil companies involved in import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing oil, with the exception of two-Australi a and

Speaker: NA
Text: the United States. With exporters exerting more

Speaker: NA
Text: control over their oil, consuming countries are

Speaker: NA
Text: forced to seek more private supply arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: because the traditional oil companies can no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer meet their needs. Recently, delivery cut-

Speaker: NA
Text: backs by international companies have forced

Speaker: NA
Text: Japan, Italy, Sweden and Greece to seek oU di-

Speaker: NA
Text: rectly from the Middle East countries rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: through the oil companies. Reinforcing this trend

Speaker: NA
Text: is the producers' view that sovereign states are

Speaker: NA
Text: not bound by commercial contract. We ought to

Speaker: NA
Text: take note of that contingency. OPEC countries

Speaker: NA
Text: obviously appear to have been chiefly concerned

Speaker: NA
Text: with alleged profiteering by oil companies. That

Speaker: NA
Text: is another aspect which we ought to examine.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Iraqi oil Minister said:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . in the long run we feel that the ideal situation is to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a direct relationship between the producers and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers so that there will be no middlemen and no

Speaker: NA
Text: brokers . . .

Speaker: NA
Text: More recently Iraq's President Hussein

Speaker: NA
Text: explained bis policy. He said that Iraq should:

Speaker: NA
Text: from . . . expand sales to national oil companies rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: middlemen who are seen as exploiting oil shortages to in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease their own profits.

Speaker: NA
Text: state oil companies and producer

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition, oil producers seek contracts which

Speaker: NA
Text: involve a quid pro quo. Paul Lewis of the New

Speaker: NA
Text: York Times recently had this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Venezuela, Saudi Arabia and even such radical Arab

Speaker: NA
Text: states as Libya and Iraq prefer to sell an increasing quantity

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil to consumer governments under package deals that in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volve reciprocal Western help for their industrial plans.

Speaker: NA
Text: Kuwait's oil minister has predicted that as OPEC countries

Speaker: NA
Text: develop their own oil-based industries, they will only sell

Speaker: NA
Text: crude oil to countries which also buy their plastics and petro-

Speaker: NA
Text: chemicals. ENI -

Speaker: NA
Text: That is in Italy-

Speaker: NA
Text: has been especially aggressive in offering industrial aid as

Speaker: NA
Text: part of deals with Libya and Iraq. Even a Western oil ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: porter, Norway, is fishing for

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in return for oil sales to Germany and France.

Speaker: NA
Text: As a result of increased government to governof

Speaker: NA
Text: ment deals, large oil companies are in the process

Speaker: NA
Text: of completely phasing out crude oil trade beassess

Speaker: NA
Text: tween producers and consuming countries. ensure

Speaker: NA
Text: Honourable members should note the report of access

Speaker: NA
Text: the Economist Intelligence Unit to this effect:

Speaker: NA
Text: This change in the structure of the international

Speaker: NA
Text: in part stems from the preference of OPEC state companies

Speaker: NA
Text: for government-to-government deals.

Speaker: NA
Text: It was reported that South Korea, which used

Speaker: NA
Text: import 33 per cent of its crude oil from Kuwait

Speaker: NA
Text: through the Gulf Oil Co., wants to switch to

Speaker: NA
Text: government-to-government crude oil supply

Speaker: NA
Text: deal. What is the reason for that? Taiwan is said

Speaker: NA
Text: to be more fortunate than South Korea, having

Speaker: NA
Text: made early provisions to secure oil for 1980,

Speaker: NA
Text: relying heavily on government-to-government

Speaker: NA
Text: deals with Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. Reflecting

Speaker: NA
Text: on these trends, the Director of the Middle East

Speaker: NA
Text: Centre at St Anthony's College in Oxford had

Speaker: NA
Text: this to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: Many governments in the major consuming countries

Speaker: NA
Text: have long understood the strategic and economic sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance of petroleum. Those countries which were not

Speaker: NA
Text: parents of the major oil companies (virtually everybody

Speaker: NA
Text: except the US and for a period the UK) felt at some time or

Speaker: NA
Text: another that the majors, precisely because they could oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate in a multitude of places, could not be relied on to act

Speaker: NA
Text: always in the national interest of every individual nation.

Speaker: NA
Text: This is no criticism of the majors, just an illustration

Speaker: NA
Text: old adage that you cannot please everybody and his

Speaker: NA
Text: brothers. If petroleum is vital, then every major country

Speaker: NA
Text: be able to rely on a national operator which could: (a) pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide information and first-hand knowledge about petroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: to the government: (b) secure a nationally-owned base

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies, refining, marketing; and (c) in some cases,

Speaker: NA
Text: with the majors in the international petroleum market and

Speaker: NA
Text: affirm in that area the presence of that particular state.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of recent experiences which

Speaker: NA
Text: illustrate the advantages of State oil corportonne.

Speaker: NA
Text: ations. I will not list them at this stage but I will

Speaker: NA
Text: mention the Pertamina Corporation which

Speaker: NA
Text: affects us. Pertamina's exports for 1980 will

Speaker: NA
Text: squeezed by a decline in production and growing

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic requirements in Indonesia. As a result

Speaker: NA
Text: will entirely eliminate some small volume cusparticular

Speaker: NA
Text: tomers. However, it has agreed to continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: honour its state to state deals with Japan,

Speaker: NA
Text: Thailand and the Philippines. Any surplus oil

Speaker: NA
Text: will be sold on the spot market. The same arareas.

Speaker: NA
Text: rangement applies between Saudi Arabia and the

Speaker: NA
Text: Italy, and between Spain and Iraq.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government's policy has been totally and rising

Speaker: NA
Text: bankrupt in this area over the last four years. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: disastrous that this country has no criteria or polsee

Speaker: NA
Text: icy to meet that contingency. In the light of the will

Speaker: NA
Text: critical Middle East situation, the confrontation this

Speaker: NA
Text: between the United States and Iran, the role in

Speaker: NA
Text: part of the Soviet Union, and the critical depen-

Speaker: NA
Text: pledges of industrial invest-

Speaker: NA
Text: dence by many countries in the Western world-

Speaker: NA
Text: this country included-o n the need for continuity

Speaker: NA
Text: access to Middle East crude oil, surely this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has an obligation to co-ordinate, to

Speaker: NA
Text: and to evaluate its options in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: that at least this nation has a long term

Speaker: NA
Text: to, and continuity of, supplies of oil. That

Speaker: NA
Text: ought to be this Government's first priority. I ask

Speaker: NA
Text: oil market the Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: John MCLeay), who is sitting at the table: What

Speaker: NA
Text: will happen if supplies of crude oil from the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Middle East are cut off in the next few months?

Speaker: NA
Text: What policies have been enunciated or looked

Speaker: NA
Text: a at? If we diversified and imported oil from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Venezuelan, Nigerian or the Chinese markets,

Speaker: NA
Text: what refining capacities would we have in this

Speaker: NA
Text: country to meet those imports? I suggest that the

Speaker: NA
Text: and answer to that question is that at this time we

Speaker: NA
Text: have none. This is a disaster and a disgrace.

Speaker: NA
Text: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

Speaker: Mr MACKENZIE
Text: Calare) (8.0)-In speaking

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate on the Liquefied Petroleum Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: (Grants) Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No. 3)1 take the opportunity to make some

Speaker: NA
Text: comments about liquefied petroleum gas and in

Speaker: NA
Text: particular the effect of gas prices on those people

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australia who live outside the major metro-

Speaker: NA
Text: politan centres of population. Before I make

Speaker: NA
Text: of the those comments I should like to refer to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill 1980.

Speaker: NA
Text: must The essence of this Bill is to provide a subsidy for

Speaker: NA
Text: domestic gas consumers throughout Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: for who are currently reliant on LPG as a fuel for

Speaker: NA
Text: compete heating, cooking and hot water. The Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has decided that to afford some relief to

Speaker: NA
Text: those people in country and regional areas of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia it will provide a subsidy of some $80 a

Speaker: NA
Text: This will provide some relief from the bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: den of high gas bills. I, together with many other

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Government parties, have

Speaker: NA
Text: be received numerous representations, both verbal

Speaker: NA
Text: and in writing. Some of them highlight the des-

Speaker: NA
Text: it perate situation in which many older people in

Speaker: NA
Text: and large families find themselves as

Speaker: NA
Text: they are faced with rapidly rising gas bills, par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticularly in the colder areas of Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Needless to say, I represent many of those colder

Speaker: NA
Text: I should like to quote one such letter from

Speaker: NA
Text: many hundreds that I have received. It states:

Speaker: NA
Text: 1 am writing to you to lodge my protest against the high

Speaker: NA
Text: price of LP gas. I am a 70 year old pensioner with

Speaker: NA
Text: gas stove and water heater. For heating I use oil so you can

Speaker: NA
Text: my total misfortune and that of many of my elderly

Speaker: NA
Text: friends and also family with a lot of children who possibly

Speaker: NA
Text: not be able to afford to cook a hot meal or to keep warm

Speaker: NA
Text: winter. May I remind you sir, that the cold winter-

Speaker: NA
Text: The writer lives in the Bathurst area-

Speaker: NA
Text: Has a severe toll on us old folks. The obituary column

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper bears this sad testimony.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that letter sums up the dilemma with

Speaker: NA
Text: which many of the older people in the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity are faced because of enormous price rises

Speaker: NA
Text: for LPG. One really cannot blame them for that

Speaker: NA
Text: dilemma. It was not so long ago that the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: companies and other bodies were encouraging

Speaker: NA
Text: gas utilities to convert their coal generation gas

Speaker: NA
Text: plants to LPG. I do not believe that we can

Speaker: NA
Text: blame those gas utilities, many of which are

Speaker: NA
Text: operated by local government councils, for

Speaker: NA
Text: taking that advice. At the time it appeared to be

Speaker: NA
Text: sound advice. Consequently, many gas utilities

Speaker: NA
Text: have had to amortise losses on their out-of-date

Speaker: NA
Text: and outmoded coal gas plants to convert to LPG.

Speaker: NA
Text: Now they find themselves in a potential situation

Speaker: NA
Text: of not being able to continue using LPG. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: may even have to revert to coal-fired energy sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tems. The councils, in many cases, have borne

Speaker: NA
Text: the losses incurred over the years through cross-

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy, amongst their other revenue producing

Speaker: NA
Text: operations. I believe that some relief should be

Speaker: NA
Text: afforded to those councils for the difficulties in

Speaker: NA
Text: which they have found themselves.

Speaker: NA
Text: In addition to the $80 subsidy which is appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cable to domestic consumers and a wider range

Speaker: NA
Text: of users of LPG following the Government's re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent decision, I am pleased to see that residential

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions of a non-profit nature, such as hospi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tals and schools, will also be eligible. Inciden-

Speaker: NA
Text: tally, I have been talking to boards of manage-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of pre-schools in my area, which have

Speaker: NA
Text: found great difficulty in bearing the additional

Speaker: NA
Text: cost burden of their gas bills, particularly in

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas. This Bill provides some relief for

Speaker: NA
Text: other groups in the community who are totally

Speaker: NA
Text: dependent on LPG. The subsidy will be appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cable as from 28 March. I presume that some

Speaker: NA
Text: type of rebate or refund will be paid through the

Speaker: NA
Text: States to the gas utilities concerned. I also note

Speaker: NA
Text: that payment of the subsidy to the registered dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tributors of gas will be conditional in all cases

Speaker: NA
Text: upon the full benefit of the subsidy being passed

Speaker: NA
Text: back to the consumers. I was not aware that this

Speaker: NA
Text: was a provision in the Bill. I am pleased that it is.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the sametime,I am mindful of the difficulties

Speaker: NA
Text: that some gas utilities face. They have been

Speaker: NA
Text: operating at a loss for some time so, presumably,

Speaker: NA
Text: they have had to pass that burden on to the rate-

Speaker: NA
Text: payers. The subsidy will be applicable for three

Speaker: NA
Text: years and will cost some $60m.

Speaker: NA
Text: I have some reservations about the validity

Speaker: NA
Text: a blanket subsidy of $80 a tonne. I hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: what we are doing is not simply deferring the day

Speaker: NA
Text: of reckoning and decision for many domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers. Perhaps there will be some oppor-

Speaker: NA
Text: in any tunity for a tapering of that subsidy or we might

Speaker: NA
Text: make it quite clear that at the end of that subsidy

Speaker: NA
Text: period of three years we would expect domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers, as well as other consumers who are

Speaker: NA
Text: eligible for the subsidy, to be moving towards

Speaker: NA
Text: other energy sources. Indeed, it may be appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: priate at that time to provide taxation incentives

Speaker: NA
Text: or some other type of incentive to consumers to

Speaker: NA
Text: convert to electricity or to another form of fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: appropriate to their particular circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: The subsidy will not apply to commercial and

Speaker: NA
Text: business undertakings. I find that a little difficult

Speaker: NA
Text: to understand. I have made representations on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of some users of gas who have no real

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative to gas as a fuel for their commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: operations. One such group are orchadists who

Speaker: NA
Text: use LPG in controlled atmosphere storage of

Speaker: NA
Text: their fruit. This matter is of considerable import-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance to orchardists in my area, where controlled

Speaker: NA
Text: atmosphere storage of fruit is a very widespread

Speaker: NA
Text: and lucrative operation for orchardists. As I

Speaker: NA
Text: understand it, LPG is essential to burn oxygen

Speaker: NA
Text: out ofthe atmosphere in which the fruit is stored.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oxygen has to be removed from the gases that

Speaker: NA
Text: are used in controlling storage atmosphere to

Speaker: NA
Text: prevent oxidation of the fruit and thereby to

Speaker: NA
Text: extend the fruit Ufe very considerably.

Speaker: NA
Text: The additional measures announced by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government are welcome. In addition to the $80

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy a new price agreement has been nego-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiated with the gas producers. Not only the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rent gas producers but also, it is expected, those

Speaker: NA
Text: producers which are operating in areas where

Speaker: NA
Text: new gasfieldsmay come on stream, will abide by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's wishes that the domestic re-

Speaker: NA
Text: quirements should be realised as a priority for

Speaker: NA
Text: production. The result of these measures taken

Speaker: NA
Text: together will be a very considerable reduction in

Speaker: NA
Text: gas prices. The price of propane, for example,

Speaker: NA
Text: will drop from $252 a tonne ex-refinery to ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proximately $125 a tonne. That is at least a 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent reduction. The price of butane, under

Speaker: NA
Text: the new price negotiations and agreements be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the Government and the gas producers,

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reduced from some $290 a tonne ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: refinery to $205 a tonne as from 9 April last. This

Speaker: NA
Text: will provide very substantial relief, particularly

Speaker: NA
Text: in regional and country areas, for those people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have little immediate alternative to LPG for

Speaker: NA
Text: their heating and cooking requirements.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore I believe the new policy will have

Speaker: NA
Text: very substantial implications for the further use

Speaker: NA
Text: of of LPG as an automotive fuel. This, indeed, is

Speaker: NA
Text: most essential because we must face up to the

Speaker: NA
Text: eventual reality that the use of LPG for cooking

Speaker: NA
Text: gas and heating purposes is a complete waste of a

Speaker: NA
Text: very scarce and valuable energy resource. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must encourage the substitution of petrol by gas

Speaker: NA
Text: as much as possible if we are to maintain and

Speaker: NA
Text: guarantee our liquid fuel requirements in the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: mediate short term before other new crude oil

Speaker: NA
Text: fields are found or other new sources of synthetic

Speaker: NA
Text: liquid fuel come into widespread use.

Speaker: NA
Text: The decisions taken by the Government have

Speaker: NA
Text: the effect of maintaining a differential between

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of LPG and that of petrol of some 50

Speaker: NA
Text: per cent. Thefigures,as I understand them, are

Speaker: NA
Text: based on Melbourne prices. The price of LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: will be reduced to 16.5c per litre compared with

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of petrol in Melbourne of 33c per litre.

Speaker: NA
Text: Additionally the Government has announced an

Speaker: NA
Text: extension of tax incentives similar to those which

Speaker: NA
Text: now apply for oil fired uses to industries which

Speaker: NA
Text: convert from LPG to other sources of energy.

Speaker: NA
Text: There has been some discussion in country

Speaker: NA
Text: areas in particular that the subsidy has not been

Speaker: NA
Text: applied to business and commercial users of

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG. The new price negotiations, of course, do

Speaker: NA
Text: apply so that we must make it quite clear that

Speaker: NA
Text: even though existing business and commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: users of LPG will enjoy a 20 per cent cut in price

Speaker: NA
Text: for propane and 30 per cent cut in price for

Speaker: NA
Text: butane respectively, these businesses will not get

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the additional subsidy of $80 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne. That does have some implications for de-

Speaker: NA
Text: centralisation. Certainly it has some implications

Speaker: NA
Text: for industries that have been encouraged to

Speaker: NA
Text: move out of the major metropolitan complexes

Speaker: NA
Text: to country areas. In many cases they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged to do so with the prospect of natural

Speaker: NA
Text: gas becoming available.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we need to discuss the future for

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and for consumers of LPG and what

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation might be in a number of years.

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot simply pat ourselves on the backs too easYet

Speaker: NA
Text: ily saying that we have alleviated the problem

Speaker: NA
Text: for gas consumers without taking into account

Speaker: NA
Text: what might be the reality of the situation in the

Speaker: NA
Text: future. To this end I believe that we should be

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraging the much wider distribution of

Speaker: NA
Text: natural gas throughout Australia wherever

Speaker: NA
Text: ible and wherever practicable. In order to do

Speaker: NA
Text: this, of course, gas consumers and the utilities

Speaker: NA
Text: supplying them must realise that the

Speaker: NA
Text: wealth Government is not prepared to provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: network of feeder lines from the main natural

Speaker: NA
Text: gas pipelines at no charge. There has been an

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional distribution of natural gas to Canberra,

Speaker: NA
Text: Newcastle, Wagga Wagga, Cootamundra and so cause,

Speaker: NA
Text: on through to Albury, connecting the Cooper

Speaker: NA
Text: Basinfieldswith those of Bass Strait. It must be

Speaker: NA
Text: fully realised that the taxpayer will not foot the

Speaker: NA
Text: bill for these lines. In other words, over a number

Speaker: NA
Text: I wish to emphasise the serious consequences

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil parity pricing on a country town which de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pends for its gas supply upon LPG rather than

Speaker: NA
Text: natural gas. In the cities it is easy to convert to

Speaker: NA
Text: another energy source. In a country town, the

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of doing so can be appalling. In the cities the

Speaker: NA
Text: gas is supplied as liquefied natural gas or LNG.

Speaker: NA
Text: Certainly that is true of Sydney and of most other

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian cities. It is a different commodity and

Speaker: NA
Text: is priced differently from LPG, the 'P' in which

Speaker: NA
Text: relates to petroleum. It is liquefied petroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: gas. As a result of the import parity pricing policy

Speaker: NA
Text: an enormous increase occurred in country towns

Speaker: NA
Text: in the price of the feedstock from which town gas

Speaker: NA
Text: was derived. There was a significant increase

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly a need, because of the lack of alternatives

Speaker: NA
Text: and the high cost of conversion, for the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment to take a very sympathetic view of the im-

Speaker: NA
Text: pact on such country towns. I am glad to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: I was one of a group which managed to convince

Text: the Government that the rights of country gas

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers should be protected.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is wrong to waste a scarce and expensive re-

Text: source such as liquefied petroleum gas, which

Speaker: NA
Text: be sold at a premium price overseas and can

Speaker: NA
Text: be used domestically in premium applications. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is wrong to burn it under a saucepan or in a

Speaker: NA
Text: heater. There are other, cheaper fuels that can be

Speaker: NA
Text: used for such purposes. Electricity is one, and

Speaker: NA
Text: moveven wood is another. There is no doubt that

Speaker: NA
Text: although the basic principle-tha t it is wasteful to

Speaker: NA
Text: a scarce resource under a pot or pan holds

Speaker: NA

Text: not have available to them the alternatives that

Speaker: NA
Text: are readily available in the cities.

Speaker: NA
Text: some country towns recently converted from gas

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: many may seek a return to coal as a feedstock. I

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: gas pipeline or will switch to the use of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative energy sources to be arranged. There

Speaker: NA
Text: have found out, three years is a long tem-

Text: porary stay. However, it is a temporary situation

Speaker: NA
Text: sources to take place. There may well be no need

Speaker: NA
Text: to convert appliances. One may well be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: go back to gas made from coal. In my area

Speaker: NA
Text: detailed studies are proceeding into the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: surplus gas from coal mines. Following the

Speaker: NA
Text: Appin tragedy, in which only last year some

Speaker: NA
Text: miners were killed as a result of a gas explosion

Speaker: NA
Text: underground, the coal companies in particular

Speaker: NA
Text: have been considering very seriously trapping

Speaker: NA
Text: underground methane gas with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: reticulating it or distributing it in bottled form.

Speaker: NA
Text: least it is an alternative energy source.

Speaker: NA
Text: If we review what the subsidy has achieved it

Speaker: NA
Text: becomes very clear that it has been of major

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit to people in country towns. The average

Speaker: NA
Text: gas consumer uses about half a tonne of gas a

Speaker: NA
Text: year. The ex-refinery price of LPG has been cut

Speaker: NA
Text: from $252 a tonne to $125 a tonne, or by $127 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne. Thus, the price has been cut by more than

Speaker: NA
Text: half. If one uses half a tonne of gas a year simple

Speaker: NA
Text: mathematics would indicate that the average gas

Speaker: NA
Text: consumer will benefit by some $60 a year. That

Speaker: NA
Text: will chop some $15 a quarter from each quarterly

Speaker: NA
Text: bill. I am certain that the pensioners about whom

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: pressure at this level.
