Text: This is not the case. In fact the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced the price of a fuel which he says is valu-

Speaker: NA
Text: able and which should be rationed by $50 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne to industry, although it has charged the

Speaker: NA
Text: full price to the petrochemical industry. The

Speaker: NA
Text: petrochemical industry would be the worse for

Speaker: NA
Text: wear as a result of sales under subsidy to the rest

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australian industry.

Speaker: Mr BAUME
Text: I take a point of order. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stood that personal explanations had to relate to

Speaker: NA
Text: the facts. As I understand it, the alleged fact

Speaker: NA
Text: which the honourable member for Blaxland has

Speaker: NA
Text: put forward is untrue. I said that there was no

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Government subsidy as against a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidy to domestic consumers.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Macarthur has made his point quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clearly. I would suggest that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Blaxland confine himself to the

Speaker: NA
Text: extent to which he claims to have been

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Macarthur. I f the honourable member for La

Speaker: NA
Text: Trobe does not desist while I am speaking I will

Speaker: NA
Text: be forced to deal with him.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I will

Speaker: NA
Text: wind up on this point. The honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Macarthur claimed that the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: opposed this measure. It does not. It supports the

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidy for country people. But the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: in the first place lifted the price by 350 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: from $80 a tonne to $250 a tonne in 14 months.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member is now debating the issue.

Speaker: Mr WALLIS
Text: Grey) (9.1)-The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Macarthur ( Mr Baume) mentioned

Speaker: NA
Text: the reduction that these Bills will achieve in the

Speaker: NA
Text: price of liquefied petroleum gas.

Speaker: Mr BAILLIEU
Text: Th e idiot from Blaxland ought

Speaker: NA
Text: to go home and read up what his members are

Speaker: NA
Text: saying.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order! The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for La Trobe will restrain

Speaker: NA
Text: himself.

Speaker: Mr BAILLIEU
Text: A n idiot Uke that-

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Order!

Speaker: Mr WALLIS
Text: O f course he did not say that

Speaker: NA
Text: the government through the Prices Justification

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal allowed the price of LPG torisecon-

Speaker: NA
Text: siderably. It then took some of the weight off .the

Speaker: NA
Text: country towns with the $80 a tonne subsidy. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Macarthur made some

Speaker: NA
Text: rather scathing remarks about members on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the House. He referred to how we hate

Speaker: NA
Text: country people. As one who represents one of the

Speaker: NA
Text: large country electorates, I think I can deny his

Speaker: NA
Text: assertion. The people of Grey have continually

Speaker: NA
Text: returned me to this House despite the many pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: dictions by Liberal Party pundits about how they

Speaker: NA
Text: would get me knocked off. But the country

Speaker: NA
Text: people still stick with me and return me to this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. I think I can fairly say that T represent

Speaker: NA
Text: country people. I represent a large country elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate and not a pocket borough such as the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate of Macarthur.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Macarthur also

Speaker: NA
Text: made mention of government policy. Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment policy in the area of petrol, petroleum,

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG and energy generally has been a bit like the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's Medibank policy. There have

Speaker: NA
Text: been so many changes that any resemblance to

Speaker: NA
Text: what it was 12 months ago is pure coincidence. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think it can be said that the Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: complete lack of policy because of the changes

Speaker: NA
Text: that have taken place. The Government an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced in the Budget the year before last a cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain policy. Within a few months it changed that

Speaker: NA
Text: poUcy. The policy has since been changed again.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think we can all say that in many respects the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's poUcy is a non-policy because the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government certainly does know in which way it

Speaker: NA
Text: is heading. It would appear that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's supposed policy is oriented towards bal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ancing its Budget problems than to conserving a

Speaker: NA
Text: scarce resource and all of the other claims that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much has been said about how the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's policy hits country people. I fully agree

Speaker: NA
Text: that the present energy policy does hit country

Speaker: NA
Text: people. A colleague in the Senate the other night

Speaker: NA
Text: said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The most recent available survey of the Australian Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: of Statistics on household expenditure shows that rural

Speaker: NA
Text: households in the lowest stratification ofincome spent nearly

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 per cent of their income on petrol, oil and lubricants. For

Speaker: NA
Text: all households the comparable figure is just less than 3 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent. In other words this policy espoused by the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Countiy Party in particular penalises the lowest income

Speaker: NA
Text: countiy households three times as much as it penalises the

Speaker: NA
Text: community in general.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think that indicates what the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: policy does. The Government's decision to offer

Speaker: NA
Text: a subsidy was brought about more by fear of a

Speaker: NA
Text: reaction in the forthcoming election than it was

Speaker: NA
Text: by genuine concern for country people. People

Speaker: NA
Text: on the Government side of the House are always

Speaker: NA
Text: saying how they represent country people. But

Speaker: NA
Text: the country people are beginning to learn that it

Speaker: NA
Text: is this very Government, the very people who are

Speaker: NA
Text: supposed to represent them, that is hitting them

Speaker: NA
Text: the hardest. This is certainly the case in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's energy policy. Certainly the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's action is governed by the fact that

Speaker: NA
Text: it is in a little bit of political trouble. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Macarthur said that he had got

Speaker: NA
Text: a group together to go to the Government to try

Speaker: NA
Text: to get it to change its policy. Why? Government

Speaker: NA
Text: members realise that if the Government does not

Speaker: NA
Text: change its policy they will be in political trouble.

Speaker: NA
Text: One should look at the whole question of pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rol pricing in the country areas generally. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Garland) answered a question that I put to him a

Speaker: NA
Text: week ago in respect of the freight subsidy. I re-

Speaker: NA
Text: alise that the Minister said that the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's freight subsidy applies only to the

Speaker: NA
Text: freight costs and that the Government will pick

Speaker: NA
Text: up the tab for any costs over 0.44c a litre. We

Speaker: NA
Text: would normally assume that the country person,

Speaker: NA
Text: irrespective of where he was in Australia, would

Speaker: NA
Text: pay only 0.44c a litre more for petrol than would

Speaker: NA
Text: his city counterpart. But, of course, that is far

Speaker: NA
Text: from the fact. I was in Adelaide at Easter and

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol in that city was selling for 31,2c a litre.

Speaker: NA
Text: less than 200 miles away in Port Augusta-w e

Speaker: NA
Text: should remember the promise of 0.44c a litre-

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol is selling for 37.7c a litre. So there is a

Speaker: NA
Text: difference of 6.5c a litre which in the old

Speaker: NA
Text: measurement is the equivalent of 30c a gallon. I

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know who is responsible. I do not know

Speaker: NA
Text: whether it is the PJT or the oil companies. I

Speaker: NA
Text: would possibly blame the oil companies mostly

Speaker: NA
Text: for this because our friend the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for FrankUn ( Mr Goodluck) pointed

Speaker: NA
Text: out the way in which the oil companies have

Speaker: NA
Text: treated service station owners for quite some

Speaker: NA
Text: time. I think the oil companies can take part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the blame for this.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government has in its hands the report of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Royal Commission on Petroleum. The fourth

Speaker: NA
Text: volume of that report deals with petroleum mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: keting. There is sufficient in that fourth report to

Speaker: NA
Text: give the Government guidelines as to what

Speaker: NA
Text: should be done to make sure that not only the

Speaker: NA
Text: public but also the service station owners are

Speaker: NA
Text: given a fair go. Figures show that possibly the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest number of businessmen who go through

Speaker: NA
Text: the bankruptcy court are the service station

Speaker: NA
Text: owners. This is mainly because the oil companies

Speaker: NA
Text: tie these people up in respect of leases. There are

Speaker: NA
Text: many other bad arrangements between the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice station lessees and the oil companies. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: only do we have the Government taking us for a

Speaker: NA
Text: ride with its oil pricing policy but also the oil

Speaker: NA
Text: companies are taking us for a ride too.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is a fact that the price of petrol has increased

Speaker: NA
Text: by 150 per cent since this Government came to

Speaker: NA
Text: power. 70 per cent of that increase goes back to

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government in excise. If we look at the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures properly we will see that the actual cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: production of petrol is somewhere in the vicinity

Speaker: NA
Text: of $2 a barrel. The producer receives $6 a barrel

Speaker: NA
Text: and the Government takes, in all, about $ 19 a

Speaker: NA
Text: barrel. This Government has always claimed

Speaker: NA
Text: that it is a low tax government. But its petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing policy makes it a very high tax govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The application of the Government's oil

Speaker: NA
Text: policy has added about 23 per cent to taxation

Speaker: NA
Text: generally. It is not fair taxation. The level of tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: not determined on a sliding scale. It is not like in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come tax under which people pay according to

Speaker: NA
Text: what they earn. If a pensioner pulls into one side

Speaker: NA
Text: of a petrol pump and a millionaire pulls into the

Speaker: NA
Text: other they both pay the same. So this is a very in-

Speaker: NA
Text: equitable and unfair type of taxation. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: directed more towards balancing the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's budgetary considerations than it is to car-

Speaker: NA
Text: rying out the Government's stated policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: I mentioned that the price of LPG went from

Speaker: NA
Text: $80 a tonne to $252 a tonne over a very short

Speaker: NA
Text: But period. This legislation will reduce that amount

Speaker: NA
Text: to some consumers by $80 a tonne. Again I say

Speaker: NA
Text: that this decision was taken mainly to get some

Speaker: NA
Text: National Country Party and Liberal Party

Speaker: NA
Text: people in country electorates off the hook be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause they will certainly feel a political reaction

Speaker: NA
Text: when the election is held later this year. I under-

Speaker: NA
Text: stand that the value of the increased subsidy will

Speaker: NA
Text: be eroded if the oil companies make an appli-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation to the Prices Justification Tribunal to raise

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of petrol a little further.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would also like to make mention of one other

Speaker: NA
Text: matter in respect of the Government's petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing policy. I have mentioned that I represent

Speaker: NA
Text: a large country electorate. Aircraft play an im-

Speaker: NA
Text: portant role in such areas. Again, it is something

Speaker: NA
Text: which has a great effect on the country dweller. I

Speaker: NA
Text: refer to the great increase that has taken place in

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of avgas. In November 1975 when the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Government went out of office avgas was

Speaker: NA
Text: 15 cents a litre. In August 1978 the cost of avgas

Speaker: NA
Text: had risen to 21 cents a litre and last month it was

Speaker: NA
Text: 42 cents a litre. I worked out that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: keeping in the air a small twin-engined aircraft

Speaker: NA
Text: that I often use for charter purposes increased by

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 13 an hour. In these areas where the use of air-

Speaker: NA
Text: craft is very important country people have again

Speaker: NA
Text: been penalised by the fact that the price of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: muter operations has gone up considerably-i n

Speaker: NA
Text: most cases in the vicinity of 30 to 35 per cent-

Speaker: NA
Text: over the last six months. The cost of avgas has

Speaker: NA
Text: doubled in the last two years and it has trebled

Speaker: NA
Text: while this Government has been in power.

Speaker: NA
Text: Distillate is, of course, of great importance to

Speaker: NA
Text: our rural industries. Look how its price has

Speaker: NA
Text: moved while the Fraser Government has been in

Speaker: NA
Text: power. In November 1975 when the Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Government went out of office it was 7.7 cents a

Speaker: NA
Text: litre, in August 1978 it was 11.7 cents a litre, and

Speaker: NA
Text: in April 1980 it had increased to 24.8 cents a litre.

Speaker: NA
Text: One can imagine the effect that that has had on

Speaker: NA
Text: many of our rural industries. This affects not only

Speaker: NA
Text: our rural industries. In my electorate there are

Speaker: NA
Text: two centres, probably the largest opal mining

Speaker: NA
Text: centres in the world, Andamooka and Coober

Speaker: NA
Text: Pedy, where distillate is used by all the machin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ery. It is in great demand. The people there go

Speaker: NA
Text: through bad periods, and they are going through

Speaker: NA
Text: a bad period at present, but they have suddenly

Speaker: NA
Text: struck this great increase in the cost of their

Speaker: NA
Text: late. This means that their operations are very

Speaker: NA
Text: much more difficult.

Speaker: NA
Text: Distillate is one of the main fuels used by local

Speaker: NA
Text: government. Local governments have their

Speaker: NA
Text: problems at present. These problems have been

Speaker: NA
Text: worsened by the increase in costs of fuel. This

Speaker: NA
Text: effectflowson to ratepayers and means that less

Speaker: NA
Text: work can be done. It certainly has a great effect

Speaker: NA
Text: on people serving in local government and those

Speaker: NA
Text: officers who are responsible for administering

Speaker: NA
Text: local government. Again I say that the present

Speaker: NA
Text: government's policy is hitting hardest the

Speaker: NA
Text: country people-th e people whom the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able members on the other side of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: claim they represent. When the election is held

Speaker: NA
Text: later this year these things will be remembered. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am sure there will be a reaction, irrespective of

Speaker: NA
Text: the fact that the Government has just knocked

Speaker: NA
Text: $80 a tonne off LPG prices for certain users in

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas. Country people will make their

Speaker: NA
Text: voices well and truly heard.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Blaxland ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating) stated earlier the Labor Party's fuel

Speaker: NA
Text: policy. He indicated that we would break the

Speaker: NA
Text: present nexus between our domestic prices and

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of Arabian Ught crude. The price of pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rol would be frozen for a period of 12 months

Speaker: NA
Text: and then would be tied to movements in the price

Speaker: NA
Text: of LPG. Labor's policy would take off at least

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the strain that people are feeling today

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the petrol pricing policy and would

Speaker: NA
Text: help to make life a little easier for them. I am

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that when people examine this matter

Speaker: NA
Text: thoroughly they will realise that that policy does

Speaker: NA
Text: have something for them, and that they will re-

Speaker: NA
Text: turn the Labor Government at the end of the

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Further to that policy, there is the plan to

Speaker: NA
Text: establish a hydrocarbon corporation to carry out

Speaker: NA
Text: an oversight of the search for further petroleum

Speaker: NA
Text: reserves. It would assist where possible and give

Speaker: NA
Text: a general line as to which way our search

Speaker: NA
Text: program should be going.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the moment the program is rather willyequivalent

Speaker: NA
Text: nilly. We have a few big projects, but there seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to be no overall direction to Australia's policy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Much has been said about how, during the term

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Labor Government, the number of wells

Speaker: NA
Text: drilled dropped considerably. I am sure the

Speaker: NA
Text: figures that have been given in this House on a

Speaker: NA
Text: number of occasions by the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Blaxland and by other members indicate that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is definitely not true. In the three years that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Labor Government was in office more wells

Speaker: NA
Text: were drilled than in the first three years of office

Speaker: NA
Text: of the present Government. I understand that at

Speaker: NA
Text: present, of our two oil rigs, the Ocean Endeavour

Speaker: NA
Text: distiland the Ocean Digger, one has already gone

Speaker: NA
Text: overseas and one is ready to go overseas in the

Speaker: NA
Text: not too distant future.

Speaker: NA
Text: We are not opposing this legislation. We feel

Speaker: NA
Text: that the payment of the $80 subsidy will give at

Speaker: NA
Text: least some relief to country people. We hope that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government will be a bit more sympathetic

Speaker: NA
Text: across the board than it is now and take some of

Speaker: NA
Text: the weight off the Australian people.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Text: Mitchell) (9.16)- I will not

Speaker: NA
Text: keep the House long. Some aspects of the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas are essential to fuel con-

Speaker: NA
Text: servation and the effective and sensible use of

Speaker: NA
Text: fuels in Australia. No doubt the House is well

Speaker: NA
Text: aware that liquefied petroleum gas is sourced

Speaker: NA
Text: mainly from oil drilling facilities off-shore and it

Speaker: NA
Text: is also a by-product of the refining industry. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has many uses. It is a premium fuel because it

Speaker: NA
Text: burns cleanly, as does natural gas. It can be

Speaker: NA
Text: transported in liquid form. Before the energy

Speaker: NA
Text: crisis liquid petroleum fuels were abundant and

Speaker: NA
Text: cheap. Therefore, liquefied petroleum gas did

Speaker: NA
Text: not compete amongst them because of the higher

Speaker: NA
Text: transport and storage costs involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today, however, this situation has changed.

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied petroleum gas and oil fuels are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely valuable and important to the nation's

Speaker: NA
Text: future. The Government's policy decision is vital

Speaker: NA
Text: if we are to conserve all petroleum products. Not

Speaker: NA
Text: only have we adopted a policy of world parity

Speaker: NA
Text: pricing for oil products produced in Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: but we have also adopted a policy which locks in

Speaker: NA
Text: LP gas with the price of oil. There is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Government's decision to reduce the

Speaker: NA
Text: common maximum price for propane and

Speaker: NA
Text: butane by $205 per tonne will bring significant

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in fuel uses in Australia and provide a

Speaker: NA
Text: more balanced approach to the conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: use of fuel. Producers of Uquefied petroleum gas

Speaker: NA
Text: will also be expected to supply first the domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: market with liquefied petroleum gas. For users in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia this ensures that there will be an ongo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing reliable supply priced at half the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol products. The new prices will

Speaker: NA
Text: mean approximately a 50 per cent differential in

Speaker: NA
Text: relation to petrol for motorists in the Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: market, and a similar situation in Sydney. Also,

Speaker: NA
Text: the highest priority use for LP gas in the days to

Speaker: NA
Text: come must be for motor vehicles. The transport

Speaker: NA
Text: field offers the greatest benefit from, and the

Speaker: NA
Text: most sensible use of, liquefied petroleum gas.

Speaker: NA
Text: Future price increases in liquefied petroleum gas

Speaker: NA
Text: will be linked with percentage increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: indigenous crude oil prices, giving the capacity

Speaker: NA
Text: for motorists to purchase a fuel that is tied to a

Speaker: NA
Text: price differential of approximately 50 per cent of

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of petrol.

Speaker: NA
Text: Another by-product of the Government's de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision is that there will be an encouragement for

Speaker: NA
Text: the wasteful use of LPG in industry to be stopped

Speaker: NA
Text: and for industrial users to start to consider use

Speaker: NA
Text: alternative fuels. Therefore, it seems to me that

Speaker: NA
Text: in major areas of policy the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: found a very sensible and commendable answer

Speaker: NA
Text: to the problems created by an unexpected price

Speaker: NA
Text: rise brought about by a decision of the Prices Jus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tification Tribunal. The recent price rise in

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas was brought about be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause the Prices Justification Tribunal chose to

Speaker: NA
Text: pick a price for it which it saw as a world parity

Speaker: NA
Text: price, which was in fact a spot export market

Speaker: NA
Text: price. This was an unfortunate decision because

Speaker: NA
Text: it was not consistent with the Government's pol-

Speaker: NA
Text: icy on oil pricing. Therefore, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has moved to readjust the balance between these

Speaker: NA
Text: fuels and so gain a longer term use and a more

Speaker: NA
Text: sensible use of these products.

Speaker: NA
Text: The transport use of liquefied petroleum gas

Speaker: NA
Text: can be extended into many areas but mainly in

Speaker: NA
Text: today's world we are looking to large fleet

Speaker: NA
Text: owners and people who travel long distances to

Speaker: NA
Text: take advantage of liquefied petroleum gas. If it is

Speaker: NA
Text: possible as a nation to use our fuel correctly to

Speaker: NA
Text: enable the ledger to be balanced, we will extend

Speaker: NA
Text: the use of liquefied petroleum gas to 14 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: of total transport fuel needs. In other terms, this

Speaker: NA
Text: will mean that for every six years use by motor-

Speaker: NA
Text: ists we will save, as a nation, one year of petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: and LPG. In current terms, the implementation

Speaker: NA
Text: of this policy alone will mean that by 1985 we

Speaker: NA
Text: will have a saving of one year's supply of petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: and LPG for use. There are other factors in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: gard to liquefied petroleum gas of which this

Speaker: NA
Text: Parliament and other parliaments in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: need to be aware.

Speaker: NA
Text: The most efficient emission control system is

Speaker: NA
Text: achieved by the conversion of a motor car to

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG. At a conversion cost of $700 to $1,000 a

Speaker: NA
Text: car can be adapted to produce an emission which

Speaker: NA
Text: is so clean that there is no comparison between

Speaker: NA
Text: that emission and the emission produced by pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rol fuels. The nitrous oxides, hydrocarbons and

Speaker: NA
Text: the carbon monoxide produced by LPG are sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificantly lower than those of petrol. Also LPG

Speaker: NA
Text: contains no lead. The lead content factor in pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rol is causing concern in the community. Added

Speaker: NA
Text: to the advantage that LPG has in this respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: travelling costs are halved. The cost of LPG as

Speaker: NA
Text: presently pegged by the Government will halve

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of trips by largefleetowners. They will

Speaker: NA
Text: be able over a period to write off the cost of con-

Speaker: NA
Text: version which can be recovered by most owners

Speaker: NA
Text: in 15,000 to 20,000 kilometres.

Speaker: NA
Text: What this nation needs to do, instead of adopt-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing the crazy proposals of the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to move to the third stage of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Design Rule 27A, is to encourage large

Speaker: NA
Text: of fleet owners to adopt the use of alternate fuels

Speaker: NA
Text: such as liquefied petroleum gas and diesolene.

Speaker: NA
Text: By doing this, the motorists of the nations would

Speaker: NA
Text: be saved significant costs which in the first place

Speaker: NA
Text: would be borne by manufacturers. Motor ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicles which use petrol more efficiently will be

Speaker: NA
Text: produced. They will be allowed to tack on

Speaker: NA
Text: emission control devices which increase the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of fuel. There would be two savings to

Speaker: NA
Text: the motorist if this nation did not adopt Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Design Rule 27A. The advantage to the

Speaker: NA
Text: average motorist will be, firstly, that the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: cars will not increase because of the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: emission control additions to the car and, sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: ondly, travel each kilometre will be cheaper as

Speaker: NA
Text: fuel emission devices increase fuel use by up to

Speaker: NA
Text: 10 percent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The decision taken by the New South Wales

Speaker: NA
Text: Government appears to fly in the face of the

Speaker: NA
Text: advice given by the State Pollution Control Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission which indicates that the emission and

Speaker: NA
Text: level of pollution by motor vehicles in Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: will remain constant until 1985. The increase in

Speaker: NA
Text: pollution in Sydney is caused by hydrocarbons

Speaker: NA
Text: emitted from other sources such as manufactur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing sources. They will be responsible for an in-

Speaker: NA
Text: crease of 122 per cent in the level of hydro-

Speaker: NA
Text: carbons in the Sydney atmosphere. Therefore, I

Speaker: NA
Text: commend these proposals to the House because

Speaker: NA
Text: they provide the motorist with a cheaper source

Speaker: NA
Text: of fuel which is pollution-free. They will be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: by the community at large to be sensible in

Speaker: NA
Text: extending the use of oil products. I commend this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to the House. I commend the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment for its decisions because I think they are

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the most sensible decisions on fuel usage

Speaker: NA
Text: and fuel conservation.

Speaker: Mr JOHN BROWN
Text: Parramatta) (9.26)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to spend a few minutes talking about the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill 1980 and

Speaker: NA
Text: the Excise TariffAmendment Bill (No. 3) 1980.

Speaker: NA
Text: The debate on the legislation has been wide

Speaker: NA
Text: ranging. I represent an outer western suburbs

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate in Sydney. In view of what other

Speaker: NA
Text: speakers have said in this debate I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable for me to spend a few moments deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing with petrol pricing. I think that the taxpayers

Speaker: NA
Text: of Australia, particularly the people in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate, should bear in mind that for seven years

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians paid $2 a barrel for Bass Strait oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: Most of that oil was discovered in 1968 and cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly all of it was discovered before 1975. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian public is now paying in excess of $25

Speaker: NA
Text: a barrel for the same indigenous Australian oil.

Speaker: NA
Text: The differential-tha t is, 83 per cent of the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of the oil-goe s to the Australian Government by

Speaker: NA
Text: way of petrol tax.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that when Australians fill their petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: tanks- I might add that 90 per cent of petrol and

Speaker: NA
Text: motor distillate used in Australia comes from in-

Speaker: NA
Text: digenous sources and 70 per cent of our oil re-

Speaker: NA
Text: serves comes from indigenous sources-an d pay

Speaker: NA
Text: the enormous price that they are paying for pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: rol at the moment they will realise that that price

Speaker: NA
Text: has been set by the Fraser Government, not as

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government wants people to believe by

Speaker: NA
Text: some cartel of mysterious Arabs who sit at

Speaker: NA
Text: different venues and decide what we will pay for

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol. The price for Australian petrol, to the

Speaker: NA
Text: great cost to the Australian people, is set by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Government. I think it is time that the

Speaker: NA
Text: deception that has been promulgated,

Speaker: NA
Text: expounded and reinforced by this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was unmasked. The Government has said that

Speaker: NA
Text: the high price of Australian petrol is due to an

Speaker: NA
Text: Arab decision. It is not. It is the result of

Speaker: NA
Text: scious decision by this Government to use petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: as a means of raising revenue. There is no doubt

Speaker: NA
Text: that this Government has an insatiable thirst for

Speaker: NA
Text: revenue. It has used that petrol tax derived rev-

Speaker: NA
Text: enue to reduce its domestic deficit to the level

Speaker: NA
Text: which it now tells us is a measure of its great

Speaker: NA
Text: efficiency as an economic manager. We on this

Speaker: NA
Text: side ofthe House know that this is not the case. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think that at this stage the Australian public

Speaker: NA
Text: knows that that is not the case.

Speaker: NA
Text: I wonder what would have happened to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's domestic deficit if the Arabs had

Speaker: NA
Text: not decided a couple of years ago to increase

Speaker: NA
Text: their oil prices to the current level. What a great

Speaker: NA
Text: windfall this has been for the Government. This

Speaker: NA
Text: is a Government of opportunistic buccaneers

Speaker: NA
Text: who are prepared to soak the working class-th

Speaker: NA
Text: people who have to put some petrol in their

Speaker: NA
Text: to get to work-i n order to fuel the economy, in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to reduce the deficit to the level that

Speaker: NA
Text: Government now trumpets as being a major course

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for its claim that it is a great economic

Speaker: NA
Text: manager.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this Government talks about reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the deficit, it is in fact running down

Speaker: NA
Text: asset to achieve income. By definition, that in-

Speaker: NA
Text: come will cease because it is a tax on pre-1975

Speaker: NA
Text: oil. When this oil runs out, as eventually it must

Speaker: NA
Text: in the mid 1980s, what will the Government do

Speaker: NA
Text: to replace the revenue that it has gained in this

Speaker: NA
Text: windfall fashion from the increase that the Arabs

Speaker: NA
Text: made in prices of their oil? I wonder what will

Speaker: NA
Text: happen when the $3,000m windfall that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has been able to expropriate from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian public expires in the mid-1980s?

Speaker: NA
Text: What will the Government do then to meet the

Speaker: NA
Text: vacuum in government funding to which it has

Speaker: NA
Text: become accustomed? There is no way that this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government or any government which is in

Speaker: NA
Text: power in the mid-1980s will be able to slow

Speaker: NA
Text: down the express train nature of government

Speaker: NA
Text: spending. The Government has become accus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tomed to this $3,000m of excess revenue every

Speaker: NA
Text: year. There is no way in the world that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government will find a way to replace that rev-

Speaker: NA
Text: enue when it expires.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Government's misguided pricing policy

Speaker: NA
Text: imposes a very heavy burden on the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: public. The Government has added 3 per cent to

Speaker: NA
Text: the national inflation figure just by virtue of its

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol pricing policies. These days to fill up the

Speaker: NA
Text: petrol tank of an ordinary, average family car

Speaker: NA
Text: costs $25. Because of the lack of public transport

Speaker: NA
Text: and because of the urban spread which is Syd-

Speaker: NA
Text: ney, there is no way in the world that the average

Speaker: NA
Text: a conworker in my electorate in the western area of

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney can get to work without driving his car. I

Speaker: NA
Text: know of many people in my electorate who have

Speaker: NA
Text: to fill up their petrol tanks twice a week just to

Speaker: NA
Text: get to work to earn the money that they need to

Speaker: NA
Text: feed their families. They are looking at $50 a

Speaker: NA
Text: week just to get to work-an d they do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: an alternative.

Speaker: NA
Text: Furthermore there is no way in the world that

Speaker: NA
Text: those people can get any relief under the income

Speaker: NA
Text: tax laws as they exist. We all know that the

Speaker: NA
Text: middle class, the company executive and the self-

Speaker: NA
Text: employed have a lurk to get out of paying the

Speaker: NA
Text: increased petrol prices. They are either leasing a

Speaker: NA
Text: car and claiming those charges as a taxation de-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction or driving a company car, a perk pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: e vided by their corporation. The ordinary work-

Speaker: NA
Text: cars ing man, the man earning $7,000, $8,000 or

Speaker: NA
Text: $10,000 a year is stuck with the fact that he is up

Speaker: NA
Text: the for $50 a week for his petrol and he has no re-

Speaker: NA
Text: to any reduction in his taxation. The prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem is that this Government is getting over

Speaker: NA
Text: $3,000m a year from petrol taxes. Because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: lack of public transport in my area people are

Speaker: NA
Text: a national stuck with high petrol bills.

Speaker: NA
Text: I would have thought that if this were a moral

Speaker: NA
Text: government at least it would have done some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing about providing funds to the State govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments to improve the standard of public

Speaker: NA
Text: transport in the large urban areas. What do we

Speaker: NA
Text: find when we examine the facts? The facts are

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the years of this Government's reign

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth receipts have gone up by 45 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent but payments to the States for all purposes

Speaker: NA
Text: have increased by only 32 per cent. It is very ob-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious that the States do not have the money to

Speaker: NA
Text: improve the public transport system. If this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government were sincere in claiming, as it does,

Speaker: NA
Text: that its petrol pricing policy is an energy conser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation policy designed to reduce the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption of Australian fuel, surely good com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mercial sense would indicate that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government should be improving public

Speaker: NA
Text: transport with Commonwealth funds in order to

Speaker: NA
Text: get people out of their motor cars. That is not the

Speaker: NA
Text: case. This Government has made every petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: pump an agent for the Taxation Office. There is

Speaker: NA
Text: no way in the world that any honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member opposite, including the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Franklin ( Mr Goodluck), who used

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a service station proprietor, could deny that

Speaker: NA
Text: that is a fact.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government tries to market its oil pricing

Speaker: NA
Text: policy as an energy policy but it is not an energy

Speaker: NA
Text: policy; it is a tax policy. Nobody can deny that.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government argues that its pricing policy is

Speaker: NA
Text: needed to encourage oil exploration. That is not

Speaker: NA
Text: the case, as has been explained by the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Blaxland ( Mr Keating) earlier

Speaker: NA
Text: in this debate. Since the Fraser Government

Speaker: NA
Text: came into power the amount of exploration in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia has decreased. The statistics prove it.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year Canada is sinking something like 3,000

Speaker: NA
Text: exploratory wells. In Australia it is a much

Speaker: NA
Text: smallerfigure-about 100. Honourable members

Speaker: NA
Text: opposite should not try to tell us that

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's oil pricing policy is designed to improve

Speaker: NA
Text: exploration in Australia. Thefiguresshow other-

Speaker: NA
Text: wise. Since this Government came into power the

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of exploration investment has decreased

Speaker: NA
Text: remarkably. So has its funding for public

Speaker: NA
Text: transport. That is very obvious.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Fraser Government promised lower tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation and smaller government, but it is the

Speaker: NA
Text: highest taxing government since Federation.

Speaker: NA
Text: Government revenue from petrol in the present

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year is $3,400m. This represents

Speaker: NA
Text: cent of total personal income tax revenue for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and more than the total receipts

Speaker: NA
Text: from company tax. Total government revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: figures show that this is the highest taxing

Speaker: NA
Text: government in Australian history. Nobody

Speaker: NA
Text: should think otherwise.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will not go on for much longer, Mr Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, because I know that you want to wind

Speaker: NA
Text: up the debate. Just allow me to tell you that i f

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government was really sincere about

Speaker: NA
Text: introducing its pricing policy to increase explo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ration it has failed dismally. On the other hand, if

Speaker: NA
Text: it tries to tell us and the Australian public, as it

Speaker: NA
Text: does that its policy is dedicated towards reducing

Speaker: NA
Text: the consumption of fuel in Australia, it has failed

Speaker: NA
Text: to a grand degree in that area also. Petrol con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumption in Australia keeps going up. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Government has done nothing in the form of tax

Speaker: NA
Text: relief to improve the situation. For instance, it

Speaker: NA
Text: has not offered incentives to Australians to buy

Speaker: NA
Text: cars with less power as has been done in

Speaker: NA
Text: America. No inducement has been given to the

Speaker: NA
Text: motor companies to produce motors with a

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller capacity and a lower fuel consumption

Speaker: NA
Text: rate. There has been no improvement in funds

Speaker: NA
Text: for public transport. Certainly there has been no

Speaker: NA
Text: inducement for people to get out of their cars and

Speaker: NA
Text: to use public transport. This Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: failed dismally on all counts.

Speaker: NA
Text: The public of Australia must realise that no

Speaker: NA
Text: matter what reason this Government puts for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward it is dedicated to its petrol pricing policy in

Speaker: NA
Text: order to increase government revenue. It has an

Speaker: NA
Text: insatiable appetite. Honourable members on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition side of the House recognise this as

Speaker: NA
Text: being the case. Every week complaints stream

Speaker: NA
Text: into my office from people in my electorate who

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to drive their motor cars to work and

Speaker: NA
Text: are forced to find $50 a week in order to get to

Speaker: NA
Text: work. The complaints are increasing. When

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable members opposite go to the ballot

Speaker: NA
Text: box in December-a s I presume they will-thi s

Speaker: NA
Text: will show up in the results. Let there be no mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: take. The Government's petrol pricing policy is a

Speaker: NA
Text: the Governtax policy, not an energy policy.

Speaker: Mr GARLAND
Text: Curtin-Minister for Business

Speaker: NA
Text: and Consumer Affairs) (9.37)-in reply-Th e

Speaker: NA
Text: attitudes expressed by the Australian Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party in this debate are very strange indeed. Lis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tening to honourable members opposite one can-

Speaker: NA
Text: not help being struck by the way in which they

Speaker: NA
Text: have all differed from one another. With respect,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Hughes ( Mr Les

Speaker: NA
Text: Johnson) really spoke a lot of nonsense. Appar-

Speaker: NA
Text: The ently he was unaware that what he was saying

Speaker: NA
Text: was in conflict to a very large degree with the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: 30 per marks made by the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Blaxland ( Mr Keating), who is the official Labor

Speaker: NA
Text: Party spokesman on energy matters in this

Speaker: NA
Text: chamber. The honourable member for Grey ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Wallis) put some emphasis on what he saw as

Speaker: NA
Text: the unfairness of the type of tax involved. I point

Speaker: NA
Text: out that it is the same type of tax-tha t is equal

Speaker: NA
Text: incidence-tha t applied when the Labor Party

Speaker: NA
Text: was in government. A whole lot of other taxes

Speaker: NA
Text: applied by State governments, including those of

Speaker: NA
Text: his own political persuasion-bu s fares and all

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of other charges-ar e equal to the quantity.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is no use honourable members expecting every

Speaker: NA
Text: tax that is raised to be progressive. That is unreal.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has an oil and oil products

Speaker: NA
Text: parity pricing policy. I think the reason for that

Speaker: NA
Text: policy bears repeating briefly. There is a scarcity

Speaker: NA
Text: of oil in the world, and that scarcity will not go

Speaker: NA
Text: away. Prices around the world are rising. We in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia must take notice of that situation. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: less we discover more oil, and at present many

Speaker: NA
Text: companies are looking for it, the day will come in

Speaker: NA
Text: the next decade- I hope it does not-whe n our

Speaker: NA
Text: present oil supplies run out. We will then have to

Speaker: NA
Text: import all our oil. There should be no mistaking

Speaker: NA
Text: that then we will be paying full prices for it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Oil has a value and liquefied petroleum gas

Speaker: NA
Text: has a value. The Liquefied Petroleum Gas

Speaker: NA
Text: (Grants) Bill and the Excise TariffAmendment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill (No. 3) relate principally to liquefied pet-

Speaker: NA
Text: roleum gas. LPG has a value in the world. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian economy has to adjust to that value,

Speaker: NA
Text: as do other economies throughout the world. We

Speaker: NA
Text: must conserve all the oil we can and convert to

Speaker: NA
Text: other forms of energy. Fortunately Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: many alternative energy sources. We must make

Speaker: NA
Text: sure that the effect is felt throughout the econ-

Speaker: NA
Text: omy just as it is overseas. Of course, honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members know that in this country we pay less

Speaker: NA
Text: by a margin for motor spirit, petrol and other oils

Speaker: NA
Text: than is paid in almost any other country. Never-

Speaker: NA
Text: theless, we have seen tremendous pricerisesin

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia. They have occurred as a consequence

Speaker: NA
Text: of tremendous rises overseas. We have a present

Speaker: NA
Text: position of a shortage of oil and a future position

Speaker: NA
Text: of a shortage of liquefied petroleum gas.

Speaker: NA
Text: We had a very rapid rise in the price of

Speaker: NA
Text: liquefied petroleum gas as from December of

Speaker: NA
Text: last year-onl y a few months ago. Movements in

Speaker: NA
Text: the world price were as follows: It was $147 a

Speaker: NA
Text: tonne last December and it rose to $252 a tonne

Speaker: NA
Text: in January. The Government, recognising that

Speaker: NA
Text: that was too sharp arisefor any reasonable con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cern to adjust to, has come up with a package of

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals to allow for discounting for all con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers except the petrochemical industry, from

Speaker: NA
Text: which there is a very rapid rise in demand. Con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers will receive a reduction in price from this

Speaker: NA
Text: package of proposals. What we have put in place

Speaker: NA
Text: of the price structure following this sharp

Speaker: NA
Text: increase-i t was announced by my colleague the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister for National Development and Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: (Senator Carrick) about two weeks ago-i s a

Speaker: NA
Text: three tier structure. Firstly, there will be a sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: sidy of $80 a tonne, principally for those con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers in country areas and those whose use of it

Speaker: NA
Text: is of a private nature. That subsidy will be retro-

Speaker: NA
Text: spective to 28 March. That is provided for in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Liquefied Petroleum Gas (Grants) Bill. It is quite

Speaker: NA
Text: clear to anyone who knows what happens in the

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas of Australia that the many gas pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducing companies which supplied the reticulated

Speaker: NA
Text: system that applies in Victoria and elsewhere

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot take the sort of rapid rise that we saw take

Speaker: NA
Text: place between December and January last. Ordi-

Speaker: NA
Text: nary households and non-profit organisations-

Speaker: NA
Text: hospitals, schools and others-wil l in effect pay

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 125 a tonne for LPG. Those industrial concerns

Speaker: NA
Text: and those who own motor vehicles which use

Speaker: NA
Text: LPG will pay $205 a tonne and the petrochemi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal industry will pay a negotiatedfigurebased on

Speaker: NA
Text: the world parity export price of LPG. That is the

Speaker: NA
Text: three tier structure. It has been brought forward

Speaker: NA
Text: for several reasons. Firstly, as I have said, the

Speaker: NA
Text: commercialfirms,households and non-profit or-

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisations need time to adjust. In this debate we

Speaker: NA
Text: have heard many criticisms of this Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: making a reduction in price in spite of the

Speaker: NA
Text: scarcity of liquid fuel. What the persons making

Speaker: NA
Text: those criticisms failed to say was that an enor-

Speaker: NA
Text: mous price rise- a larger one-too k place in

Speaker: NA
Text: January of this year. The matter must be looked

Speaker: NA
Text: at in terms of the price in December last. I repeat

Speaker: NA
Text: that it rose from $147 a tonne to $252 a tonne.

Speaker: NA
Text: We have now reduced the price to commercial

Speaker: NA
Text: firms to $205 a tonne and ordinary household

Speaker: NA
Text: consumers, hospitals and the like will pay even

Speaker: NA
Text: less than that. They will pay $125 a tonne-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: is to say, $80 a tonne less. I would have thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that that was a rational policy. It is a policy which

Speaker: NA
Text: envisages that there is a limit to therisethat can

Speaker: NA
Text: be stood by consumers in ordinary households

Speaker: NA
Text: and in commercial enterprises. Even if the world

Speaker: NA
Text: price rises very rapidly we cannot follow just as

Speaker: NA
Text: rapidly with hugerises.After all, we are still left

Speaker: NA
Text: with commercial enterprises being faced with a

Speaker: NA
Text: rise in price from $147 a tonne to $205 a tonne.

Speaker: NA
Text: So this package has been put in place.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member for Blaxland ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Keating) made a speech last week. I was greatly

Speaker: NA
Text: intrigued by it. I was sitting at the table at the

Speaker: NA
Text: time. He was speaking in a debate on another

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill but his remarks concerned the same matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: He made some interesting comments to which I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to refer briefly. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: What the Government has done now is to change com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely the basis of its policy. There were two matters in ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion. The first relates to the narrowing gap between the price

Speaker: NA
Text: nf petrol and LPG. That gap . . . is about 13c-

Speaker: NA
Text: So he continued. He went on to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: . . . the true import parity price for oil which we all

Speaker: NA
Text: know is about $30 a barrel. But at the moment we are

Speaker: NA
Text: ing our refineries $24.77 a barrel.

Speaker: NA
Text: He is recorded on the next page of Hansard-

Speaker: NA
Text: page 1895-a s having said:

Speaker: NA
Text: There was a need for the Government to change its policy

Speaker: NA
Text: in respect of those people in the country who were

Speaker: NA
Text: to a Liquefied petroleum gas supply.

Speaker: NA
Text: Later he said:

Speaker: NA
Text: But what the Government did then was to reduce com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pletely and dramatically the whole pricing structure

Speaker: NA
Text: Arbitrarily it picked on a price of $205 per tonne and

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced the per tonne price of"butane from $252 to $205 and

Speaker: NA
Text: propane from $290 to $205.

Speaker: NA
Text: I make two points. I have just referred to the

Speaker: NA
Text: one; namely, that this reduction is to take place

Speaker: NA
Text: few weeks after an enormous increase was

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced. What we are effecting is a relative

Speaker: NA
Text: duction to offset the enormous increase that has

Speaker: NA
Text: taken place so far.

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Text: Th e Government's typical to

Speaker: NA
Text: yo-yo policy.

Speaker: Mr GARLAND
Text: Well , of course, the world

Speaker: NA
Text: price is a yo-yo. That is the way of the world

Speaker: NA
Text: which we live. The second point, which I think is

Text: scheme. Certainly, we would like to see some

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: charg- rol. In ideal conditions we could have up to 10

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: saving in motor spirit. Those people who wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: hooked up would be mainly fleet owners-wil l be

Speaker: NA
Text: encouraged to do so because, under this policy,

Speaker: NA
Text: at $205 a tonne than they would pay if LPG were

Speaker: NA
Text: of LPG. sold at the world price which is approximately

Speaker: NA
Text: $252 a tonne at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has achieved a gap between

Speaker: NA
Text: the price of LPG and the price of petrol. That

Speaker: NA
Text: first gap means that if one does a reasonable

Speaker: NA
Text: a mileage- I refer mainly to fleet owners-ther e

Speaker: NA
Text: will be a saving. As I understand it, vehicles

Text: remanufactured for the use of LPG and not need-

Text: ing conversion will be manufactured in Australia

Text: next year. That will allow more and more people

Speaker: NA
Text: use LPG and stop the use of oil in this country.

Speaker: NA
Text: ductions to discourage people from using oil and

Speaker: NA
Text: in LPG and encourage them to use electricity and

Speaker: NA
Text: other fuels. That is the objective of these Bills.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the part is to give the Government time.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: scarce. In the case of LPG, that energy source

Text: fields and before very long will be consuming the

Speaker: NA

Text: Administrative Services)- Mr Speaker, may I

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Text: Prospect) (10.7)-We are

Speaker: NA
Text: debating two Bills tonight. The more important

Speaker: NA
Text: is the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will explain very quickly to the House the

Speaker: NA
Text: reason for this legislation. The Australian Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: Thomson. D. S.

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Police Act 1979 established the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police Force which was basically a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: bination of the former Australian Capital Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory Police Force and the Commonwealth Police

Speaker: NA
Text: NOES Force. The Act gave to members of those two

Speaker: NA
Text: forces legal preferences for any appointment to

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones. Barry

Speaker: NA
Text: Jones. Charles

Speaker: NA
Text: the ranks in the Australian Federal Police Force

Speaker: NA
Text: ahead of any person joining from outside the

Speaker: NA
Text: Kerin. J.C.

Speaker: NA
Text: Klugman, R. E.

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police Force, particularly to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of the Force which was performing gen-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral police functions. It is important to realise

Speaker: NA
Text: that basically the Federal Police Force consists

Speaker: NA
Text: of two components: A general duty component

Speaker: NA
Text: Wallis. L. G.

Speaker: NA
Text: West. S.J.

Speaker: NA
Text: and a protective services component.

Speaker: NA
Text: After the establishment of the Australian Fed-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Police Force last year, on 6 November 1979

Speaker: NA
Text: the Deputy Prime Minister ( Mr Anthony) an-

Speaker: NA
Text: nounced that the Government had adopted a

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendation of the interim report of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Innes, V. E. Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron. Clyde

Speaker: NA
Text: Drugs. That recommendation was to disband the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Narcotics Bureau and to transfer the

Speaker: NA
Text: functions of the Bureau to the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police. The Government also announced that it

Speaker: NA
Text: would transfer those members of the Narcotics

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau whom the Commissioner of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading tralian Federal Police considered to be suitable

Speaker: NA
Text: and qualified for appointment as police officers

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Australian Federal Police Force. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: the background of what happened. To appoint

Speaker: NA
Text: those people to the Federal Police Force, it is

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to amend legal preferences which were

Speaker: NA
Text: established in the original Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading The Opposition opposes this legislation and I

Speaker: NA
Text: now formally move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stituting the following words:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'as the present arrangements for the policing of major

Speaker: NA
Text: drug trafficking legislation are unsatisfactory and

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed arrangements for the transfer to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police of former officers ofthe Narcotics Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: will produce anomalies and unfairness, the bill be with-

Speaker: NA
Text: drawn and re-drafted to provide for:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) the creation of a further major component of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Police to be responsible for the

Speaker: NA
Text: policing of Federal and State drug trafficking legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation, such component to be accountable to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Police Commissioner, and through

Speaker: NA
Text: him to the Minister and the Parliament;

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) the proposed component to comprise A.F.P. officers,

Speaker: NA
Text: together with a significant number of experienced

Speaker: NA
Text: officers seconded from State Police Forces, such State

Speaker: NA
Text: officers to continue to operate as far as possible in

Speaker: NA
Text: their home States, and not to be prejudiced in their

Speaker: NA
Text: career advancement by accepting such secondment,

Speaker: NA
Text: and

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) an arrangement whereby former members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Narcotics Bureau who seek transfer to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police, and who are considered qualified in

Speaker: NA
Text: this respect by the Commissioner, may be appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: as officers or non-commissioned officers of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed new narcotics component'.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are a number of reasons for my moving

Speaker: NA
Text: that amendment. The first is that it seems unfair

Speaker: NA
Text: to us that within six months of establishing

Speaker: NA
Text: preference for the members of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police, that legal preference is considerwill

Speaker: NA
Text: ably watered down by the movement of 84 or 86

Speaker: NA
Text: officers into the Australian Federal Police Force

Speaker: NA
Text: at different levels. The only evidence I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the levels at which they will be moved in is

Speaker: NA
Text: article in the Canberra Times of 4 April 1980.

Speaker: NA
Text: The article refers to 86 former Bureau members.

Speaker: NA
Text: It states:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is expected that 86 former bureau agents will be offered

Speaker: NA
Text: ranks in the force; 36 at constable level, 42 at sergeant and

Speaker: NA
Text: seven at inspector level. One former agent is expected

Speaker: NA
Text: given the rank of superintendent or chief superintendent.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposal is that people who have previously

Speaker: NA
Text: been employed in the Federal Narcotics Bureau

Speaker: NA
Text: will be moved sideways-o r laterally-int o the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police Force on the basis of their salary.

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, a public servant of a particular

Speaker: NA
Text: grade receiving, for example, about $18,000

Speaker: NA
Text: nually, the salary of an inspector in the Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police Force, would be transferred into the Fedinvestigation

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Police Force at inspector level. I think all

Speaker: NA
Text: us would agree that whilst that person

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified to be an inspector and to hold the pos-

Speaker: NA
Text: ition of inspector in regard to narcotics investiby They

Speaker: NA
Text: gations, he does not necessarily have the training

Speaker: NA
Text: to be a general inspector in the Australian Fedpresent,

Speaker: NA
Text: eral Police. One can easily understand the were

Speaker: NA
Text: complaint-an d I would hope, agree with it-b y cotics

Speaker: NA
Text: present members of the Australian Federal trafficking.

Speaker: NA
Text: Pohce that people from an outside bureau are

Speaker: NA
Text: being admitted laterally to the general duties

Speaker: NA
Text: component of the Australian Federal Police

Speaker: NA
Text: Force at a level for which they are not necessarly

Speaker: NA
Text: qualified. At present, a person serving in the

Speaker: NA
Text: tective services component of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police Force can cross over to the genviously,

Speaker: NA
Text: eral duties section only by way of examination,

Speaker: NA
Text: even though he may have had training in a State

Speaker: NA
Text: police force. But this examination will not

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary for people from the Narcotics Bureau.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I understand it from members of the AusHall

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Federal Police, they would like what

Speaker: NA
Text: called a brevet rank for such people who will

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in narcotics work.

Speaker: NA
Text: I will be interested to hear the arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister for Administrative Services ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: John MCLeay) or other Government members

Text: against establishing a third component for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Federal Police. One of the significant arguments

Speaker: NA
Text: -an d I think it would be silly to ignore it

Speaker: NA
Text: we are debating this legislation tonight-relate s

Speaker: NA
Text: to the qualifications that people of the old Nar-

Text: cotics Bureau have. After all, the Federal Nar-

Text: cotics Bureau was not dissolved because it had

Speaker: NA

Text: an tainly suggest that some of them are not appro-

Speaker: NA
Text: In July 1979 following allegations of leakages of infor-

Text: mation from an unknown officer of the Sydney office of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Narcotics Bureau, the Government decided it was appropri-

Text: trol, lines of responsibility to the Permanent Head and the

Speaker: NA

Text: lency the Governor-General, the Prime Minister ( Mr Mal-

Text: colm Fraser) sought from the Australian Royal Commission

Text: of Inquiry into Drugs an interim repon on those issues. The

Speaker: NA

Text: terim report was presented to the House because

Text: significant scale.

Speaker: NA
Text: alleThe interim report of the Royal Commissioner

Speaker: NA
Text: There is considerable and increasing distrust of the Nar-

Text: Bureau among other law enforcement bodies. For

Speaker: NA
Text: years relationships between the Narcotics Bureau and

Text: ships between the Narcotics Bureau and State police are bad

Text: in many places.

Speaker: NA

Text: were bad. Members of the law enforcement

Speaker: NA
Text: relating to the Narcotics Bu-

Speaker: NA
Text: agencies did not trust the Bureau, yet now we are

Speaker: NA
Text: The report was highly critical of Mr Harvey

Speaker: NA
Text: Bates. We all recall when Mr Harvey Bates first

Text: inBureau and then was asked by the Minister for

Text: ribly pleased that Mr Bates had done so. Within

Speaker: NA
Text: the the Government's face. Amongst other things,

Speaker: NA
Text: staff of the Nar Mr Justice Williams said:

Speaker: NA
Text: of transferring to the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: The Narcotics Bureau is not a highly efficient enforcement

Text: agency.

Speaker: NA
Text: Increases in arrests, prosecutions and seizures of drugs

Speaker: NA
Text: have often occurred with little or no Narcotics Bureau

Text: assistance.

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the largest seizures in recent years attributed in

Speaker: NA

Text: for efficiency is lower than

Speaker: NA
Text: Police force. He said also that the training of

Text: Narcotics Bureau officers leaves much to be

Text: in August and September of last year state that

Text: with us for a considerable period. It is a major

Speaker: NA
Text: problem not only in this country but also in most

Text: others.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: Dr KLUGMAN
Text: Prospect) (10.31)-This

Speaker: NA
Text: chap was telling me about what was going on in

Speaker: NA
Text: East German medicine. He was emphasising its

Speaker: NA
Text: inferiority. I think honourable members will

Speaker: NA
Text: that I am not a great supporter of the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of regime that exists in the German Democratic

Speaker: NA
Text: Republic, but I started to feel sorry for him. I

Speaker: NA
Text: said: 'You will probably have less of a problem

Speaker: NA
Text: with car accidents because you have fewer cars'.

Speaker: NA
Text: He said: 'People get drunk and go faster because

Speaker: NA
Text: there are fewer cars on the road. So we finish up

Speaker: NA
Text: with just as many accidents'. So I tried some-

Speaker: NA
Text: thing else. I said to him: 'What about the drug

Speaker: NA
Text: problem? I suppose that you have fewer prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lems with drugs'. He said: 'That is true. Many of

Speaker: NA
Text: us believe that this is due to the new socio-

Speaker: NA
Text: economic conditions in this country, but others

Speaker: NA
Text: have suggested that it is due to the fact that the

Speaker: NA
Text: traffickers will not accept our currency'. I think

Speaker: NA
Text: that is undoubtedly the reason that East Ger-

Speaker: NA
Text: many has less of a drug problem than many

Speaker: NA
Text: other countries. When one goes to a money

Speaker: NA
Text: exchange in West Berlin one can get 4.3 East

Speaker: NA
Text: German marks for every West German mark.

Speaker: NA
Text: The point I am emphasising is that the drug

Speaker: NA
Text: problem will continue for as long as there is

Speaker: NA
Text: conmoney in it. There will be people prepared to

Speaker: NA
Text: take very highrisksto make huge profits. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: previously made the point in this House, in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: to what we are talking about tonight, that

Speaker: NA
Text: to in my view some of the propaganda and pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: licity associated with the arrests of drug

Speaker: NA
Text: do traffickers are counterproductive. Again and

Speaker: NA
Text: when news of such arrests is released to the

Speaker: NA
Text: media it is emphasised that $lm, $2m or similar

Speaker: NA
Text: huge amounts is involved. My view is that those

Speaker: NA
Text: figures are probably exaggerated in any case and

Speaker: NA
Text: even if they are not, it would be better i f

Speaker: NA
Text: they were not emphasised. If people continue to

Speaker: NA
Text: be told that such huge amounts can be made out

Speaker: NA
Text: of drug trafficking, and if those amounts are

Speaker: NA
Text: often exaggerated because it gives the police

Speaker: NA
Text: officers some satisfaction to be able to say that

Speaker: NA
Text: they have caught somebody with $lm worth of

Speaker: NA
Text: heroin, or whatever it may be, there will be a

Speaker: NA
Text: for people to take the risks associated

Speaker: NA
Text: with drug trafficking because they can see huge

Speaker: NA
Text: profits in it.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of these people are very young. The

Speaker: NA
Text: word 'innocent' is probably the wrong one to use

Speaker: NA
Text: to describe them, but they start off innocent when

Speaker: NA
Text: they are travellers. Let us point out to these

Speaker: NA
Text: people the risks involved. Let us point out to

Speaker: NA
Text: them that they can finish up in gaol in Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: or in other countries where it is even less pleasant

Speaker: NA
Text: to be in gaol. Let us point out to them that the

Speaker: NA
Text: actual profit to them will be very much less than

Speaker: NA
Text: the millions of dollars which are talked about,

Speaker: NA
Text: that they will get relatively little out of it and that

Speaker: NA
Text: they take a tremendous risk, quite apart from the

Speaker: NA
Text: morality of making any sort of money out of

Speaker: NA
Text: spreading drug addiction in this country. This is

Speaker: NA
Text: my appeal to the Government. I hope that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister in his reply will point out to me why this

Speaker: NA
Text: third component of the Australian Federal

Speaker: NA
Text: Police Force should not be established and why

Speaker: NA
Text: it should not be possible to move suitable people

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Narcotics Bureau into that special com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ponent of the Federal Police Force.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Text: Is the amendment

Speaker: NA
Text: seconded?

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith)

Speaker: NA
Text: (10.34)- I second the amendment. I know that

Speaker: NA
Text: time is short and that there is to be another

Speaker: NA
Text: speaker in this debate, but I want to make a point

Speaker: NA
Text: because debate on this subject has been going on

Speaker: NA
Text: for some time now. Last year the then Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Business and Consumer Affairs introduced

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation to give powers to what was then

Speaker: NA
Text: called the Australian Narcotics Bureau. At the

Speaker: NA
Text: time he introduced that Bill he said that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: necessary to face the drug menace head on,

Speaker: NA
Text: armed with a law enforcement capacity equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the threat that was posed. I make the point that

Speaker: NA
Text: that was last year and that that Bill went through

Speaker: NA
Text: the Senate on or about 28 August. It gave great

Speaker: NA
Text: powers to the Narcotics Bureau. We said that the

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation was dangerous. We suggested that

Speaker: NA
Text: there be more safeguards.

Speaker: NA
Text: We can now say in retrospect that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: honest legislation because, as you know Mr real

Speaker: NA
Text: Deputy Speaker, the interim report of Mr Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: Williams was handed down on 18 September,

Speaker: NA
Text: only a few days after the Bill went through

Speaker: NA
Text: Senate. That report recommended that the Narcome

Speaker: NA
Text: cotics Bureau be disbanded because it was action

Speaker: NA
Text: inefficient and incompetent. In June of last year,

Speaker: NA
Text: as has been said, the Government appointed a

Speaker: NA
Text: special police team to investigate the murders

Speaker: NA
Text: Douglas and Isabel Wilson. The suggestion was

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Narcotics Bureau had

Speaker: NA
Text: a drug trafficking syndicate. We have not got that

Speaker: NA
Text: report, as the honourable member for Prospect

Speaker: NA
Text: (Dr Klugman) said. There have been more than

Speaker: NA
Text: those two murders. If we look at what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General (Senator Durack) said on

Speaker: NA
Text: August last year, we will realise that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: belief to think that he was making such comwould

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. He made this point:

Speaker: NA
Text: Because of the encouragement that Ihe Government

Speaker: NA
Text: given to the Narcotics Bureau, stronger methods have

Speaker: NA
Text: adopted to combat the situation and to improve the

Speaker: NA
Text: ties of detection. The Federal Bureau of Narcotics has been

Speaker: NA
Text: substantially upgraded.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within a matter of days Mr Justice Williams de-

Speaker: NA
Text: scribed it as inefficient, poorly trained, low in

Speaker: NA
Text: morale, indecisive and poorly led. Something

Speaker: NA
Text: has to be done about this. We do not believe this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation is good enough from the point of view

Speaker: NA
Text: of the people of this country. Simply because of

Speaker: NA
Text: that background we have to look very closely at

Speaker: NA
Text: the information that has been fed to the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It has to be responsible enough to get the

Speaker: NA
Text: best possible people in this area. In answer to an

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment which was moved in the Senate the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Opposition has moved an amendment which would

Speaker: NA
Text: have the effect really of negating the Bill. It wants the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: withdrawn until the current police inquiry into the Narcotics

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau has been completed. That inquiry is not one into the

Speaker: NA
Text: Narcotics Bureau as such. It is a police inquiry into a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: plaint or an allegation that has been made against one

Speaker: NA
Text: unnamed member of the Narcotics Bureau . . . this in-

Speaker: NA
Text: quiry is not one into the Narcotics Bureau as a whole. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: nothing like that. It is an inquiry into allegations that have

Speaker: NA
Text: been made against one man in that Bureau.

Speaker: NA
Text: The other proposal put forward by the Opposition is that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill should not proceed until the Williams Royal Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission has completed its inquiry. My colleague, the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Business and Consumer Affairs in another place has

Speaker: NA
Text: indicated that Mr Justice Williams, the Royal Commissioner,

Speaker: NA
Text: has been made aware ofthe Government's intentions lo pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceed with this legislation. He has not expressed any oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition to that.

Speaker: NA
Text: How anyone could possibly suggest that at that

Speaker: NA
Text: stage Mr Justice Williams supported the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, is beyond belief. That is the sort of argu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment that has been put up. If one wanted to look

Speaker: NA
Text: at Mr Justice Williams's other report, which one

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot do, one would see that this matter was not

Speaker: NA
Text: disrelated to one man in the Narcotics Bureau. The

Speaker: NA
Text: problem that we have in this country is that

Speaker: NA
Text: there appears to have been massive infiltration of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Narcotics Bureau. Allegations were made

Speaker: NA
Text: the that in every case when information seemed to

Speaker: NA
Text: to the notice of the Narcotics Bureau no

Speaker: NA
Text: took place or criminals were alerted to the

Speaker: NA
Text: fact that perhaps action was to be taken against

Speaker: NA
Text: them. It is incredible to think that we will now

Speaker: NA
Text: of say: 'Everything is all right. Only one or two

Speaker: NA
Text: people are involved. Everybody else is clean'.

Speaker: NA
Text: been infiltrated by That is not so.

Speaker: NA
Text: We want to look at the issues which Mr Justice

Speaker: NA
Text: Williams raised with the Government. We raised

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of warrants for telephone tapping

Speaker: NA
Text: 28 and the Government rejected those amend-

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond ments. Honourable members can imagine what

Speaker: NA
Text: happen if people who do not have the in-

Speaker: NA
Text: tegrity they should have are able to use these

Speaker: NA
Text: sorts of devices to intrude into everybody else's

Speaker: NA
Text: has privacy. What sort of power are we unleashing in

Speaker: NA
Text: been this area? We make it clear that the Williams re-

Speaker: NA
Text: possibiliport was an indictment of the Government. It

Speaker: NA
Text: highlighted its ineptitude and its dishonesty.

Speaker: NA
Text: There are many disquieting feature: of this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation. We are particularly concerned at the

Speaker: NA
Text: wholesale transfer of the Narcotics Bureau to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Federal Police. We asked questions

Speaker: NA
Text: about this matter on 26 March and again today.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole thrust of those questions was about

Speaker: NA
Text: the serious charges that have been levelled at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau. They just cannot be swept aside. But we

Speaker: NA
Text: have not had responsible answers. These are ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tremely serious matters. The two most serious

Speaker: NA
Text: are, first, that the Bureau was infiltrated by drug

Speaker: NA
Text: traffickers and, secondly, that it was generally

Speaker: NA
Text: inept, inefficient and poorly trained. Williams

Speaker: NA
Text: says that in his report. He makes an important

Speaker: NA
Text: point talking about the special police report into

Speaker: NA
Text: the murders. We do not have it and he obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: did not have it. He said:

Speaker: NA
Text: It is unfortunate that the repon of the four police

Speaker: NA
Text: not available at the time of writing. The Commission be-

Speaker: NA
Text: lieves the police officers' report will have a general sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificance of greater imponance than that simply in relation

Text: to the Wilsons' allegations.

Speaker: NA
Text: course, the security of systems of criminal intelligence

Speaker: NA
Text: against abuse and misuse by the persons entrusted with the

Speaker: NA
Text: information.

Speaker: NA
Text: We make the point that that report has not yet

Speaker: NA
Text: been made available to us. This is a most serious

Speaker: NA
Text: matter. Yet, once again, we have been asked to

Speaker: NA
Text: pass this legislation. Infiltration of the Narcotics

Speaker: NA
Text: Bureau could perhaps involve only a handful of

Speaker: NA
Text: officers. But we would like to know that

Speaker: NA
Text: all been cleared. However, the allegations of cor-

Text: ruption have been made by people who have electronic

Text: subsequently been murdered. One can underuse

Speaker: NA
Text: stand the concern of officers of the Australian

Text: Federal Police that they may be forced to work

Text: formation concerning both informants and

Text: officers in deep cover. If we looked at the centres
