Text: The following answers to questions were circula

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Health,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 27 September 1979:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Are any statistics available

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) general practitioners and (b) medical specialists who fre-

Speaker: NA
Text: quently charge above-Schedule fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, what is the frequency per total services of above-

Speaker: NA
Text: Schedule fee charges and for what services are they most

Speaker: NA
Text: pronounced as a percentage of (a) services and (b) Schedule

Speaker: NA
Text: fees.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr MACKellar-Th e answer to the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) and (2) The information sought by the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the number of general practitioners and medical

Speaker: NA
Text: specialists who frequently charge above Schedule fees is not

Speaker: NA
Text: available from the existing analyses of medical benefit

Speaker: NA
Text: claims. Consideration will be given to the possible inclusion

Speaker: NA
Text: of a development computer analysis, after my Department

Speaker: NA
Text: has been able to bring the more conventional analyses on

Speaker: NA
Text: line. Until the developmental analysis has been tried, it will

Speaker: NA
Text: not be known whether the exact type of information sought

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honourable member can be produced from the claims

Speaker: NA
Text: data.

Speaker: NA
Text: In respect of total and selected individual medical services

Speaker: NA
Text: and specialties, some overall statistics on the level of observ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of Medical Benefits Schedule fees from conventional

Speaker: NA
Text: analyses were issued in my Press statements Nos 130/79 of 4

Speaker: NA
Text: November and 149/79 of 2 December 1979.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mail Redirection Orders

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Innes asked the Minister for Post and

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications, upon notice, on 19

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many redirection orders for mail are lodged with

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post each year.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) For what period(s) of time do these orders operate.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How many orders are renewed (a) once, (b) twice,

Speaker: NA
Text: and (c) more than twice.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) For what periods do renewals operate.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What is the scale of charges for redirection orders and

Speaker: NA
Text: renewals, including any rebates, etc.

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) For the past two years, the annual figure has been ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: proximately 800,000.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Although periods of redirection are recorded at indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: vidual post offices, details are not available in a consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: form.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Details are not available. Renewals of redirection

Speaker: NA
Text: orders are treated as new orders.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) See (2) and (3) above. Renewals operate for the

Speaker: NA
Text: length of time requested by the customer. ('Temporary'

Speaker: NA
Text: redirections are restricted to a maximum period of one year.)

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) The scale of charges for redirection orders is as

Speaker: NA
Text: follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Speaker: NA
Text: Doctors' Fees Business and Government-$6.7 0 per month.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 4763) Pensioners (as specified by Commonwealth Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Social Security)-N o charge for first month of

Speaker: NA
Text: redirection then $2.00 per month thereafter.

Speaker: NA
Text: Other customers-$2.0 0 per month.

Speaker: NA
Text: concerning the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: Where applicants request that redirections be discon-

Speaker: NA
Text: tinued, they are eligible for a refund of the redirection service

Speaker: NA
Text: fee paid for each full month of the nominated period for

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Document Transmission Equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. S392)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Innes asked the Minister for Post and

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications, upon notice, on 20

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is terrestrial equipment which is necessaiy to enable

Speaker: NA
Text: complete newspaper pages to be electronically transmitted

Speaker: NA
Text: between Australian cities (a) currently installed, (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: planned, or (c) operational elsewhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Who (a) owns and operates the varying parts of the

Speaker: NA
Text: technology if terrestrial equipment is currently installed, or

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) will own or operate the varying parts of the technology if

Speaker: NA
Text: the equipment is planned for installation.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is this equipment planned for (a) introduction, or (b)

Speaker: NA
Text: commercial use in Australia; if so, when.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What are the costs of installing equipment capable of

Speaker: NA
Text: these transmissions between capital cities.

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5290)

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Terrestrial equipment used to enable complete

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper pages to be electronically transmitted between

Speaker: NA
Text: cities is in operation in Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Telecom Australia's involvement in these services is

Speaker: NA
Text: limited to providing suitable transmission facilities. Telecom

Speaker: NA
Text: acts solely as a common carrier in these instances. The trans-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission facilities comprise suitably prepared broadened

Speaker: NA
Text: transmission links which are extended to the customers

Speaker: NA
Text: premises. Equipment used for transmitting and receiving the

Speaker: NA
Text: newspaper pages is provided and owned by the customer

Speaker: NA
Text: and is connected to the Telecom network under permitted

Speaker: NA
Text: attachment arrangements. Arrangements for operation and

Speaker: NA
Text: maintenance of the privately owned facsimile equipment is

Speaker: NA
Text: left to the customer.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) See(l)above.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) The costs involved in providing the facsimile equip-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are private to the customer. The transmission facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: for newspapers are provided on a part-time basis and at

Speaker: NA
Text: other times the same equipment is used for public communi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations purposes. The facilities are provided at a tariff which

Speaker: NA
Text: is appropriate to the bandwidth involved and to the hours of

Speaker: NA
Text: normal usage.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post: Motor Vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5395)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Innes asked the Minister for Post and

Speaker: NA
Text: Telecommunications, upon notice, on 20

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Further to the answer to Quesuon No. 4534 (Hansard,

Speaker: NA
Text: 22 November 1979, pages 3464-5), why does Australia Post

Speaker: NA
Text: operate 26 times as many V8 vehicles as does Telecom

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, having as it does, 52 V8s in a total vehicle comp-

Speaker: NA
Text: lement of 2,262, compared with Telecom's 14 V8s in a fleet

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Why does Australia Post operate 2.16 times as many 6

Speaker: NA
Text: cylinder vehicles as does Telecom, having as it does, 1,527 6

Speaker: NA
Text: cylinder vehicles in a total vehicle complement of 2,262,

Speaker: NA
Text: compared with Telecom's 5,000 6 cylinder vehicles in a fleet

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Why does Australia Post operate 0.44 times as many

Speaker: NA
Text: cylinder vehicles as does Telecom.

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) to (3) It is suggested that the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: have misinterpreted my answer to

Speaker: NA
Text: 4534. It will be noted in part

Speaker: NA
Text: dition to the totals given, Telecom Australia operates 6,000

Speaker: NA
Text: heavy trucks which have either V8 or 6 cylinder

Speaker: NA
Text: bringing Telecom's total vehicle complement to 22,014.

Speaker: NA
Text: When this is taken into account,

Speaker: NA
Text: question, Australia Post in fact operates only

Speaker: NA
Text: many V8 and 6 cylinder vehicles as does Telecom Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Similarly, Australia Post operates 0.6 times as many four

Speaker: NA
Text: inder vehicles in its fleet in comparison with Telecom

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post and Telecom Australia, however, should be

Speaker: NA
Text: viewed as separate entities. Direct comparison between the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commissions' fleets is not considered appropriate

Speaker: NA
Text: the widely different nature of the services they offer. Most of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Post's larger engine vehicles

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the current drive to conserve

Speaker: NA
Text: gressively considered for replacement by vehicles with

Speaker: NA
Text: smaller engines at the appropriate time.

Speaker: NA
Text: Labour Force Statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 20

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: What percentage of the total Australian labour force is

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in (a) the production of commodities for export

Speaker: NA
Text: (including food, minerals, wool and manufactured goods)

Speaker: NA
Text: and (b) the production of goods which are subject to direct

Speaker: NA
Text: import competition.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: Official statistics of actual employment in the activities

Speaker: NA
Text: ferred to in the honourable member's quesuon are not

Speaker: NA
Text: collected.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only available official statistics relating to employ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment are classified by broad industry groups. Within these

Speaker: NA
Text: groups, individual businesses may be involved in the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction of goods for the domestic market only, for the export

Speaker: NA
Text: market only, or both. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: the breakdown of the Australian labour force asked for.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, persons interested in making broad estimates of

Speaker: NA
Text: the proportion of the Australian labour force engaged in the

Speaker: NA
Text: activities mentioned could derive rough figures on the basis

Speaker: NA
Text: of available employment statistics in associauon with other

Speaker: NA
Text: official statistics on commodity production and overseas

Speaker: NA
Text: trade.

Text: Post and Telecommunications: Galbally Report

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5636)

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5399) Dr Cass asked the Minister for Post and Tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: communications, upon notice, on 6 March 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) At what stage of (a) development and (b) implemen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tation are the following recommendations made by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Galbally report: 51, 52, 53 and 54 for which his Department

Speaker: NA
Text: is responsible.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What sum has been spent specifically on each of the

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations in part ( I ) in (a) each financial year since

Speaker: NA
Text: acceptance of the report and (b) the period 1 July to 31

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1979.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) How much ofthe funds recommended in the report for

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure on each of the recommendations within his port-

Text: folio has been spent on (a)refugeesettlement, (b) refugee

Speaker: NA
Text: programs, (c) refugee organisations, (d) other organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: resupporting refugees and (e) employment of staff to help with

Speaker: NA
Text: refugee settlement in (i) each financial year since the report

Speaker: NA
Text: was accepted and (ii) the period 1 July to 31 December

Text: tation of any recommendation, but not spent, in a specific

Speaker: NA
Text: financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: not therefore possible to provide

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) What (a) specific skills and (b) experiences are

Text: required of the persons employed on the implementation of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: communities.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Italian, (b) Greek, (c) Yugoslav and (d) Arabic ethnic

Speaker: NA
Text: groups and at what level are they employed.

Speaker: NA
Text: (7) What mechanisms of (a) consultation and (b) co-

Speaker: NA
Text: ordination exist between his Department and the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (8) What (a) funds have been provided over and above

Speaker: NA
Text: the recommendations in the report and (b) new programs

Speaker: NA
Text: have been initiated by his

Speaker: NA
Text: the spirit ofthe report.

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Recommendation 51-Th e transmitter for 3EA Mel-

Speaker: NA
Text: bourne began broadcasting on 5kW in January 1980 and the

Speaker: NA
Text: upgrading of 2EA is expected to be completed by the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: April 1980. Wollongong and Newcastle have been linked to

Speaker: NA
Text: 2EA by way of translator stations which began broadcasting

Speaker: NA
Text: in August 1979.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has yet to consider a timetable and

Speaker: NA
Text: method for the extension of ethnic radio to the other centres

Speaker: NA
Text: mentioned in the Galbally report. In the meantime, the SBS

Speaker: NA
Text: subsidises ethnic radio on public broadcasting stations in

Speaker: NA
Text: these and other centres.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recommendation 52- A survey of Italian, Serbo-

Speaker: NA
Text: Croatian, Spanish and Arabic listeners to ethnic radio in

Speaker: NA
Text: Sydney and Melbourne was conducted in June 1978. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: expected that a further survey of other communities will be

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted before June 1980.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recommendation 53-Th e SBS has conducted two series

Speaker: NA
Text: of 13 week experiments in ethnic television, which are

Speaker: NA
Text: broadcast on the ABC each Sunday morning.

Speaker: NA
Text: Recommendation 54-Followin g a report from NEBAC

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Council was unable to conduct public consultations

Speaker: NA
Text: on the future role of ethnic television, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed the Ethnic Television Review Panel, chaired by

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Frank Galbally, to undertake the consultations. The Eth-

Speaker: NA
Text: nic Television Review Panel produced 3 reports for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government, and as a result, the Independent and Multicul-

Speaker: NA
Text: tural Broadcasting Corporation will be established to oper-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate a permanent ethnic television service in Sydney and

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: People employed in the Television Branch have experience

Speaker: NA
Text: in television production and/or ethnic affairs.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) At present the Policy Secretariat does not contain

Speaker: NA
Text: viduals of Italian. Greek, Yugoslav or Arabic background,

Speaker: NA
Text: but the Television Branch employs 6 Italians, 5 Greeks, 3

Speaker: NA

Text: capacity.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Marine Radios

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5681)

Speaker: NA
Text: Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Post

Speaker: NA
Text: and Telecommunications, upon notice, on 19

Speaker: NA
Text: March 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: When will single sideband transmission for the inter-

Speaker: NA
Text: national distress frequency be available for marine radios in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia as it is in the United States of America.

Speaker: Mr STALEY
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The World Administrative Radio Conference (WARC) of

Speaker: NA
Text: the International Telecommunication Union which met at

Speaker: NA
Text: Geneva in late 1979 considered the use of a single sideband

Speaker: NA
Text: (SSB) techniques for distress and safety purposes on the dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tress frequency 2182 kHz. Although the Conference recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised the inherent operational advantages of SSB to the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rently employed double sideband (DSB) mode, it also

Speaker: NA
Text: identified that SSB equipment must be designed to work

Speaker: NA
Text: with closer frequency tolerance and higher technical stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards than those necessary for DSB equipment.

Speaker: NA
Text: To this end, the WARC resolved that continuation of the

Speaker: NA
Text: study of the use of SSB for distress and safety purposes, now

Speaker: NA
Text: being undertaken by a technical committee of the Union, is

Speaker: NA
Text: required but added that arecommendationshould be made

Speaker: NA
Text: sufficiently in advance of the next WARC competent to deal

Speaker: NA
Text: with the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In view of this Resolution of the 1979 WARC, it would

Speaker: NA
Text: seem unwise for Australia to deviate from the currently ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cepted world practice without full consideration being given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: In the meantime, the Australian Administration in con-

Speaker: NA
Text: forming with the International Radio Regulations has

Speaker: NA
Text: elected to continue authorising proven DSB techniques for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1978-79 1.7.79-31.12.79 the international distress frequency as a means of providing

Speaker: NA
Text: reliable distress and safety communications.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tradesmen Statistics

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5705)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Les MCMahon asked the Minister for Em-

Speaker: NA
Text: ployment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26

Speaker: NA
Text: March 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: spent are returned to the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: What was the shortfall in the number of tradesmen

Speaker: NA
Text: required by industry for the year 1978-79 in (a) New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales, (b) Victoria, (c) Queensland, (d) Western Australia,

Speaker: NA
Text: (e) South Australia, (f) Tasmania, (g) the Northern Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory and (h) the Australian Capital Territory.

Speaker: Mr VINER
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The information is not collected. However, a Survey con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducted by the Metal Trades Industry Association in New

Speaker: NA
Text: indiSouth Wales, Victoria, Queensland and South Australia last

Speaker: NA
Text: year revealed that at 31 October 1979 the 743 firms which

Speaker: NA
Text: responded had a total of 1,321 vacancies for tradesmen.

Speaker: NA
Text: Further details of the results ofthe survey arc available from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Association.

Speaker: NA
Text: Computing Equipment: Offset Arrangements

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 5852)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Uren asked the Minister for Productivity,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice, on 2 April 1980:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What offset under the scheme administered by his De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment was provided by the computer supplier Facom

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia Limited when it first secured the tender for

Speaker: NA
Text: puting equipment for the CSIRO.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What offset has been provided for any subsequent

Speaker: NA
Text: supplies of computing equipment by Facomfor use by the

Speaker: NA
Text: CSIRO.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Newman-Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) None, because the CSIRO has only purchased one

Speaker: NA
Text: small computer from Facom, and the amount involved was

Speaker: NA
Text: less than the threshold at which onsets are required.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) None, because there have been no subsequent pur-

Speaker: NA
Text: comchases of computing equipment from Facom for use by the

Speaker: NA
Text: CSIRO. However Facom has also provided the CSIRO with

Speaker: NA
Text: a large computer, free of capital cost, aimed at fulfilling

Speaker: NA
Text: offset obligations against other Government orders by foster-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing research and development in computer technology.
